Other letters,\r\nlater in date, described him as a little too ready to despond about\r\nhimself; as having been sent away, on that account, to some new railway\r\nworks, to see if change of scene would rouse him; and as having\r\nbenefited in every respect by the experiment\xe2\x80\x94except perhaps in regard\r\nto his professional studies, which still advanced but slowly.\r\nSubsequent communications announced his departure, under care of a\r\ntrustworthy foreman, for some public works in Belgium; touched on the\r\ngeneral benefit he appeared to derive from this new change; praised his\r\nexcellent manners and address, which were of great assistance in\r\nfacilitating business communications with the foreigners\xe2\x80\x94and passed\r\nover in ominous silence the main question of his actual progress in the\r\nacquirement of knowledge. These reports, and many others which\r\nresembled them, were all conscientiously presented by Frank\xe2\x80\x99s friend to\r\nthe attention of Frank\xe2\x80\x99s father. On each occasion, Mr. Clare exulted\r\nover Mr. Vanstone, and Mr. Vanstone quarreled with Mr. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cOne of\r\nthese days you\xe2\x80\x99ll wish you hadn\xe2\x80\x99t laid that wager,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cynic\r\nphilosopher. \xe2\x80\x9cOne of these days I shall have the blessed satisfaction\r\nof pocketing your guinea,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the sanguine friend. Two years had\r\nthen passed since Frank\xe2\x80\x99s departure. In one year more results asserted\r\nthemselves, and settled the question.\r\n\r\nTwo days after Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s return from London, he was called away\r\nfrom the breakfast-table before he had found time enough to look over\r\nhis letters, delivered by the morning\xe2\x80\x99s post. Thrusting them into one\r\nof the pockets of his shooting-jacket, he took the letters out again,\r\nat one grasp, to read them when occasion served, later in the day. The\r\ngrasp included the whole correspondence, with one exception\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nexception being a final report from the civil engineer, which notified\r\nthe termination of the connection between his pupil and himself, and\r\nthe immediate return of Frank to his father\xe2\x80\x99s house.\r\n\r\nWhile this important announcement lay unsuspected in Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npocket, the object of it was traveling home, as fast as railways could\r\ntake him. At half-past ten at night, while Mr. Clare was sitting in\r\nstudious solitude over his books and his green tea, with his favorite\r\nblack cat to keep him company, he heard footsteps in the passage\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ndoor opened\xe2\x80\x94and Frank stood before him.\r\n\r\nOrdinary men would have been astonished. But the philosopher\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncomposure was not to be shaken by any such trifle as the unexpected\r\nreturn of his eldest son. He could not have looked up more calmly from\r\nhis learned volume if Frank had been absent for three minutes instead\r\nof three years.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly what I predicted,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Clare. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t interrupt me by\r\nmaking explanations; and don\xe2\x80\x99t frighten the cat. If there is anything\r\nto eat in the kitchen, get it and go to bed. You can walk over to\r\nCombe-Raven tomorrow and give this message from me to Mr. Vanstone:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Father\xe2\x80\x99s compliments, sir, and I have come back upon your hands like a\r\nbad shilling, as he always said I should. He keeps his own guinea, and\r\ntakes your five; and he hopes you\xe2\x80\x99ll mind what he says to you another\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x99 That is the message. Shut the door after you. Good-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUnder these unfavorable auspices, Mr. Francis Clare made his appearance\r\nthe next morning in the grounds at Combe-Raven; and, something doubtful\r\nof the reception that might await him, slowly approached the precincts\r\nof the house.\r\n\r\nIt was not wonderful that Magdalen should have failed to recognize him\r\nwhen he first appeared in view. He had gone away a backward lad of\r\nseventeen; he returned a young man of twenty. His slim figure had now\r\nacquired strength and grace, and had increased in stature to the medium\r\nheight. The small regular features, which he was supposed to have\r\ninherited from his mother, were rounded and filled out, without having\r\nlost their remarkable delicacy of form. His beard was still in its\r\ninfancy; and nascent lines of whisker traced their modest way sparely\r\ndown his cheeks. His gentle, wandering brown eyes would have looked to\r\nbetter advantage in a woman\xe2\x80\x99s face\xe2\x80\x94they wanted spirit and firmness to\r\nfit them for the face of a man. His hands had the same wandering habit\r\nas his eyes; they were constantly changing from one position to\r\nanother, constantly twisting and turning any little stray thing they\r\ncould pick up. He was undeniably handsome, graceful, well-bred\xe2\x80\x94but no\r\nclose observer could look at him without suspecting that the stout old\r\nfamily stock had begun to wear out in the later generations, and that\r\nMr. Francis Clare had more in him of the shadow of his ancestors than\r\nof the substance.\r\n\r\nWhen the astonishment caused by his appearance had partially subsided,\r\na search was instituted for the missing report. It was found in the\r\nremotest recesses of Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s capacious pocket, and was read by\r\nthat gentleman on the spot.\r\n\r\nThe plain facts, as stated by the engineer, were briefly these: Frank\r\nwas not possessed of the necessary abilities to fit him for his new\r\ncalling; and it was useless to waste time by keeping him any longer in\r\nan employment for which he had no vocation. This, after three years\xe2\x80\x99\r\ntrial, being the conviction on both sides, the master had thought it\r\nthe most straightforward course for the pupil to go home and candidly\r\nplace results before his father and his friends. In some other pursuit,\r\nfor which he was more fit, and in which he could feel an interest, he\r\nwould no doubt display the industry and perseverance which he had been\r\ntoo much discouraged to practice in the profession that he had now\r\nabandoned. Personally, he was liked by all who knew him; and his future\r\nprosperity was heartily desired by the many friends whom he had made in\r\nthe North. Such was the substance of the report, and so it came to an\r\nend.\r\n\r\nMany men would have thought the engineer\xe2\x80\x99s statement rather too\r\ncarefully worded; and, suspecting him of trying to make the best of a\r\nbad case, would have entertained serious doubts on the subject of\r\nFrank\xe2\x80\x99s future. Mr. Vanstone was too easy-tempered and sanguine\xe2\x80\x94and too\r\nanxious, as well, not to yield his old antagonist an inch more ground\r\nthan he could help\xe2\x80\x94to look at the letter from any such unfavorable\r\npoint of view. Was it Frank\xe2\x80\x99s fault if he had not got the stuff in him\r\nthat engineers were made of? Did no other young men ever begin life\r\nwith a false start? Plenty began in that way, and got over it, and did\r\nwonders afterward. With these commentaries on the letter, the\r\nkind-hearted gentleman patted Frank on the shoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cCheer up, my\r\nlad!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Vanstone. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will be even with your father one of these\r\ndays, though he _has_ won the wager this time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe example thus set by the master of the house was followed at once by\r\nthe family\xe2\x80\x94with the solitary exception of Norah, whose incurable\r\nformality and reserve expressed themselves, not too graciously, in her\r\ndistant manner toward the visitor. The rest, led by Magdalen (who had\r\nbeen Frank\xe2\x80\x99s favorite playfellow in past times) glided back into their\r\nold easy habits with him without an effort. He was \xe2\x80\x9cFrank\xe2\x80\x9d with all of\r\nthem but Norah, who persisted in addressing him as \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Clare.\xe2\x80\x9d Even\r\nthe account he was now encouraged to give of the reception accorded to\r\nhim by his father, on the previous night, failed to disturb Norah\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngravity. She sat with her dark, handsome face steadily averted, her\r\neyes cast down, and the rich color in her cheeks warmer and deeper than\r\nusual. All the rest, Miss Garth included, found old Mr. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s speech\r\nof welcome to his son quite irresistible. The noise and merriment were\r\nat their height when the servant came in, and struck the whole party\r\ndumb by the announcement of visitors in the drawing-room. \xe2\x80\x9cMr.\r\nMarrable, Mrs. Marrable, and Miss Marrable; Evergreen Lodge, Clifton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNorah rose as readily as if the new arrivals had been a relief to her\r\nmind. Mrs. Vanstone was the next to leave her chair. These two went\r\naway first, to receive the visitors. Magdalen, who preferred the\r\nsociety of her father and Frank, pleaded hard to be left behind; but\r\nMiss Garth, after granting five minutes\xe2\x80\x99 grace, took her into custody\r\nand marched her out of the room. Frank rose to take his leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Vanstone, detaining him. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t go. These people\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t stop long. Mr. Marrable\xe2\x80\x99s a merchant at Bristol. I\xe2\x80\x99ve met him\r\nonce or twice, when the girls forced me to take them to parties at\r\nClifton. Mere acquaintances, nothing more. Come and smoke a cigar in\r\nthe greenhouse. Hang all visitors\xe2\x80\x94they worry one\xe2\x80\x99s life out. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nappear at the last moment with an apology; and you shall follow me at a\r\nsafe distance, and be a proof that I was really engaged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nProposing this ingenious stratagem in a confidential whisper, Mr.\r\nVanstone took Frank\xe2\x80\x99s arm and led him round the house by the back way.\r\nThe first ten minutes of seclusion in the conservatory passed without\r\nevents of any kind. At the end of that time, a flying figure in bright\r\ngarments flashed upon the two gentlemen through the glass\xe2\x80\x94the door was\r\nflung open\xe2\x80\x94flower-pots fell in homage to passing petticoats\xe2\x80\x94and Mr.\r\nVanstone\xe2\x80\x99s youngest daughter ran up to him at headlong speed, with\r\nevery external appearance of having suddenly taken leave of her senses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa! the dream of my whole life is realized,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, as soon as\r\nshe could speak. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall fly through the roof of the greenhouse if\r\nsomebody doesn\xe2\x80\x99t hold me down. Guess, you darling\xe2\x80\x94guess what they\xe2\x80\x99re going to give at\r\nEvergreen Lodge!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA ball!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Vanstone, without a moment\xe2\x80\x99s hesitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrivate Theatricals!!!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Magdalen, her clear young voice ringing\r\nthrough the conservatory like a bell; her loose sleeves falling back\r\nand showing her round white arms to the dimpled elbows, as she clapped\r\nher hands ecstatically in the air. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The Rivals\xe2\x80\x99 is the play, papa\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98The\r\nRivals,\xe2\x80\x99 by the famous what\xe2\x80\x99s-his-name\xe2\x80\x94and they want ME to act! The one\r\nthing in the whole universe that I long to do most. It all depends on\r\nyou. Mamma shakes her head; and Miss Garth looks daggers; and Norah\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nas sulky as usual\xe2\x80\x94but if you say Yes, they must all three give way and\r\nlet me do as I like. Say Yes,\xe2\x80\x9d she pleaded, nestling softly up to her\r\nfather, and pressing her lips with a fond gentleness to his ear, as she\r\nwhispered the next words. \xe2\x80\x9cSay Yes, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll be a good girl for the\r\nrest of my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA good girl?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca mad girl, I think you must\r\nmean. Hang these people and their theatricals! I shall have to go\r\nindoors and see about this matter. You needn\xe2\x80\x99t throw away your cigar,\r\nFrank. You\xe2\x80\x99re well out of the business, and you can stop here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he can\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s in the business, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Francis Clare had hitherto remained modestly in the background. He\r\nnow came forward with a face expressive of speechless amazement.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Magdalen, answering his blank look of inquiry with\r\nperfect composure. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are to act. Miss Marrable and I have a turn for\r\nbusiness, and we settled it all in five minutes. There are two parts in\r\nthe play left to be filled. One is Lucy, the waiting-maid; which is the\r\ncharacter I have undertaken\xe2\x80\x94with papa\xe2\x80\x99s permission,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, slyly\r\npinching her father\xe2\x80\x99s arm; \xe2\x80\x9cand he won\xe2\x80\x99t say No, will he? First,\r\nbecause he\xe2\x80\x99s a darling; secondly, because I love him, and he loves me;\r\nthirdly, because there is never any difference of opinion between us\r\n(is there?); fourthly, because I give him a kiss, which naturally stops\r\nhis mouth and settles the whole question. Dear me, I\xe2\x80\x99m wandering. Where\r\nwas I just now? Oh yes! explaining myself to Frank\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d began Frank, attempting, at this point, to enter\r\nhis protest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe second character in the play,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Magdalen, without taking\r\nthe smallest notice of the protest, \xe2\x80\x9cis Falkland\xe2\x80\x94a jealous lover, with\r\na fine flow of language. Miss Marrable and I discussed Falkland\r\nprivately on the window-seat while the rest were talking. She is a\r\ndelightful girl\xe2\x80\x94so impulsive, so sensible, so entirely unaffected. She\r\nconfided in me. She said: \xe2\x80\x98One of our miseries is that we can\xe2\x80\x99t find a\r\ngentleman who will grapple with the hideous difficulties of Falkland.\xe2\x80\x99\r\nOf course I soothed her. Of course I said: \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the gentleman, and\r\nhe shall grapple immediately.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Oh heavens! who is he?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Mr. Francis\r\nClare.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98And where is he?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98In the house at this moment.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Will you be\r\nso very charming, Miss Vanstone, as to fetch him?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99ll fetch him,\r\nMiss Marrable, with the greatest pleasure.\xe2\x80\x99 I left the window-seat\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nrushed into the morning-room\xe2\x80\x94I smelled cigars\xe2\x80\x94I followed the smell\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nhere I am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a compliment, I know, to be asked to act,\xe2\x80\x9d said Frank, in great\r\nembarrassment. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I hope you and Miss Marrable will excuse me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not. Miss Marrable and I are both remarkable for the\r\nfirmness of our characters. When we say Mr. So-and-So is positively to\r\nact the part of Falkland, we positively mean it. Come in and be\r\nintroduced.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I never tried to act. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot of the slightest consequence. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t know how, come to me\r\nand I\xe2\x80\x99ll teach you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mr. Vanstone. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you know about it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray, papa, be serious! I have the strongest internal conviction that\r\nI could act every character in the play\xe2\x80\x94Falkland included. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let me\r\nhave to speak a second time, Frank. Come and be introduced.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe took her father\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and moved on with him to the door of the\r\ngreenhouse. At the steps, she turned and looked round to see if Frank\r\nwas following her. It was only the action of a moment; but in that\r\nmoment her natural firmness of will rallied all its\r\nresources\xe2\x80\x94strengthened itself with the influence of her beauty\r\n\xe2\x80\x94commanded\xe2\x80\x94and conquered. She looked lovely: the flush was tenderly\r\nbright in her cheeks; the radiant pleasure shone and sparkled in her\r\neyes; the position of her figure, turned suddenly from the waist\r\nupward, disclosed its delicate strength, its supple firmness, its\r\nseductive, serpentine grace. \xe2\x80\x9cCome!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a coquettish\r\nbeckoning action of her head. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, Frank!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFew men of forty would have resisted her at that moment. Frank was\r\ntwenty last birthday. In other words, he threw aside his cigar, and\r\nfollowed her out of the greenhouse.\r\n\r\nAs he turned and closed the door\xe2\x80\x94in the instant when he lost sight of\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94his disinclination to be associated with the private theatricals\r\nrevived. At the foot of the house-steps he stopped again; plucked a\r\ntwig from a plant near him; broke it in his hand; and looked about him\r\nuneasily, on this side and on that. The path to the left led back to\r\nhis father\xe2\x80\x99s cottage\xe2\x80\x94the way of escape lay open. Why not take it?\r\n\r\nWhile he still hesitated, Mr. Vanstone and his daughter reached the top\r\nof the steps. Once more, Magdalen looked round\xe2\x80\x94looked with her\r\nresistless beauty, with her all-conquering smile. She beckoned again;\r\nand again he followed her\xe2\x80\x94up the steps, and over the threshold. The\r\ndoor closed on them.\r\n\r\nSo, with a trifling gesture of invitation on one side, with a trifling\r\nact of compliance on the other: so\xe2\x80\x94with no knowledge in his mind, with\r\nno thought in hers, of the secret still hidden under the journey to\r\nLondon\xe2\x80\x94they took the way which led to that secret\xe2\x80\x99s discovery, through\r\nmany a darker winding that was yet to come.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V.\r\n\r\nMr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s inquiries into the proposed theatrical entertainment at\r\nEvergreen Lodge were answered by a narrative of dramatic disasters; of\r\nwhich Miss Marrable impersonated the innocent cause, and in which her\r\nfather and mother played the parts of chief victims.\r\n\r\nMiss Marrable was that hardest of all born tyrants\xe2\x80\x94an only child. She\r\nhad never granted a constitutional privilege to her oppressed father\r\nand mother since the time when she cut her first tooth. Her seventeenth\r\nbirthday was now near at hand; she had decided on celebrating it by\r\nacting a play; had issued her orders accordingly; and had been obeyed\r\nby her docile parents as implicitly as usual. Mrs. Marrable gave up the\r\ndrawing-room to be laid waste for a stage and a theater. Mr. Marrable\r\nsecured the services of a respectable professional person to drill the\r\nyoung ladies and gentlemen, and to accept all the other\r\nresponsibilities incidental to creating a dramatic world out of a\r\ndomestic chaos. Having further accustomed themselves to the breaking of\r\nfurniture and the staining of walls\xe2\x80\x94to thumping, tumbling, hammering,\r\nand screaming; to doors always banging, and to footsteps perpetually\r\nrunning up and down stairs\xe2\x80\x94the nominal master and mistress of the house\r\nfondly believed that their chief troubles were over. Innocent and fatal\r\ndelusion! It is one thing in private society to set up the stage and\r\nchoose the play\xe2\x80\x94it is another thing altogether to find the actors.\r\nHitherto, only the small preliminary annoyances proper to the occasion\r\nhad shown themselves at Evergreen Lodge. The sound and serious troubles\r\nwere all to come.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Rivals\xe2\x80\x9d having been chosen as the play, Miss Marrable, as a matter\r\nof course, appropriated to herself the part of \xe2\x80\x9cLydia Languish.\xe2\x80\x9d One of\r\nher favored swains next secured \xe2\x80\x9cCaptain Absolute,\xe2\x80\x9d and another laid\r\nviolent hands on \xe2\x80\x9cSir Lucius O\xe2\x80\x99Trigger.\xe2\x80\x9d These two were followed by an\r\naccommodating spinster relative, who accepted the heavy dramatic\r\nresponsibility of \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Malaprop\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and there the theatrical proceedings\r\ncame to a pause. Nine more speaking characters were left to be fitted\r\nwith representatives; and with that unavoidable necessity the serious\r\ntroubles began.\r\n\r\nAll the friends of the family suddenly became unreliable people, for\r\nthe first time in their lives. After encouraging the idea of the play,\r\nthey declined the personal sacrifice of acting in it\xe2\x80\x94or, they accepted\r\ncharacters, and then broke down in the effort to study them\xe2\x80\x94or they\r\nvolunteered to take the parts which they knew were already engaged, and\r\ndeclined the parts which were waiting to be acted\xe2\x80\x94or they were\r\nafflicted with weak constitutions, and mischievously fell ill when they\r\nwere wanted at rehearsal\xe2\x80\x94or they had Puritan relatives in the\r\nbackground, and, after slipping into their parts cheerfully at the\r\nweek\xe2\x80\x99s beginning, oozed out of them penitently, under serious family\r\npressure, at the week\xe2\x80\x99s end. Meanwhile, the carpenters hammered and the\r\nscenes rose. Miss Marrable, whose temperament was sensitive, became\r\nhysterical under the strain of perpetual anxiety; the family doctor\r\ndeclined to answer for the nervous consequences if something was not\r\ndone. Renewed efforts were made in every direction. Actors and\r\nactresses were sought with a desperate disregard of all considerations\r\nof personal fitness. Necessity, which knows no law, either in the drama\r\nor out of it, accepted a lad of eighteen as the representative of \xe2\x80\x9cSir\r\nAnthony Absolute\xe2\x80\x9d; the stage-manager undertaking to supply the\r\nnecessary wrinkles from the illimitable resources of theatrical art. A\r\nlady whose age was unknown, and whose personal appearance was stout\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nwhose heart was in the right place\xe2\x80\x94volunteered to act the part of the\r\nsentimental \xe2\x80\x9cJulia,\xe2\x80\x9d and brought with her the dramatic qualification of\r\nhabitually wearing a wig in private life. Thanks to these vigorous\r\nmeasures, the play was at last supplied with representatives\xe2\x80\x94always\r\nexcepting the two unmanageable characters of \xe2\x80\x9cLucy\xe2\x80\x9d the waiting-maid,\r\nand \xe2\x80\x9cFalkland,\xe2\x80\x9d Julia\xe2\x80\x99s jealous lover. Gentlemen came; saw Julia at\r\nrehearsal; observed her stoutness and her wig; omitted to notice that\r\nher heart was in the right place; quailed at the prospect, apologized,\r\nand retired. Ladies read the part of \xe2\x80\x9cLucy\xe2\x80\x9d; remarked that she appeared\r\nto great advantage in the first half of the play, and faded out of it\r\naltogether in the latter half; objected to pass from the notice of the\r\naudience in that manner, when all the rest had a chance of\r\ndistinguishing themselves to the end; shut up the book, apologized, and\r\nretired. In eight days more the night of performance would arrive; a\r\nphalanx of social martyrs two hundred strong had been convened to\r\nwitness it; three full rehearsals were absolutely necessary; and two\r\ncharacters in the play were not filled yet. With this lamentable story,\r\nand with the humblest apologies for presuming on a slight acquaintance,\r\nthe Marrables appeared at Combe-Raven, to appeal to the young ladies\r\nfor a \xe2\x80\x9cLucy,\xe2\x80\x9d and to the universe for a \xe2\x80\x9cFalkland,\xe2\x80\x9d with the mendicant\r\npertinacity of a family in despair.\r\n\r\nThis statement of circumstances\xe2\x80\x94addressed to an audience which included\r\na father of Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s disposition, and a daughter of Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntemperament\xe2\x80\x94produced the result which might have been anticipated from\r\nthe first.\r\n\r\nEither misinterpreting, or disregarding, the ominous silence preserved\r\nby his wife and Miss Garth, Mr. Vanstone not only gave Magdalen\r\npermission to assist the forlorn dramatic company, but accepted an\r\ninvitation to witness the performance for Norah and himself. Mrs.\r\nVanstone declined accompanying them on account of her health; and Miss\r\nGarth only engaged to make one among the audience conditionally on not\r\nbeing wanted at home. The \xe2\x80\x9cparts\xe2\x80\x9d of \xe2\x80\x9cLucy\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cFalkland\xe2\x80\x9d (which the\r\ndistressed family carried about with them everywhere, like incidental\r\nmaladies) were handed to their representatives on the spot. Frank\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfaint remonstrances were rejected without a hearing; the days and hours\r\nof rehearsal were carefully noted down on the covers of the parts; and\r\nthe Marrables took their leave, with a perfect explosion of\r\nthanks\xe2\x80\x94father, mother, and daughter sowing their expressions of\r\ngratitude broadcast, from the drawing-room door to the garden-gates.\r\n\r\nAs soon as the carriage had driven away, Magdalen presented herself to\r\nthe general observation under an entirely new aspect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf any more visitors call to-day,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with the profoundest\r\ngravity of look and manner, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not at home. This is a far more\r\nserious matter than any of you suppose. Go somewhere by yourself,\r\nFrank, and read over your part, and don\xe2\x80\x99t let your attention wander if\r\nyou can possibly help it. I shall not be accessible before the evening.\r\nIf you will come here\xe2\x80\x94with papa\xe2\x80\x99s permission\xe2\x80\x94after tea, my views on the\r\nsubject of Falkland will be at your disposal. Thomas! whatever else the\r\ngardener does, he is not to make any floricultural noises under my\r\nwindow. For the rest of the afternoon I shall be immersed in study\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthe quieter the house is, the more obliged I shall feel to everybody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBefore Miss Garth\xe2\x80\x99s battery of reproof could open fire, before the\r\nfirst outburst of Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s hearty laughter could escape his lips,\r\nshe bowed to them with imperturbable gravity; ascended the house-steps,\r\nfor the first time in her life, at a walk instead of a run, and retired\r\nthen and there to the bedroom regions. Frank\xe2\x80\x99s helpless astonishment at\r\nher disappearance added a new element of absurdity to the scene. He\r\nstood first on one leg and then on the other; rolling and unrolling his\r\npart, and looking piteously in the faces of the friends about him. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nknow I can\xe2\x80\x99t do it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cMay I come in after tea, and hear\r\nMagdalen\xe2\x80\x99s views? Thank you\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll look in about eight. Don\xe2\x80\x99t tell my\r\nfather about this acting, please; I should never hear the last of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThose were the only words he had spirit enough to utter. He drifted\r\naway aimlessly in the direction of the shrubbery, with the part hanging\r\nopen in his hand\xe2\x80\x94the most incapable of Falklands, and the most helpless\r\nof mankind.\r\n\r\nFrank\xe2\x80\x99s departure left the family by themselves, and was the signal\r\naccordingly for an attack on Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s inveterate carelessness in\r\nthe exercise of his paternal authority.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat could you possibly be thinking of, Andrew, when you gave your\r\nconsent?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vanstone. \xe2\x80\x9cSurely my silence was a sufficient\r\nwarning to you to say No?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA mistake, Mr. Vanstone,\xe2\x80\x9d chimed in Miss Garth. \xe2\x80\x9cMade with the best\r\nintentions\xe2\x80\x94but a mistake for all that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be a mistake,\xe2\x80\x9d said Norah, taking her father\xe2\x80\x99s part, as usual.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I really don\xe2\x80\x99t see how papa, or any one else, could have declined,\r\nunder the circumstances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite right, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Mr. Vanstone. \xe2\x80\x9cThe circumstances, as\r\nyou say, were dead against me. Here were these unfortunate people in a\r\nscrape on one side; and Magdalen, on the other, mad to act. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsay I had methodistical objections\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve nothing methodistical about me.\r\nWhat other excuse could I make? The Marrables are respectable people,\r\nand keep the best company in Clifton. What harm can she get in their\r\nhouse? If you come to prudence and that sort of thing\xe2\x80\x94why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nMagdalen do what Miss Marrable does? There! there! let the poor things\r\nact, and amuse themselves. We were their age once\xe2\x80\x94and it\xe2\x80\x99s no use\r\nmaking a fuss\xe2\x80\x94and that\xe2\x80\x99s all I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to say about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that characteristic defense of his own conduct, Mr. Vanstone\r\nsauntered back to the greenhouse to smoke another cigar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t say so to papa,\xe2\x80\x9d said Norah, taking her mother\xe2\x80\x99s arm on the\r\nway back to the house, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the bad result of the acting, in my\r\nopinion, will be the familiarity it is sure to encourage between\r\nMagdalen and Francis Clare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are prejudiced against Frank, my love,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Vanstone.\r\n\r\nNorah\xe2\x80\x99s soft, secret, hazel eyes sank to the ground; she said no more.\r\nHer opinions were unchangeable\xe2\x80\x94but she never disputed with anybody. She\r\nhad the great failing of a reserved nature\xe2\x80\x94the failing of obstinacy;\r\nand the great merit\xe2\x80\x94the merit of silence. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your head running on\r\nnow?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Miss Garth, casting a sharp look at Norah\xe2\x80\x99s dark,\r\ndowncast face. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re one of the impenetrable sort. Give me Magdalen,\r\nwith all her perversities; I can see daylight through her. You\xe2\x80\x99re as\r\ndark as night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hours of the afternoon passed away, and still Magdalen remained\r\nshut up in her own room. No restless footsteps pattered on the stairs;\r\nno nimble tongue was heard chattering here, there, and everywhere, from\r\nthe garret to the kitchen\xe2\x80\x94the house seemed hardly like itself, with the\r\none ever-disturbing element in the family serenity suddenly withdrawn\r\nfrom it. Anxious to witness with her own eyes the reality of a\r\ntransformation in which past experience still inclined her to\r\ndisbelieve, Miss Garth ascended to Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s room, knocked twice at\r\nthe door, received no answer, opened it and looked in.\r\n\r\nThere sat Magdalen, in an arm-chair before the long looking-glass, with\r\nall her hair let down over her shoulders; absorbed in the study of her\r\npart and comfortably arrayed in her morning wrapper, until it was time\r\nto dress for dinner. And there behind her sat the lady\xe2\x80\x99s-maid, slowly\r\ncombing out the long heavy locks of her young mistress\xe2\x80\x99s hair, with the\r\nsleepy resignation of a woman who had been engaged in that employment\r\nfor some hours past. The sun was shining; and the green shutters\r\noutside the window were closed. The dim light fell tenderly on the two\r\nquiet seated figures; on the little white bed, with the knots of\r\nrose-colored ribbon which looped up its curtains, and the bright dress\r\nfor dinner laid ready across it; on the gayly painted bath, with its\r\npure lining of white enamel; on the toilet-table with its sparkling\r\ntrinkets, its crystal bottles, its silver bell with Cupid for a handle,\r\nits litter of little luxuries that adorn the shrine of a woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbed-chamber. The luxurious tranquillity of the scene; the cool\r\nfragrance of flowers and perfumes in the atmosphere; the rapt attitude\r\nof Magdalen, absorbed over her reading; the monotonous regularity of\r\nmovement in the maid\xe2\x80\x99s hand and arm, as she drew the comb smoothly\r\nthrough and through her mistress\xe2\x80\x99s hair\xe2\x80\x94all conveyed the same soothing\r\nimpression of drowsy, delicious quiet. On one side of the door were the\r\nbroad daylight and the familiar realities of life. On the other was the\r\ndream-land of Elysian serenity\xe2\x80\x94the sanctuary of unruffled repose.\r\n\r\nMiss Garth paused on the threshold, and looked into the room in\r\nsilence.\r\n\r\nMagdalen\xe2\x80\x99s curious fancy for having her hair combed at all times and\r\nseasons was among the peculiarities of her character which were\r\nnotorious to everybody in the house. It was one of her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfavorite jokes that she reminded him, on such occasions, of a cat\r\nhaving her back stroked, and that he always expected, if the combing\r\nwere only continued long enough, to hear her _purr_. Extravagant as it\r\nmay seem, the comparison was not altogether inappropriate. The girl\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfervid temperament intensified the essentially feminine pleasure that\r\nmost women feel in the passage of the comb through their hair, to a\r\nluxury of sensation which absorbed her in enjoyment, so serenely\r\nself-demonstrative, so drowsily deep that it did irresistibly suggest a\r\npet cat\xe2\x80\x99s enjoyment under a caressing hand. Intimately as Miss Garth\r\nwas acquainted with this peculiarity in her pupil, she now saw it\r\nasserting itself for the first time, in association with mental\r\nexertion of any kind on Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s part. Feeling, therefore, some\r\ncuriosity to know how long the combing and the studying had gone on\r\ntogether, she ventured on putting the question, first to the mistress;\r\nand (receiving no answer in that quarter) secondly to the maid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the afternoon, miss, off and on,\xe2\x80\x9d was the weary answer. \xe2\x80\x9cMiss\r\nMagdalen says it soothes her feelings and clears her mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nKnowing by experience that interference would be hopeless, under these\r\ncircumstances, Miss Garth turned sharply and left the room. She smiled\r\nwhen she was outside on the landing. The female mind does\r\noccasionally\xe2\x80\x94though not often\xe2\x80\x94project itself into the future. Miss\r\nGarth was prophetically pitying Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s unfortunate husband.\r\n\r\nDinner-time presented the fair student to the family eye in the same\r\nmentally absorbed aspect. On all ordinary occasions Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s appetite\r\nwould have terrified those feeble sentimentalists who affect to ignore\r\nthe all-important influence which female feeding exerts in the\r\nproduction of female beauty. On this occasion she refused one dish\r\nafter another with a resolution which implied the rarest of all modern\r\nmartyrdoms\xe2\x80\x94gastric martyrdom. \xe2\x80\x9cI have conceived the part of Lucy,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nobserved, with the demurest gravity. \xe2\x80\x9cThe next difficulty is to make\r\nFrank conceive the part of Falkland. I see nothing to laugh at\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nwould all be serious enough if you had my responsibilities. No, papa\xe2\x80\x94no\r\nwine to-day, thank you. I must keep my intelligence clear. Water,\r\nThomas\xe2\x80\x94and a little more jelly, I think, before you take it away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Frank presented himself in the evening, ignorant of the first\r\nelements of his part, she took him in hand, as a middle-aged\r\nschoolmistress might have taken in hand a backward little boy. The few\r\nattempts he made to vary the sternly practical nature of the evening\xe2\x80\x99s\r\noccupation by slipping in compliments sidelong she put away from her\r\nwith the contemptuous self-possession of a woman of twice her age. She\r\nliterally forced him into his part. Her father fell asleep in his\r\nchair. Mrs. Vanstone and Miss Garth lost their interest in the\r\nproceedings, retired to the further end of the room, and spoke together\r\nin whispers. It grew later and later; and still Magdalen never flinched\r\nfrom her task\xe2\x80\x94still, with equal perseverance, Norah, who had been on\r\nthe watch all through the evening, kept on the watch to the end. The\r\ndistrust darkened and darkened on her face as she looked at her sister\r\nand Frank; as she saw how close they sat together, devoted to the same\r\ninterest and working to the same end. The clock on the mantel-piece\r\npointed to half-past eleven before Lucy the resolute permitted Falkland\r\nthe helpless to shut up his task-book for the night. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s wonderfully\r\nclever, isn\xe2\x80\x99t she?\xe2\x80\x9d said Frank, taking leave of Mr. Vanstone at the\r\nhall door. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m to come to-morrow, and hear more of her views\xe2\x80\x94if you\r\nhave no objection. I shall never do it; don\xe2\x80\x99t tell her I said so. As\r\nfast as she teaches me one speech, the other goes out of my head.\r\nDiscouraging, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? Goodnight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe next day but one was the day of the first full rehearsal. On the\r\nprevious evening Mrs. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s spirits had been sadly depressed. At a\r\nprivate interview with Miss Garth she had referred again, of her own\r\naccord, to the subject of her letter from London\xe2\x80\x94had spoken\r\nself-reproachfully of her weakness in admitting Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimpudent claim to a family connection with her\xe2\x80\x94and had then reverted to\r\nthe state of her health and to the doubtful prospect that awaited her\r\nin the coming summer in a tone of despondency which it was very\r\ndistressing to hear. Anxious to cheer her spirits, Miss Garth had\r\nchanged the conversation as soon as possible\xe2\x80\x94had referred to the\r\napproaching theatrical performance\xe2\x80\x94and had relieved Mrs. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmind of all anxiety in that direction, by announcing her intention of\r\naccompanying Magdalen to each rehearsal, and of not losing sight of her\r\nuntil she was safely back again in her father\xe2\x80\x99s house. Accordingly,\r\nwhen Frank presented himself at Combe-Raven on the eventful morning,\r\nthere stood Miss Garth, prepared\xe2\x80\x94in the interpolated character of\r\nArgus\xe2\x80\x94to accompany Lucy and Falkland to the scene of trial. The railway\r\nconveyed the three, in excellent time, to Evergreen Lodge; and at one\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock the rehearsal began.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope Miss Vanstone knows her part?\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Mrs. Marrable,\r\nanxiously addressing herself to Miss Garth, in a corner of the theater.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf airs and graces make an actress, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s performance will\r\nastonish us all.\xe2\x80\x9d With that reply, Miss Garth took out her work, and\r\nseated herself, on guard, in the center of the pit.\r\n\r\nThe manager perched himself, book in hand, on a stool close in front of\r\nthe stage. He was an active little man, of a sweet and cheerful temper;\r\nand he gave the signal to begin with as patient an interest in the\r\nproceedings as if they had caused him no trouble in the past and\r\npromised him no difficulty in the future. The two characters which\r\nopened the comedy of The Rivals, \xe2\x80\x9cFag\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThe Coachman,\xe2\x80\x9d appeared on\r\nthe scene\xe2\x80\x94looked many sizes too tall for their canvas background, which\r\nrepresented a \xe2\x80\x9cStreet in Bath\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94exhibited the customary inability to\r\nmanage their own arms, legs, and voices\xe2\x80\x94went out severally at the wrong\r\nexits\xe2\x80\x94and expressed their perfect approval of results, so far, by\r\nlaughing heartily behind the scenes. \xe2\x80\x9cSilence, gentlemen, if you\r\nplease,\xe2\x80\x9d remonstrated the cheerful manager. \xe2\x80\x9cAs loud as you like _on_\r\nthe stage, but the audience mustn\xe2\x80\x99t hear you _off_ it. Miss Marrable\r\nready? Miss Vanstone ready? Easy there with the \xe2\x80\x98Street in Bath\xe2\x80\x99; it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngoing up crooked! Face this way, Miss Marrable; full face, if you\r\nplease. Miss Vanstone\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d he checked himself suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cCurious,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, under his breath\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cshe fronts the audience of her own accord!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nLucy opened the scene in these words: \xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, I traversed half\r\nthe town in search of it: I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe there\xe2\x80\x99s a circulating library\r\nin Bath I haven\xe2\x80\x99t been at.\xe2\x80\x9d The manager started in his chair. \xe2\x80\x9cMy heart\r\nalive! she speaks out without telling!\xe2\x80\x9d The dialogue went on. Lucy\r\nproduced the novels for Miss Lydia Languish\xe2\x80\x99s private reading from\r\nunder her cloak. The manager rose excitably to his feet. Marvelous! No\r\nhurry with the books; no dropping them. She looked at the titles before\r\nshe announced them to her mistress; she set down \xe2\x80\x9cHumphrey Clinker\xe2\x80\x9d on\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Tears of Sensibility\xe2\x80\x9d with a smart little smack which pointed the\r\nantithesis. One moment\xe2\x80\x94and she announced Julia\xe2\x80\x99s visit; another\xe2\x80\x94and she\r\ndropped the brisk waiting-maid\xe2\x80\x99s courtesy; a third\xe2\x80\x94and she was off the\r\nstage on the side set down for her in the book. The manager wheeled\r\nround on his stool, and looked hard at Miss Garth. \xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon,\r\nma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Marrable told me, before we began, that this was\r\nthe young lady\xe2\x80\x99s first attempt. It can\xe2\x80\x99t be, surely!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Miss Garth, reflecting the manager\xe2\x80\x99s look of amazement\r\non her own face. Was it possible that Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s unintelligible\r\nindustry in the study of her part really sprang from a serious interest\r\nin her occupation\xe2\x80\x94an interest which implied a natural fitness for it?\r\n\r\nThe rehearsal went on. The stout lady with the wig (and the excellent\r\nheart) personated the sentimental Julia from an inveterately tragic\r\npoint of view, and used her handkerchief distractedly in the first\r\nscene. The spinster relative felt Mrs. Malaprop\xe2\x80\x99s mistakes in language\r\nso seriously, and took such extraordinary pains with her blunders, that\r\nthey sounded more like exercises in elocution than anything else. The\r\nunhappy lad who led the forlorn hope of the company, in the person of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Anthony Absolute,\xe2\x80\x9d expressed the age and irascibility of his\r\ncharacter by tottering incessantly at the knees, and thumping the stage\r\nperpetually with his stick. Slowly and clumsily, with constant\r\ninterruptions and interminable mistakes, the first act dragged on,\r\nuntil Lucy appeared again to end it in soliloquy, with the confession\r\nof her assumed simplicity and the praise of her own cunning.\r\n\r\nHere the stage artifice of the situation presented difficulties which\r\nMagdalen had not encountered in the first scene\xe2\x80\x94and here, her total\r\nwant of experience led her into more than one palpable mistake. The\r\nstage-manager, with an eagerness which he had not shown in the case of\r\nany other member of the company, interfered immediately, and set her\r\nright. At one point she was to pause, and take a turn on the stage\xe2\x80\x94she\r\ndid it. At another, she was to stop, toss her head, and look pertly at\r\nthe audience\xe2\x80\x94she did it. When she took out the paper to read the list\r\nof the presents she had received, could she give it a tap with her\r\nfinger (Yes)? And lead off with a little laugh (Yes\xe2\x80\x94after twice\r\ntrying)? Could she read the different items with a sly look at the end\r\nof each sentence, straight at the pit (Yes, straight at the pit, and as\r\nsly as you please)? The manager\xe2\x80\x99s cheerful face beamed with approval.\r\nHe tucked the play under his arm, and clapped his hands gayly; the\r\ngentlemen, clustered together behind the scenes, followed his example;\r\nthe ladies looked at each other with dawning doubts whether they had\r\nnot better have left the new recruit in the retirement of private life.\r\nToo deeply absorbed in the business of the stage to heed any of them,\r\nMagdalen asked leave to repeat the soliloquy, and make quite sure of\r\nher own improvement. She went all through it again without a mistake,\r\nthis time, from beginning to end; the manager celebrating her attention\r\nto his directions by an outburst of professional approbation, which\r\nescaped him in spite of himself. \xe2\x80\x9cShe can take a hint!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the\r\nlittle man, with a hearty smack of his hand on the prompt-book. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na born actress, if ever there was one yet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Garth to herself, taking up the work which had\r\ndropped into her lap, and looking down at it in some perplexity. Her\r\nworst apprehension of results in connection with the theatrical\r\nenterprise had foreboded levity of conduct with some of the\r\ngentlemen\xe2\x80\x94she had not bargained for this. Magdalen, in the capacity of\r\na thoughtless girl, was comparatively easy to deal with. Magdalen, in\r\nthe character of a born actress, threatened serious future\r\ndifficulties.\r\n\r\nThe rehearsal proceeded. Lucy returned to the stage for her scenes in\r\nthe second act (the last in which she appears) with Sir Lucius and Fag.\r\nHere, again, Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s inexperience betrayed itself\xe2\x80\x94and here once more\r\nher resolution in attacking and conquering her own mistakes astonished\r\neverybody. \xe2\x80\x9cBravo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the gentlemen behind the scenes, as she\r\nsteadily trampled down one blunder after another. \xe2\x80\x9cRidiculous!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe ladies, \xe2\x80\x9cwith such a small part as hers.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cHeaven forgive me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthought Miss. Garth, coming round unwillingly to the general opinion.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI almost wish we were Papists, and I had a convent to put her in\r\nto-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d One of Mr. Marrable\xe2\x80\x99s servants entered the theater as that\r\ndesperate aspiration escaped the governess. She instantly sent the man\r\nbehind the scene with a message: \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Vanstone has done her part in\r\nthe rehearsal; request her to come here and sit by me.\xe2\x80\x9d The servant\r\nreturned with a polite apology: \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s kind love, and she\r\nbegs to be excused\xe2\x80\x94she\xe2\x80\x99s prompting Mr. Clare.\xe2\x80\x9d She prompted him to such\r\npurpose that he actually got through his part. The performances of the\r\nother gentlemen were obtrusively imbecile. Frank was just one degree\r\nbetter\xe2\x80\x94he was modestly incapable; and he gained by comparison. \xe2\x80\x9cThanks\r\nto Miss Vanstone,\xe2\x80\x9d observed the manager, who had heard the prompting.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe pulled him through. We shall be flat enough at night, when the\r\ndrop falls on the second act, and the audience have seen the last of\r\nher. It\xe2\x80\x99s a thousand pities she hasn\xe2\x80\x99t got a better part!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a thousand mercies she\xe2\x80\x99s no more to do than she has,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered\r\nMiss Garth, overhearing him. \xe2\x80\x9cAs things are, the people can\xe2\x80\x99t well turn\r\nher head with applause. She\xe2\x80\x99s out of the play in the second act\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\none comfort!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo well-regulated mind ever draws its inferences in a hurry; Miss\r\nGarth\xe2\x80\x99s mind was well regulated; therefore, logically speaking, Miss\r\nGarth ought to have been superior to the weakness of rushing at\r\nconclusions. She had committed that error, nevertheless, under present\r\ncircumstances. In plainer terms, the consoling reflection which had\r\njust occurred to her assumed that the play had by this time survived\r\nall its disasters, and entered on its long-deferred career of success.\r\nThe play had done nothing of the sort. Misfortune and the Marrable\r\nfamily had not parted company yet.\r\n\r\nWhen the rehearsal was over, nobody observed that the stout lady with\r\nthe wig privately withdrew herself from the company; and when she was\r\nafterward missed from the table of refreshments, which Mr. Marrable\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhospitality kept ready spread in a room near the theater, nobody\r\nimagined that there was any serious reason for her absence. It was not\r\ntill the ladies and gentlemen assembled for the next rehearsal that the\r\ntrue state of the case was impressed on the minds of the company. At\r\nthe appointed hour no Julia appeared. In her stead, Mrs. Marrable\r\nportentously approached the stage, with an open letter in her hand. She\r\nwas naturally a lady of the mildest good breeding: she was mistress of\r\nevery bland conventionality in the English language\xe2\x80\x94but disasters and\r\ndramatic influences combined, threw even this harmless matron off her\r\nbalance at last. For the first time in her life Mrs. Marrable indulged\r\nin vehement gesture, and used strong language. She handed the letter\r\nsternly, at arms-length, to her daughter. \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with an\r\naspect of awful composure, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are under a Curse.\xe2\x80\x9d Before the amazed\r\ndramatic company could petition for an explanation, she turned and left\r\nthe room. The manager\xe2\x80\x99s professional eye followed her out\r\nrespectfully\xe2\x80\x94he looked as if he approved of the exit, from a theatrical\r\npoint of view.\r\n\r\nWhat new misfortune had befallen the play? The last and worst of all\r\nmisfortunes had assailed it. The stout lady had resigned her part.\r\n\r\nNot maliciously. Her heart, which had been in the right place\r\nthroughout, remained inflexibly in the right place still. Her\r\nexplanation of the circumstances proved this, if nothing else did. The\r\nletter began with a statement: She had overheard, at the last rehearsal\r\n(quite unintentionally), personal remarks of which she was the subject.\r\nThey might, or might not, have had reference to her\xe2\x80\x94Hair; and\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94Figure. She would not distress Mrs. Marrable by repeating them.\r\nNeither would she mention names, because it was foreign to her nature\r\nto make bad worse. The only course at all consistent with her own\r\nself-respect was to resign her part. She inclosed it, accordingly, to\r\nMrs. Marrable, with many apologies for her presumption in undertaking a\r\nyouthful character, at\xe2\x80\x94what a gentleman was pleased to term\xe2\x80\x94her Age;\r\nand with what two ladies were rude enough to characterize as her\r\ndisadvantages of\xe2\x80\x94Hair, and\xe2\x80\x94Figure. A younger and more attractive\r\nrepresentative of Julia would no doubt be easily found. In the\r\nmeantime, all persons concerned had her full forgiveness, to which she\r\nwould only beg leave to add her best and kindest wishes for the success\r\nof the play.\r\n\r\nIn four nights more the play was to be performed. If ever any human\r\nenterprise stood in need of good wishes to help it, that enterprise was\r\nunquestionably the theatrical entertainment at Evergreen Lodge!\r\n\r\nOne arm-chair was allowed on the stage; and into that arm-chair Miss\r\nMarrable sank, preparatory to a fit of hysterics. Magdalen stepped\r\nforward at the first convulsion; snatched the letter from Miss\r\nMarrable\xe2\x80\x99s hand; and stopped the threatened catastrophe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s an ugly, bald-headed, malicious, middle-aged wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMagdalen, tearing the letter into fragments, and tossing them over the\r\nheads of the company. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I can tell her one thing\xe2\x80\x94she shan\xe2\x80\x99t spoil\r\nthe play. I\xe2\x80\x99ll act Julia.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the chorus of gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94the anonymous gentleman who had\r\nhelped to do the mischief (otherwise Mr. Francis Clare) loudest of all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you want the truth, I don\xe2\x80\x99t shrink from owning it,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nMagdalen. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m one of the ladies she means. I said she had a head like\r\na mop, and a waist like a bolster. So she has.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am the other lady,\xe2\x80\x9d added the spinster relative. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I only said\r\nshe was too stout for the part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am the gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d chimed in Frank, stimulated by the force of\r\nexample. \xe2\x80\x9cI said nothing\xe2\x80\x94I only agreed with the ladies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere Miss Garth seized her opportunity, and addressed the stage loudly\r\nfrom the pit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop! Stop!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t settle the difficulty that way. If\r\nMagdalen plays Julia, who is to play Lucy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Marrable sank back in the arm-chair, and gave way to the second\r\nconvulsion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStuff and nonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Magdalen, \xe2\x80\x9cthe thing\xe2\x80\x99s simple enough, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nact Julia and Lucy both together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe manager was consulted on the spot. Suppressing Lucy\xe2\x80\x99s first\r\nentrance, and turning the short dialogue about the novels into a\r\nsoliloquy for Lydia Languish, appeared to be the only changes of\r\nimportance necessary to the accomplishment of Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s project.\r\nLucy\xe2\x80\x99s two telling scenes, at the end of the first and second acts,\r\nwere sufficiently removed from the scenes in which Julia appeared to\r\ngive time for the necessary transformations in dress. Even Miss Garth,\r\nthough she tried hard to find them, could put no fresh obstacles in the\r\nway. The question was settled in five minutes, and the rehearsal went\r\non; Magdalen learning Julia\xe2\x80\x99s stage situations with the book in her\r\nhand, and announcing afterward, on the journey home, that she proposed\r\nsitting up all night to study the new part. Frank thereupon expressed\r\nhis fears that she would have no time left to help him through his\r\ntheatrical difficulties. She tapped him on the shoulder coquettishly\r\nwith her part. \xe2\x80\x9cYou foolish fellow, how am I to do without you? You\xe2\x80\x99re\r\nJulia\xe2\x80\x99s jealous lover; you\xe2\x80\x99re always making Julia cry. Come to-night,\r\nand make me cry at tea-time. You haven\xe2\x80\x99t got a venomous old woman in a\r\nwig to act with now. It\xe2\x80\x99s _my_ heart you\xe2\x80\x99re to break\xe2\x80\x94and of course I\r\nshall teach you how to do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe four days\xe2\x80\x99 interval passed busily in perpetual rehearsals, public\r\nand private. The night of performance arrived; the guests assembled;\r\nthe great dramatic experiment stood on its trial. Magdalen had made the\r\nmost of her opportunities; she had learned all that the manager could\r\nteach her in the time. Miss Garth left her when the overture began,\r\nsitting apart in a corner behind the scenes, serious and silent, with\r\nher smelling-bottle in one hand, and her book in the other, resolutely\r\ntraining herself for the coming ordeal, to the very last.\r\n\r\nThe play began, with all the proper accompaniments of a theatrical\r\nperformance in private life; with a crowded audience, an African\r\ntemperature, a bursting of heated lamp-glasses, and a difficulty in\r\ndrawing up the curtain. \xe2\x80\x9cFag\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthe Coachman,\xe2\x80\x9d who opened the scene,\r\ntook leave of their memories as soon as they stepped on the stage; left\r\nhalf their dialogue unspoken; came to a dead pause; were audibly\r\nentreated by the invisible manager to \xe2\x80\x9ccome off\xe2\x80\x9d; and went off\r\naccordingly, in every respect sadder and wiser men than when they went\r\non. The next scene disclosed Miss Marrable as \xe2\x80\x9cLydia Languish,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ngracefully seated, very pretty, beautifully dressed, accurately\r\nmistress of the smallest words in her part; possessed, in short, of\r\nevery personal resource\xe2\x80\x94except her voice. The ladies admired, the\r\ngentlemen applauded. Nobody heard anything but the words \xe2\x80\x9cSpeak up,\r\nmiss,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered by the same voice which had already entreated \xe2\x80\x9cFag\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand \xe2\x80\x9cthe Coachman\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9ccome off.\xe2\x80\x9d A responsive titter rose among the\r\nyounger spectators; checked immediately by magnanimous applause. The\r\ntemperature of the audience was rising to Blood Heat\xe2\x80\x94but the national\r\nsense of fair play was not boiled out of them yet.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of the demonstration, Magdalen quietly made her first\r\nentrance, as \xe2\x80\x9cJulia.\xe2\x80\x9d She was dressed very plainly in dark colors, and\r\nwore her own hair; all stage adjuncts and alterations (excepting the\r\nslightest possible touch of rouge on her cheeks) having been kept in\r\nreserve to disguise her the more effectually in her second part. The\r\ngrace and simplicity of her costume, the steady self-possession with\r\nwhich she looked out over the eager rows of faces before her, raised a\r\nlow hum of approval and expectation. She spoke\xe2\x80\x94after suppressing a\r\nmomentary tremor\xe2\x80\x94with a quiet distinctness of utterance which reached\r\nall ears, and which at once confirmed the favorable impression that her\r\nappearance had produced. The one member of the audience who looked at\r\nher and listened to her coldly, was her elder sister. Before the\r\nactress of the evening had been five minutes on the stage, Norah\r\ndetected, to her own indescribable astonishment, that Magdalen had\r\naudaciously individualized the feeble amiability of \xe2\x80\x9cJulia\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncharacter, by seizing no less a person than herself as the model to act\r\nit by. She saw all her own little formal peculiarities of manner and\r\nmovement unblushingly reproduced\xe2\x80\x94and even the very tone of her voice so\r\naccurately mimicked from time to time, that the accents startled her as\r\nif she was speaking herself, with an echo on the stage. The effect of\r\nthis cool appropriation of Norah\xe2\x80\x99s identity to theatrical purposes on\r\nthe audience\xe2\x80\x94who only saw results\xe2\x80\x94asserted itself in a storm of\r\napplause on Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s exit. She had won two incontestable triumphs in\r\nher first scene. By a dexterous piece of mimicry, she had made a living\r\nreality of one of the most insipid characters in the English drama; and\r\nshe had roused to enthusiasm an audience of two hundred exiles from the\r\nblessings of ventilation, all simmering together in their own animal\r\nheat. Under the circumstances, where is the actress by profession who\r\ncould have done much more?\r\n\r\nBut the event of the evening was still to come. Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s disguised\r\nre-appearance at the end of the act, in the character of \xe2\x80\x9cLucy\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94with\r\nfalse hair and false eyebrows, with a bright-red complexion and patches\r\non her cheeks, with the gayest colors flaunting in her dress, and the\r\nshrillest vivacity of voice and manner\xe2\x80\x94fairly staggered the audience.\r\nThey looked down at their programmes, in which the representative of\r\nLucy figured under an assumed name; looked up again at the stage;\r\npenetrated the disguise; and vented their astonishment in another round\r\nof applause, louder and heartier even than the last. Norah herself\r\ncould not deny this time that the tribute of approbation had been well\r\ndeserved. There, forcing its way steadily through all the faults of\r\ninexperience\xe2\x80\x94there, plainly visible to the dullest of the spectators,\r\nwas the rare faculty of dramatic impersonation, expressing itself in\r\nevery look and action of this girl of eighteen, who now stood on a\r\nstage for the first time in her life. Failing in many minor requisites\r\nof the double task which she had undertaken, she succeeded in the one\r\nimportant necessity of keeping the main distinctions of the two\r\ncharacters thoroughly apart. Everybody felt that the difficulty lay\r\nhere\xe2\x80\x94everybody saw the difficulty conquered\xe2\x80\x94everybody echoed the\r\nmanager\xe2\x80\x99s enthusiasm at rehearsal, which had hailed her as a born\r\nactress.\r\n\r\nWhen the drop-scene descended for the first time, Magdalen had\r\nconcentrated in herself the whole interest and attraction of the play.\r\nThe audience politely applauded Miss Marrable, as became the guests\r\nassembled in her father\xe2\x80\x99s house: and good-humoredly encouraged the\r\nremainder of the company, to help them through a task for which they\r\nwere all, more or less, palpably unfit. But, as the play proceeded,\r\nnothing roused them to any genuine expression of interest when Magdalen\r\nwas absent from the scene. There was no disguising it: Miss Marrable\r\nand her bosom friends had been all hopelessly cast in the shade by the\r\nnew recruit whom they had summoned to assist them, in the capacity of\r\nforlorn hope. And this on Miss Marrable\xe2\x80\x99s own birthday! and this in her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s house! and this after the unutterable sacrifices of six weeks\r\npast! Of all the domestic disasters which the thankless theatrical\r\nenterprise had inflicted on the Marrable family, the crowning\r\nmisfortune was now consummated by Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s success.\r\n\r\nLeaving Mr. Vanstone and Norah, on the conclusion of the play, among\r\nthe guests in the supper-room, Miss Garth went behind the scenes;\r\nostensibly anxious to see if she could be of any use; really bent on\r\nascertaining whether Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s head had been turned by the triumphs of\r\nthe evening. It would not have surprised Miss Garth if she had\r\ndiscovered her pupil in the act of making terms with the manager for\r\nher forthcoming appearance in a public theater. As events really turned\r\nout, she found Magdalen on the stage, receiving, with gracious smiles,\r\na card which the manager presented to her with a professional bow.\r\nNoticing Miss Garth\xe2\x80\x99s mute look of inquiry, the civil little man\r\nhastened to explain that the card was his own, and that he was merely\r\nasking the favor of Miss Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s recommendation at any future\r\nopportunity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is not the last time the young lady will be concerned in private\r\ntheatricals, I\xe2\x80\x99ll answer for it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the manager. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd if a\r\nsuperintendent is wanted on the next occasion, she has kindly promised\r\nto say a good word for me. I am always to be heard of, miss, at that\r\naddress.\xe2\x80\x9d Saying those words, he bowed again, and discreetly\r\ndisappeared.\r\n\r\nVague suspicions beset the mind of Miss Garth, and urged her to insist\r\non looking at the card. No more harmless morsel of pasteboard was ever\r\npassed from one hand to another. The card contained nothing but the\r\nmanager\xe2\x80\x99s name, and, under it, the name and address of a theatrical\r\nagent in London.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not worth the trouble of keeping,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Garth.\r\n\r\nMagdalen caught her hand before she could throw the card away\xe2\x80\x94possessed\r\nherself of it the next instant\xe2\x80\x94and put it in her pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promised to recommend him,\xe2\x80\x9d she said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand that\xe2\x80\x99s one reason for\r\nkeeping his card. If it does nothing else, it will remind me of the\r\nhappiest evening of my life\xe2\x80\x94and that\xe2\x80\x99s another. Come!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried,\r\nthrowing her arms round Miss Garth with a feverish gayety\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ccongratulate\r\nme on my success!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will congratulate you when you have got over it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Garth.\r\n\r\nIn half an hour more Magdalen had changed her dress; had joined the\r\nguests; and had soared into an atmosphere of congratulation high above\r\nthe reach of any controlling influence that Miss Garth could exercise.\r\nFrank, dilatory in all his proceedings, was the last of the dramatic\r\ncompany who left the precincts of the stage. He made no attempt to join\r\nMagdalen in the supper-room\xe2\x80\x94but he was ready in the hall with her cloak\r\nwhen the carriages were called and the party broke up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Frank!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking round at him as he put the cloak on her\r\nshoulders, \xe2\x80\x9cI am so sorry it\xe2\x80\x99s all over! Come to-morrow morning, and\r\nlet\xe2\x80\x99s talk about it by ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the shrubbery at ten?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Frank, in a whisper.\r\n\r\nShe drew up the hood of her cloak and nodded to him gayly. Miss Garth,\r\nstanding near, noticed the looks that passed between them, though the\r\ndisturbance made by the parting guests prevented her from hearing the\r\nwords. There was a soft, underlying tenderness in Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s assumed\r\ngayety of manner\xe2\x80\x94there was a sudden thoughtfulness in her face, a\r\nconfidential readiness in her hand, as she took Frank\xe2\x80\x99s arm and went\r\nout to the carriage. What did it mean? Had her passing interest in him\r\nas her stage-pupil treacherously sown the seeds of any deeper interest\r\nin him, as a man? Had the idle theatrical scheme, now that it was all\r\nover, graver results to answer for than a mischievous waste of time?\r\n\r\nThe lines on Miss Garth\xe2\x80\x99s face deepened and hardened: she stood lost\r\namong the fluttering crowd around her. Norah\xe2\x80\x99s warning words, addressed\r\nto Mrs. Vanstone in the garden, recurred to her memory\xe2\x80\x94and now, for the\r\nfirst time, the idea dawned on her that Norah had seen the consequences\r\nin their true light.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII.\r\n\r\nEarly the next morning Miss Garth and Norah met in the garden and spoke\r\ntogether privately. The only noticeable result of the interview, when\r\nthey presented themselves at the breakfast-table, appeared in the\r\nmarked silence which they both maintained on the topic of the\r\ntheatrical performance. Mrs. Vanstone was entirely indebted to her\r\nhusband and to her youngest daughter for all that she heard of the\r\nevening\xe2\x80\x99s entertainment. The governess and the elder daughter had\r\nevidently determined on letting the subject drop.\r\n\r\nAfter breakfast was over Magdalen proved to be missing, when the ladies\r\nassembled as usual in the morning-room. Her habits were so little\r\nregular that Mrs. Vanstone felt neither surprise nor uneasiness at her\r\nabsence. Miss Garth and Norah looked at one another significantly, and\r\nwaited in silence. Two hours passed\xe2\x80\x94and there were no signs of\r\nMagdalen. Norah rose, as the clock struck twelve, and quietly left the\r\nroom to look for her.\r\n\r\nShe was not upstairs dusting her jewelry and disarranging her dresses.\r\nShe was not in the conservatory, not in the flower-garden; not in the\r\nkitchen teasing the cook; not in the yard playing with the dogs. Had\r\nshe, by any chance, gone out with her father? Mr. Vanstone had\r\nannounced his intention, at the breakfast-table, of paying a morning\r\nvisit to his old ally, Mr. Clare, and of rousing the philosopher\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsarcastic indignation by an account of the dramatic performance. None\r\nof the other ladies at Combe-Raven ever ventured themselves inside the\r\ncottage. But Magdalen was reckless enough for anything\xe2\x80\x94and Magdalen\r\nmight have gone there. As the idea occurred to her, Norah entered the\r\nshrubbery.\r\n\r\nAt the second turning, where the path among the trees wound away out of\r\nsight of the house, she came suddenly face to face with Magdalen and\r\nFrank: they were sauntering toward her, arm in arm, their heads close\r\ntogether, their conversation apparently proceeding in whispers. They\r\nlooked suspiciously handsome and happy. At the sight of Norah both\r\nstarted, and both stopped. Frank confusedly raised his hat, and turned\r\nback in the direction of his father\xe2\x80\x99s cottage. Magdalen advanced to\r\nmeet her sister, carelessly swinging her closed parasol from side to\r\nside, carelessly humming an air from the overture which had preceded\r\nthe rising of the curtain on the previous night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLuncheon-time already!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking at her watch. \xe2\x80\x9cSurely not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you and Mr. Francis Clare been alone in the shrubbery since ten\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Norah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Mr._ Francis Clare! How ridiculously formal you are. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\ncall him Frank?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI asked you a question, Magdalen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear me, how black you look this morning! I\xe2\x80\x99m in disgrace, I suppose.\r\nHaven\xe2\x80\x99t you forgiven me yet for my acting last night? I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help\r\nit, love; I should have made nothing of Julia, if I hadn\xe2\x80\x99t taken you\r\nfor my model. It\xe2\x80\x99s quite a question of Art. In your place, I should\r\nhave felt flattered by the selection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn _your_ place, Magdalen, I should have thought twice before I\r\nmimicked my sister to an audience of strangers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s exactly why I did it\xe2\x80\x94an audience of strangers. How were they to\r\nknow? Come! come! don\xe2\x80\x99t be angry. You are eight years older than I\r\nam\xe2\x80\x94you ought to set me an example of good-humor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will set you an example of plain-speaking. I am more sorry than I\r\ncan say, Magdalen, to meet you as I met you here just now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat next, I wonder? You meet me in the shrubbery at home, talking\r\nover the private theatricals with my old playfellow, whom I knew when I\r\nwas no taller than this parasol. And that is a glaring impropriety, is\r\nit? \xe2\x80\x98Honi soit qui mal y pense.\xe2\x80\x99 You wanted an answer a minute\r\nago\xe2\x80\x94there it is for you, my dear, in the choicest Norman-French.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am in earnest about this, Magdalen\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a doubt of it. Nobody can accuse you of ever making jokes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am seriously sorry\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is quite useless to interrupt me. I have it on my conscience to\r\ntell you\xe2\x80\x94and I _will_ tell you\xe2\x80\x94that I am sorry to see how this intimacy\r\nis growing. I am sorry to see a secret understanding established\r\nalready between you and Mr. Francis Clare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Frank! How you do hate him, to be sure. What on earth has he done\r\nto offend you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNorah\xe2\x80\x99s self-control began to show signs of failing her. Her dark\r\ncheeks glowed, her delicate lips trembled, before she spoke again.\r\nMagdalen paid more attention to her parasol than to her sister. She\r\ntossed it high in the air and caught it. \xe2\x80\x9cOnce!\xe2\x80\x9d she said\xe2\x80\x94and tossed it\r\nup again. \xe2\x80\x9cTwice!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and she tossed it higher. \xe2\x80\x9cThrice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d Before she could\r\ncatch it for the third time, Norah seized her passionately by the arm,\r\nand the parasol dropped to the ground between them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are treating me heartlessly,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cFor shame, Magdalen\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nshame!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe irrepressible outburst of a reserved nature, forced into open\r\nself-assertion in its own despite, is of all moral forces the hardest\r\nto resist. Magdalen was startled into silence. For a moment, the two\r\nsisters\xe2\x80\x94so strangely dissimilar in person and character\xe2\x80\x94faced one\r\nanother, without a word passing between them. For a moment the deep\r\nbrown eyes of the elder and the light gray eyes of the younger looked\r\ninto each other with steady, unyielding scrutiny on either side.\r\nNorah\xe2\x80\x99s face was the first to change; Norah\xe2\x80\x99s head was the first to\r\nturn away. She dropped her sister\xe2\x80\x99s arm in silence. Magdalen stooped\r\nand picked up her parasol.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI try to keep my temper,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cand you call me heartless for\r\ndoing it. You always were hard on me, and you always will be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNorah clasped her trembling hands fast in each other. \xe2\x80\x9cHard on you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe said, in low, mournful tones\xe2\x80\x94and sighed bitterly.\r\n\r\nMagdalen drew back a little, and mechanically dusted the parasol with\r\nthe end of her garden cloak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d she resumed, doggedly. \xe2\x80\x9cHard on me and hard on Frank.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrank!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Norah, advancing on her sister and turning pale as\r\nsuddenly as she had turned red. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you talk of yourself and Frank as\r\nif your interests were One already? Magdalen! if I hurt _you_, do I\r\nhurt _him_? Is he so near and so dear to you as that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMagdalen drew further and further back. A twig from a tree near caught\r\nher cloak; she turned petulantly, broke it off, and threw it on the\r\nground. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat right have you to question me?\xe2\x80\x9d she broke out on a\r\nsudden. \xe2\x80\x9cWhether I like Frank, or whether I don\xe2\x80\x99t, what interest is it\r\nof yours?\xe2\x80\x9d As she said the words, she abruptly stepped forward to pass\r\nher sister and return to the house.\r\n\r\nNorah, turning paler and paler, barred the way to her. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I hold you\r\nby main force,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall stop and hear me. I have watched\r\nthis Francis Clare; I know him better than you do. He is unworthy of a\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x99s serious feeling on your part; he is unworthy of our dear,\r\ngood, kind-hearted father\xe2\x80\x99s interest in him. A man with any principle,\r\nany honor, any gratitude, would not have come back as he has come back,\r\ndisgraced\xe2\x80\x94yes! disgraced by his spiritless neglect of his own duty. I\r\nwatched his face while the friend who has been better than a father to\r\nhim was comforting and forgiving him with a kindness he had not\r\ndeserved: I watched his face, and I saw no shame and no distress in\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94I saw nothing but a look of thankless, heartless relief. He is\r\nselfish, he is ungrateful, he is ungenerous\xe2\x80\x94he is only twenty, and he\r\nhas the worst failings of a mean old age already. And this is the man I\r\nfind you meeting in secret\xe2\x80\x94the man who has taken such a place in your\r\nfavor that you are deaf to the truth about him, even from _my_ lips!\r\nMagdalen! this will end ill. For God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, think of what I have said\r\nto you, and control yourself before it is too late!\xe2\x80\x9d She stopped,\r\nvehement and breathless, and caught her sister anxiously by the hand.\r\n\r\nMagdalen looked at her in unconcealed astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are so violent,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cand so unlike yourself, that I hardly\r\nknow you. The more patient I am, the more hard words I get for my\r\npains. You have taken a perverse hatred to Frank; and you are\r\nunreasonably angry with me because I won\xe2\x80\x99t hate him, too. Don\xe2\x80\x99t, Norah!\r\nyou hurt my hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNorah pushed the hand from her contemptuously. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall never hurt your\r\nheart,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; and suddenly turned her back on Magdalen as she spoke\r\nthe words.\r\n\r\nThere was a momentary pause. Norah kept her position. Magdalen looked\r\nat her perplexedly\xe2\x80\x94hesitated\xe2\x80\x94then walked away by herself toward the\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\nAt the turn in the shrubbery path she stopped and looked back uneasily.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, dear, dear!\xe2\x80\x9d she thought to herself, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t Frank go when I\r\ntold him?\xe2\x80\x9d She hesitated, and went back a few steps. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s Norah\r\nstanding on her dignity, as obstinate as ever.\xe2\x80\x9d She stopped again.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat had I better do? I hate quarreling: I think I\xe2\x80\x99ll make up.\xe2\x80\x9d She\r\nventured close to her sister and touched her on the shoulder. Norah\r\nnever moved. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not often she flies into a passion,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\r\nMagdalen, touching her again; \xe2\x80\x9cbut when she does, what a time it lasts\r\nher!\xe2\x80\x94Come!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cgive me a kiss, Norah, and make it up. Won\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nlet me get at any part of you, my dear, but the back of your neck?\r\nWell, it\xe2\x80\x99s a very nice neck\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s better worth kissing than mine\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nthere the kiss is, in spite of you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe caught fast hold of Norah from behind, and suited the action to the\r\nword, with a total disregard of all that had just passed, which her\r\nsister was far from emulating. Hardly a minute since the warm\r\noutpouring of Norah\xe2\x80\x99s heart had burst through all obstacles. Had the\r\nicy reserve frozen her up again already! It was hard to say. She never\r\nspoke; she never changed her position\xe2\x80\x94she only searched hurriedly for\r\nher handkerchief. As she drew it out, there was a sound of approaching\r\nfootsteps in the inner recesses of the shrubbery. A Scotch terrier\r\nscampered into view; and a cheerful voice sang the first lines of the\r\nglee in \xe2\x80\x9cAs You Like It.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s papa!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Magdalen. \xe2\x80\x9cCome,\r\nNorah\xe2\x80\x94come and meet him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nInstead of following her sister, Norah pulled down the veil of her\r\ngarden hat, turned in the opposite direction, and hurried back to the\r\nhouse. She ran up to her own room and locked herself in. She was crying\r\nbitterly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII.\r\n\r\nWhen Magdalen and her father met in the shrubbery Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s face\r\nshowed plainly that something had happened to please him since he had\r\nleft home in the morning. He answered the question which his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncuriosity at once addressed to him by informing her that he had just\r\ncome from Mr. Clare\xe2\x80\x99s cottage; and that he had picked up, in that\r\nunpromising locality, a startling piece of news for the family at\r\nCombe-Raven.\r\n\r\nOn entering the philosopher\xe2\x80\x99s study that morning, Mr. Vanstone had\r\nfound him still dawdling over his late breakfast, with an open letter\r\nby his side, in place of the book which, on other occasions, lay ready\r\nto his hand at meal-times. He held up the letter the moment his visitor\r\ncame into the room, and abruptly opened the conversation by asking Mr.\r\nVanstone if his nerves were in good order, and if he felt himself\r\nstrong enough for the shock of an overwhelming surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNerves!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mr. Vanstone. \xe2\x80\x9cThank God, I know nothing about my\r\nnerves.
