At another point, a wooden tower of observation,\r\ncrowned by the figure-head of a wrecked Russian vessel, rises high\r\nabove the neighboring houses, and discloses through its scuttle-window\r\ngrave men in dark clothing seated on the topmost story, perpetually on\r\nthe watch\xe2\x80\x94the pilots of Aldborough looking out from their tower for\r\nships in want of help. Behind the row of buildings thus curiously\r\nintermingled runs the one straggling street of the town, with its\r\nsturdy pilots\xe2\x80\x99 cottages, its mouldering marine store-houses, and its\r\ncomposite shops. Toward the northern end this street is bounded by the\r\none eminence visible over all the marshy flat\xe2\x80\x94a low wooded hill, on\r\nwhich the church is built. At its opposite extremity the street leads\r\nto a deserted martello tower, and to the forlorn outlying suburb of\r\nSlaughden, between the river Alde and the sea. Such are the main\r\ncharacteristics of this curious little outpost on the shores of England\r\nas it appears at the present time.\r\n\r\nOn a hot and cloudy July afternoon, and on the second day which had\r\nelapsed since he had written to Magdalen, Captain Wragge sauntered\r\nthrough the gate of North Shingles Villa to meet the arrival of the\r\ncoach, which then connected Aldborough with the Eastern Counties\r\nRailway. He reached the principal inn as the coach drove up, and was\r\nready at the door to receive Magdalen and Mrs. Wragge, on their leaving\r\nthe vehicle.\r\n\r\nThe captain\xe2\x80\x99s reception of his wife was not characterized by an\r\ninstant\xe2\x80\x99s unnecessary waste of time. He looked distrustfully at her\r\nshoes\xe2\x80\x94raised himself on tiptoe\xe2\x80\x94set her bonnet straight for her with a\r\nsharp tug\xe2\x80\x94-said, in a loud whisper, \xe2\x80\x9chold your tongue\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and left her,\r\nfor the time being, without further notice. His welcome to Magdalen,\r\nbeginning with the usual flow of words, stopped suddenly in the middle\r\nof the first sentence. Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s eye was a sharp one, and it\r\ninstantly showed him something in the look and manner of his old pupil\r\nwhich denoted a serious change.\r\n\r\nThere was a settled composure on her face which, except when she spoke,\r\nmade it look as still and cold as marble. Her voice was softer and more\r\nequable, her eyes were steadier, her step was slower than of old. When\r\nshe smiled, the smile came and went suddenly, and showed a little\r\nnervous contraction on one side of her mouth never visible there\r\nbefore. She was perfectly patient with Mrs. Wragge; she treated the\r\ncaptain with a courtesy and consideration entirely new in his\r\nexperience of her\xe2\x80\x94but she was interested in nothing. The curious little\r\nshops in the back street; the high impending sea; the old town-hall on\r\nthe beach; the pilots, the fishermen, the passing ships\xe2\x80\x94she noticed all\r\nthese objects as indifferently as if Aldborough had been familiar to\r\nher from her infancy. Even when the captain drew up at the garden-gate\r\nof North Shingles, and introduced her triumphantly to the new house,\r\nshe hardly looked at it. The first question she asked related not to\r\nher own residence, but to Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow near to us does he live?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired, with the only betrayal of\r\nemotion which had escaped her yet.\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge answered by pointing to the fifth villa from North\r\nShingles, on the Slaughden side of Aldborough. Magdalen suddenly drew\r\nback from the garden-gate as he indicated the situation, and walked\r\naway by herself to obtain a nearer view of the house. Captain Wragge\r\nlooked after her, and shook his head, discontentedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I speak now?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired a meek voice behind him, articulating\r\nrespectfully ten inches above the top of his straw hat.\r\n\r\nThe captain turned round, and confronted his wife. The more than\r\nordinary bewilderment visible in her face at once suggested to him that\r\nMagdalen had failed to carry out the directions in his letter; and that\r\nMrs. Wragge had arrived at Aldborough without being properly aware of\r\nthe total transformation to be accomplished in her identity and her\r\nname. The necessity of setting this doubt at rest was too serious to be\r\ntrifled with; and Captain Wragge instituted the necessary inquiries\r\nwithout a moment\xe2\x80\x99s delay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand straight, and listen to me,\xe2\x80\x9d he began. \xe2\x80\x9cI have a question to ask\r\nyou. Do you know whose Skin you are in at this moment? Do you know that\r\nyou are dead and buried in London; and that you have risen like a\r\nphoenix from the ashes of Mrs. Wragge? No! you evidently don\xe2\x80\x99t know it.\r\nThis is perfectly disgraceful. What is your name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMatilda,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mrs. Wragge, in a state of the densest\r\nbewilderment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing of the sort!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the captain, fiercely. \xe2\x80\x9cHow dare you tell\r\nme your name\xe2\x80\x99s Matilda? Your name is Julia. Who am I?\xe2\x80\x94Hold that basket\r\nof sandwiches straight, or I\xe2\x80\x99ll pitch it into the sea!\xe2\x80\x94Who am I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Wragge, meekly taking refuge in the negative\r\nside of the question this time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit down!\xe2\x80\x9d said her husband, pointing to the low garden wall of North\r\nShingles Villa. \xe2\x80\x9cMore to the right! More still! That will do. You don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nknow?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the captain, sternly confronting his wife as soon as he\r\nhad contrived, by seating her, to place her face on a level with his\r\nown. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t let me hear you say that a second time. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let me have a\r\nwoman who doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know who I am to operate on my beard to-morrow\r\nmorning. Look at me! More to the left\xe2\x80\x94more still\xe2\x80\x94that will do. Who am\r\nI? I\xe2\x80\x99m Mr. Bygrave\xe2\x80\x94Christian name, Thomas. Who are you? You\xe2\x80\x99re Mrs.\r\nBygrave\xe2\x80\x94Christian name, Julia. Who is that young lady who traveled with\r\nyou from London? That young lady is Miss Bygrave\xe2\x80\x94Christian name, Susan.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m her clever uncle Tom; and you\xe2\x80\x99re her addle-headed aunt Julia. Say\r\nit all over to me instantly, like the Catechism! What is your name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpare my poor head!\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded Mrs. Wragge. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, please spare my poor\r\nhead till I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the stage-coach out of it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t distress her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen, joining them at that moment. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\r\nwill learn it in time. Come into the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge shook his wary head once more. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are beginning badly,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, with less politeness than usual. \xe2\x80\x9cMy wife\xe2\x80\x99s stupidity stands\r\nin our way already.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey went into the house. Magdalen was perfectly satisfied with all the\r\ncaptain\xe2\x80\x99s arrangements; she accepted the room which he had set apart\r\nfor her; approved of the woman servant whom he had engaged; presented\r\nherself at tea-time the moment she was summoned but still showed no\r\ninterest whatever in the new scene around her. Soon after the table was\r\ncleared, although the daylight had not yet faded out, Mrs. Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncustomary drowsiness after fatigue of any kind overcame her, and she\r\nreceived her husband\xe2\x80\x99s orders to leave the room (taking care that she\r\nleft it \xe2\x80\x9cup at heel\xe2\x80\x9d), and to betake herself (strictly in the character\r\nof Mrs. Bygrave) to bed. As soon as they were left alone, the captain\r\nlooked hard at Magdalen, and waited to be spoken to. She said nothing.\r\nHe ventured next on opening the conversation by a polite inquiry after\r\nthe state of her health. \xe2\x80\x9cYou look fatigued,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked, in his most\r\ninsinuating manner. \xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid the journey has been too much for\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking out listlessly through the window; \xe2\x80\x9cI am not\r\nmore tired than usual. I am always weary now; weary at going to bed,\r\nweary at getting up. If you would like to hear what I have to say to\r\nyou to-night, I am willing and ready to say it. Can\xe2\x80\x99t we go out? It is\r\nvery hot here; and the droning of those men\xe2\x80\x99s voices is beyond all\r\nendurance.\xe2\x80\x9d She pointed through the window to a group of boatmen\r\nidling, as only nautical men can idle, against the garden wall. \xe2\x80\x9cIs\r\nthere no quiet walk in this wretched place?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, impatiently.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t we breathe a little fresh air, and escape being annoyed by\r\nstrangers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is perfect solitude within half an hour\xe2\x80\x99s walk of the house,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied the ready captain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well. Come out, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith a weary sigh she took up her straw bonnet and her light muslin\r\nscarf from the side-table upon which she had thrown them on coming in,\r\nand carelessly led the way to the door. Captain Wragge followed her to\r\nthe garden gate, then stopped, struck by a new idea.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered, confidentially. \xe2\x80\x9cIn my wife\xe2\x80\x99s existing state\r\nof ignorance as to who she is, we had better not trust her alone in the\r\nhouse with a new servant. I\xe2\x80\x99ll privately turn the key on her, in case\r\nshe wakes before we come back. Safe bind, safe find\xe2\x80\x94you know the\r\nproverb!\xe2\x80\x94I will be with you again in a moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe hastened back to the house, and Magdalen seated herself on the\r\ngarden wall to await his return.\r\n\r\nShe had hardly settled herself in that position when two gentlemen\r\nwalking together, whose approach along the public path she had not\r\npreviously noticed, passed close by her.\r\n\r\nThe dress of one of the two strangers showed him to be a clergyman. His\r\ncompanion\xe2\x80\x99s station in life was less easily discernible to ordinary\r\nobservation. Practiced eyes would probably have seen enough in his\r\nlook, his manner, and his walk to show that he was a sailor. He was a\r\nman in the prime of life; tall, spare, and muscular; his face\r\nsun-burned to a deep brown; his black hair just turning gray; his eyes\r\ndark, deep and firm\xe2\x80\x94the eyes of a man with an iron resolution and a\r\nhabit of command. He was the nearest of the two to Magdalen, as he and\r\nhis friend passed the place where she was sitting; and he looked at her\r\nwith a sudden surprise at her beauty, with an open, hearty, undisguised\r\nadmiration, which was too evidently sincere, too evidently beyond his\r\nown control, to be justly resented as insolent; and yet, in her humor\r\nat that moment, Magdalen did resent it. She felt the man\xe2\x80\x99s resolute\r\nblack eyes strike through her with an electric suddenness; and frowning\r\nat him impatiently, she turned away her head and looked back at the\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\nThe next moment she glanced round again to see if he had gone on. He\r\nhad advanced a few yards\xe2\x80\x94had then evidently stopped\xe2\x80\x94and was now in the\r\nvery act of turning to look at her once more. His companion, the\r\nclergyman, noticing that Magdalen appeared to be annoyed, took him\r\nfamiliarly by the arm, and, half in jest, half in earnest, forced him\r\nto walk on. The two disappeared round the corner of the next house. As\r\nthey turned it, the sun-burned sailor twice stopped his companion\r\nagain, and twice looked back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA friend of yours?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Captain Wragge, joining Magdalen at that\r\nmoment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied; \xe2\x80\x9ca perfect stranger. He stared at me in\r\nthe most impertinent manner. Does he belong to this place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll find out in a moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said the compliant captain, joining the\r\ngroup of boatmen, and putting his questions right and left, with the\r\neasy familiarity which distinguished him. He returned in a few minutes\r\nwith a complete budget of information. The clergyman was well known as\r\nthe rector of a place situated some few miles inland. The dark man with\r\nhim was his wife\xe2\x80\x99s brother, commander of a ship in the\r\nmerchant-service. He was supposed to be staying with his relatives, as\r\ntheir guest for a short time only, preparatory to sailing on another\r\nvoyage. The clergyman\xe2\x80\x99s name was Strickland, and the merchant-captain\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nname was Kirke; and that was all the boatmen knew about either of them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is of no consequence who they are,\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen, carelessly. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s rudeness merely annoyed me for the moment. Let us have done with\r\nhim. I have something else to think of, and so have you. Where is the\r\nsolitary walk you mentioned just now? Which way do we go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain pointed southward toward Slaughden, and offered his arm.\r\n\r\nMagdalen hesitated before she took it. Her eyes wandered away\r\ninquiringly to Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s house. He was out in the garden, pacing\r\nbackward and forward over the little lawn, with his head high in the\r\nair, and with Mrs. Lecount demurely in attendance on him, carrying her\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s green fan. Seeing this, Magdalen at once took Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nright arm, so as to place herself nearest to the garden when they\r\npassed it on their walk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe eyes of our neighbors are on us; and the least your niece can do\r\nis to take your arm,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a bitter laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cCome! let us go\r\non.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are looking this way,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cShall I introduce\r\nyou to Mrs. Lecount?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered. \xe2\x80\x9cWait, and hear what I have to say to you\r\nfirst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey passed the garden wall. Captain Wragge took off his hat with a\r\nsmart flourish, and received a gracious bow from Mrs. Lecount in\r\nreturn. Magdalen saw the housekeeper survey her face, her figure, and\r\nher dress, with that reluctant interest, that distrustful curiosity,\r\nwhich women feel in observing each other. As she walked on beyond the\r\nhouse, the sharp voice of Noel Vanstone reached her through the evening\r\nstillness. \xe2\x80\x9cA fine girl, Lecount,\xe2\x80\x9d she heard him say. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know I am a\r\njudge of that sort of thing\xe2\x80\x94a fine girl!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs those words were spoken, Captain Wragge looked round at his\r\ncompanion in sudden surprise. Her hand was trembling violently on his\r\narm, and her lips were fast closed with an expression of speechless\r\npain.\r\n\r\nSlowly and in silence the two walked on until they reached the southern\r\nlimit of the houses, and entered on a little wilderness of shingle and\r\nwithered grass\xe2\x80\x94the desolate end of Aldborough, the lonely beginning of\r\nSlaughden.\r\n\r\nIt was a dull, airless evening. Eastward, was the gray majesty of the\r\nsea, hushed in breathless calm; the horizon line invisibly melting into\r\nthe monotonous, misty sky; the idle ships shadowy and still on the idle\r\nwater. Southward, the high ridge of the sea dike, and the grim, massive\r\ncircle of a martello tower reared high on its mound of grass, closed\r\nthe view darkly on all that lay beyond. Westward, a lurid streak of\r\nsunset glowed red in the dreary heaven, blackened the fringing trees on\r\nthe far borders of the great inland marsh, and turned its little\r\ngleaming water-pools to pools of blood. Nearer to the eye, the sullen\r\nflow of the tidal river Alde ebbed noiselessly from the muddy banks;\r\nand nearer still, lonely and unprosperous by the bleak water-side, lay\r\nthe lost little port of Slaughden, with its forlorn wharfs and\r\nwarehouses of decaying wood, and its few scattered coasting-vessels\r\ndeserted on the oozy river-shore. No fall of waves was heard on the\r\nbeach, no trickling of waters bubbled audibly from the idle stream. Now\r\nand then the cry of a sea-bird rose from the region of the marsh; and\r\nat intervals, from farmhouses far in the inland waste, the faint\r\nwinding of horns to call the cattle home traveled mournfully through\r\nthe evening calm.\r\n\r\nMagdalen drew her hand from the captain\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and led the way to the\r\nmound of the martello tower. \xe2\x80\x9cI am weary of walking,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us\r\nstop and rest here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe seated herself on the slope, and resting on her elbow, mechanically\r\npulled up and scattered from her into the air the tufts of grass\r\ngrowing under her hand. After silently occupying herself in this way\r\nfor some minutes, she turned suddenly on Captain Wragge. \xe2\x80\x9cDo I surprise\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, with a startling abruptness. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you find me changed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain\xe2\x80\x99s ready tact warned him that the time had come to be plain\r\nwith her, and to reserve his flowers of speech for a more appropriate\r\noccasion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you ask the question, I must answer it,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I do\r\nfind you changed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe pulled up another tuft of grass. \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you can guess the\r\nreason?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nThe captain was wisely silent. He only answered by a bow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have lost all care for myself,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, tearing faster and\r\nfaster at the tufts of grass. \xe2\x80\x9cSaying that is not saying much, perhaps,\r\nbut it may help you to understand me. There are things I would have\r\ndied sooner than do at one time\xe2\x80\x94things it would have turned me cold to\r\nthink of. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care now whether I do them or not. I am nothing to\r\nmyself; I am no more interested in myself than I am in these handfuls\r\nof grass. I suppose I have lost something. What is it? Heart?\r\nConscience? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. Do you? What nonsense I am talking! Who cares\r\nwhat I have lost? It has gone; and there\xe2\x80\x99s an end of it. I suppose my\r\noutside is the best side of me\xe2\x80\x94and that\xe2\x80\x99s left, at any rate. I have not\r\nlost my good looks, have I? There! there! never mind answering; don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ntrouble yourself to pay me compliments. I have been admired enough\r\nto-day. First the sailor, and then Mr. Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x94enough for any\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s vanity, surely! Have I any right to call myself a woman?\r\nPerhaps not: I am only a girl in my teens. Oh, me, I feel as if I was\r\nforty!\xe2\x80\x9d She scattered the last fragments of grass to the winds; and\r\nturning her back on the captain, let her head droop till her cheek\r\ntouched the turf bank. \xe2\x80\x9cIt feels soft and friendly,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, nestling\r\nto it with a hopeless tenderness horrible to see. \xe2\x80\x9cIt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t cast me\r\noff. Mother Earth! The only mother I have left!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge looked at her in silent surprise. Such experience of\r\nhumanity as he possessed was powerless to sound to its depths the\r\nterrible self-abandonment which had burst its way to the surface in her\r\nreckless words\xe2\x80\x94which was now fast hurrying her to actions more reckless\r\nstill. \xe2\x80\x9cDevilish odd!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought to himself, uneasily. \xe2\x80\x9cHas the loss\r\nof her lover turned her brain?\xe2\x80\x9d He considered for a minute longer and\r\nthen spoke to her. \xe2\x80\x9cLeave it till to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d suggested the captain\r\nconfidentially. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are a little tired to-night. No hurry, my dear\r\ngirl\xe2\x80\x94no hurry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe raised her head instantly, and looked round at him with the same\r\nangry resolution, with the same desperate defiance of herself, which he\r\nhad seen in her face on the memorable day at York when she had acted\r\nbefore him for the first time. \xe2\x80\x9cI came here to tell you what is in my\r\nmind,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cand I _will_ tell it!\xe2\x80\x9d She seated herself upright on\r\nthe slope; and clasping her hands round her knees, looked out steadily,\r\nstraight before her, at the slowly darkening view. In that strange\r\nposition, she waited until she had composed herself, and then addressed\r\nthe captain, without turning her head to look round at him, in these\r\nwords:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you and I first met,\xe2\x80\x9d she began, abruptly, \xe2\x80\x9cI tried hard to keep\r\nmy thoughts to myself. I know enough by this time to know that I\r\nfailed. When I first told you at York that Michael Vanstone had ruined\r\nus, I believe you guessed for yourself that I, for one, was determined\r\nnot to submit to it. Whether you guessed or not, it is so. I left my\r\nfriends with that determination in my mind; and I feel it in me now\r\nstronger, ten times stronger, than ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTen times stronger than ever,\xe2\x80\x9d echoed the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cExactly so\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nnatural result of firmness of character.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94the natural result of having nothing else to think of. I had\r\nsomething else to think of before you found me ill in Vauxhall Walk. I\r\nhave nothing else to think of now. Remember that, if you find me for\r\nthe future always harping on the same string. One question first. Did\r\nyou guess what I meant to do on that morning when you showed me the\r\nnewspaper, and when I read the account of Michael Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s death?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGenerally,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI guessed, generally, that you\r\nproposed dipping your hand into his purse and taking from it (most\r\nproperly) what was your own. I felt deeply hurt at the time by your not\r\npermitting me to assist you. Why is she so reserved with me? (I\r\nremarked to myself)\xe2\x80\x94why is she so unreasonably reserved?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall have no reserve to complain of now,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Magdalen. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ntell you plainly, if events had not happened as they did, you _would_\r\nhave assisted me. If Michael Vanstone had not died, I should have gone\r\nto Brighton, and have found my way safely to his acquaintance under an\r\nassumed name. I had money enough with me to live on respectably for\r\nmany months together. I would have employed that time\xe2\x80\x94I would have\r\nwaited a whole year, if necessary, to destroy Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s influence\r\nover him\xe2\x80\x94and I would have ended by getting that influence, on my own\r\nterms, into my own hands. I had the advantage of years, the advantage\r\nof novelty, the advantage of downright desperation, all on my side, and\r\nI should have succeeded. Before the year was out\xe2\x80\x94before half the year\r\nwas out\xe2\x80\x94you should have seen Mrs. Lecount dismissed by her master, and\r\nyou should have seen me taken into the house in her place, as Michael\r\nVanstone\xe2\x80\x99s adopted daughter\xe2\x80\x94as the faithful friend\xe2\x80\x94who had saved him\r\nfrom an adventuress in his old age. Girls no older than I am have tried\r\ndeceptions as hopeless in appearance as mine, and have carried them\r\nthrough to the end. I had my story ready; I had my plans all\r\nconsidered; I had the weak point in that old man to attack in my way,\r\nwhich Mrs. Lecount had found out before me to attack in hers, and I\r\ntell you again I should have succeeded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think you would,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Michael Vanstone would have changed his man of business next. You\r\nwould have succeeded to the place; and those clever speculations on\r\nwhich he was so fond of venturing would have cost him the fortunes of\r\nwhich he had robbed my sister and myself. To the last farthing, Captain\r\nWragge, as certainly as you sit there, to the last farthing! A bold\r\nconspiracy, a shocking deception\xe2\x80\x94wasn\xe2\x80\x99t it? I don\xe2\x80\x99t care! Any\r\nconspiracy, any deception, is justified to my conscience by the vile\r\nlaw which has left us helpless. You talked of my reserve just now. Have\r\nI dropped it at last? Have I spoken out at the eleventh hour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain laid his hand solemnly on his heart, and launched himself\r\nonce more on his broadest flow of language.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou fill me with unavailing regret,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf that old man had\r\nlived, what a crop I might have reaped from him! What enormous\r\ntransactions in moral agriculture it might have been my privilege to\r\ncarry on! _Ars longa,_\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Wragge, pathetically drifting into\r\nLatin\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c_vita brevis!_ Let us drop a tear on the lost opportunities of\r\nthe past, and try what the present can do to console us. One conclusion\r\nis clear to my mind\xe2\x80\x94the experiment you proposed to try with Mr. Michael\r\nVanstone is totally hopeless, my dear girl, in the case of his son. His\r\nson is impervious to all common forms of pecuniary temptation. You may\r\ntrust my solemn assurance,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the captain, speaking with an\r\nindignant recollection of the answer to his advertisement in the Times,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhen I inform you that Mr. Noel Vanstone is emphatically the meanest\r\nof mankind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can trust my own experience as well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen. \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen\r\nhim, and spoken to him\xe2\x80\x94I know him better than you do. Another\r\ndisclosure, Captain Wragge, for your private ear! I sent you back\r\ncertain articles of costume when they had served the purpose for which\r\nI took them to London. That purpose was to find my way to Noel Vanstone\r\nin disguise, and to judge for myself of Mrs. Lecount and her master. I\r\ngained my object; and I tell you again, I know the two people in that\r\nhouse yonder whom we have now to deal with better than you do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge expressed the profound astonishment, and asked the\r\ninnocent questions appropriate to the mental condition of a person\r\ntaken completely by surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he resumed, when Magdalen had briefly answered him, \xe2\x80\x9cand what\r\nis the result on your own mind? There must be a result, or we should\r\nnot be here. You see your way? Of course, my dear girl, you see your\r\nway?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, quickly. \xe2\x80\x9cI see my way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain drew a little nearer to her, with eager curiosity expressed\r\nin every line of his vagabond face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, in an anxious whisper; \xe2\x80\x9cpray go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked out thoughtfully into the gathering darkness, without\r\nanswering, without appearing to have heard him. Her lips closed, and\r\nher clasped hands tightened mechanically round her knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no disguising the fact,\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Wragge, warily rousing\r\nher into speaking to him. \xe2\x80\x9cThe son is harder to deal with than the\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot in my way,\xe2\x80\x9d she interposed, suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cWell! they say there is a short cut to\r\neverything, if we only look long enough to find it. You have looked\r\nlong enough, I suppose, and the natural result has followed\xe2\x80\x94you have\r\nfound it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not troubled myself to look; I have found it without looking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe deuce you have!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Captain Wragge, in great perplexity. \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\ndear girl, is my view of your present position leading me altogether\r\nastray? As I understand it, here is Mr. Noel Vanstone in possession of\r\nyour fortune and your sister\xe2\x80\x99s, as his father was, and determined to\r\nkeep it, as his father was?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd here are you\xe2\x80\x94quite helpless to get it by persuasion\xe2\x80\x94quite helpless\r\nto get it by law\xe2\x80\x94just as resolute in his case as you were in his\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s, to take it by stratagem in spite of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust as resolute. Not for the sake of the fortune\xe2\x80\x94mind that! For the\r\nsake of the right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so. And the means of coming at that right which were hard with\r\nthe father\xe2\x80\x94who was not a miser\xe2\x80\x94are easy with the son, who is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly easy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWrite me down an Ass for the first time in my life!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the\r\ncaptain, at the end of his patience. \xe2\x80\x9cHang me if I know what you mean!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked round at him for the first time\xe2\x80\x94looked him straight and\r\nsteadily in the face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you what I mean,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI mean to marry him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge started up on his knees, and stopped on them, petrified\r\nby astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember what I told you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen, looking away from him again.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have lost all care for myself. I have only one end in life now, and\r\nthe sooner I reach it\xe2\x80\x94and die\xe2\x80\x94the better. If\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d She stopped, altered her\r\nposition a little, and pointed with one hand to the fast-ebbing stream\r\nbeneath her, gleaming dim in the darkening twilight\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cif I had been what\r\nI once was, I would have thrown myself into that river sooner than do\r\nwhat I am going to do now. As it is, I trouble myself no longer; I\r\nweary my mind with no more schemes. The short way and the vile way lies\r\nbefore me. I take it, Captain Wragge, and marry him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeeping him in total ignorance of who you are?\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain,\r\nslowly rising to his feet, and slowly moving round, so as to see her\r\nface. \xe2\x80\x9cMarrying him as my niece, Miss Bygrave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs your niece, Miss Bygrave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd after the marriage\xe2\x80\x94?\xe2\x80\x9d His voice faltered, as he began the\r\nquestion, and he left it unfinished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter the marriage,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall stand in no further need of\r\nyour assistance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain stooped as she gave him that answer, looked close at her,\r\nand suddenly drew back, without uttering a word. He walked away some\r\npaces, and sat down again doggedly on the grass. If Magdalen could have\r\nseen his face in the dying light, his face would have startled her. For\r\nthe first time, probably, since his boyhood, Captain Wragge had changed\r\ncolor. He was deadly pale.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you nothing to say to me?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you are waiting to\r\nhear what terms I have to offer? These are my terms; I pay all our\r\nexpenses here; and when we part, on the day of the marriage, you take a\r\nfarewell gift away with you of two hundred pounds. Do you promise me\r\nyour assistance on those conditions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I expected to do?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, with a furtive glance at her, and\r\na sudden distrust in his voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are expected to preserve my assumed character and your own,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nanswered, \xe2\x80\x9cand you are to prevent any inquiries of Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s from\r\ndiscovering who I really am. I ask no more. The rest is my\r\nresponsibility\xe2\x80\x94not yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have nothing to do with what happens\xe2\x80\x94at any time, or in any\r\nplace\xe2\x80\x94after the marriage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing whatever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI may leave you at the church door if I please?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the church door, with your fee in your pocket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPaid from the money in your own possession?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly! How else should I pay it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge took off his hat, and passed his handkerchief over his\r\nface with an air of relief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me a minute to consider it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs many minutes as you like,\xe2\x80\x9d she rejoined, reclining on the bank in\r\nher former position, and returning to her former occupation of tearing\r\nup the tufts of grass and flinging them out into the air.\r\n\r\nThe captain\xe2\x80\x99s reflections were not complicated by any unnecessary\r\ndivergences from the contemplation of his own position to the\r\ncontemplation of Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s. Utterly incapable of appreciating the\r\ninjury done her by Frank\xe2\x80\x99s infamous treachery to his engagement\xe2\x80\x94an\r\ninjury which had severed her, at one cruel blow, from the aspiration\r\nwhich, delusion though it was, had been the saving aspiration of her\r\nlife\xe2\x80\x94Captain Wragge accepted the simple fact of her despair just as he\r\nfound it, and then looked straight to the consequences of the proposal\r\nwhich she had made to him.\r\n\r\nIn the prospect _before_ the marriage he saw nothing more serious\r\ninvolved than the practice of a deception, in no important degree\r\ndifferent\xe2\x80\x94except in the end to be attained by it\xe2\x80\x94from the deceptions\r\nwhich his vagabond life had long since accustomed him to contemplate\r\nand to carry out. In the prospect _after_ the marriage he dimly\r\ndiscerned, through the ominous darkness of the future, the lurking\r\nphantoms of Terror and Crime, and the black gulfs behind them of Ruin\r\nand Death. A man of boundless audacity and resource, within his own\r\nmean limits; beyond those limits, the captain was as deferentially\r\nsubmissive to the majesty of the law as the most harmless man in\r\nexistence; as cautious in looking after his own personal safety as the\r\nveriest coward that ever walked the earth. But one serious question now\r\nfilled his mind. Could he, on the terms proposed to him, join the\r\nconspiracy against Noel Vanstone up to the point of the marriage, and\r\nthen withdraw from it, without risk of involving himself in the\r\nconsequences which his experience told him must certainly ensue?\r\n\r\nStrange as it may seem, his decision in this emergency was mainly\r\ninfluenced by no less a person than Noel Vanstone himself. The captain\r\nmight have resisted the money-offer which Magdalen had made to him\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nthe profits of the Entertainment had filled his pockets with more than\r\nthree times two hundred pounds. But the prospect of dealing a blow in\r\nthe dark at the man who had estimated his information and himself at\r\nthe value of a five pound note proved too much for his caution and his\r\nself-control. On the small neutral ground of self-importance, the best\r\nmen and the worst meet on the same terms. Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s indignation,\r\nwhen he saw the answer to his advertisement, stooped to no\r\nretrospective estimate of his own conduct; he was as deeply offended,\r\nas sincerely angry as if he had made a perfectly honorable proposal,\r\nand had been rewarded for it by a personal insult. He had been too full\r\nof his own grievance to keep it out of his first letter to Magdalen. He\r\nhad more or less forgotten himself on every subsequent occasion when\r\nNoel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s name was mentioned. And in now finally deciding the\r\ncourse he should take, it is not too much to say that the motive of\r\nmoney receded, for the first time in his life, into the second place,\r\nand the motive of malice carried the day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI accept the terms,\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Wragge, getting briskly on his legs\r\nagain. \xe2\x80\x9cSubject, of course, to the conditions agreed on between us. We\r\npart on the wedding-day. I don\xe2\x80\x99t ask where you go: you don\xe2\x80\x99t ask where\r\nI go. From that time forth we are strangers to each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMagdalen rose slowly from the mound. A hopeless depression, a sullen\r\ndespair, showed itself in her look and manner. She refused the\r\ncaptain\xe2\x80\x99s offered hand; and her tones, when she answered him, were so\r\nlow that he could hardly hear her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe understand each other,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cand we can now go back. You may\r\nintroduce me to Mrs. Lecount to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must ask a few questions first,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, gravely. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\r\nare more risks to be run in this matter, and more pitfalls in our way,\r\nthan you seem to suppose. I must know the whole history of your morning\r\ncall on Mrs. Lecount before I put you and that woman on speaking terms\r\nwith each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait till to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d she broke out impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t madden me by\r\ntalking about it to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain said no more. They turned their faces toward Aldborough,\r\nand walked slowly back.\r\n\r\nBy the time they reached the houses night had overtaken them. Neither\r\nmoon nor stars were visible. A faint noiseless breeze blowing from the\r\nland had come with the darkness. Magdalen paused on the lonely public\r\nwalk to breathe the air more freely. After a while she turned her face\r\nfrom the breeze and looked out toward the sea. The immeasurable silence\r\nof the calm waters, lost in the black void of night, was awful. She\r\nstood looking into the darkness, as if its mystery had no secrets for\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94she advanced toward it slowly, as if it drew her by some hidden\r\nattraction into itself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going down to the sea,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to her companion. \xe2\x80\x9cWait here,\r\nand I will come back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe lost sight of her in an instant; it was as if the night had\r\nswallowed her up. He listened, and counted her footsteps by the\r\ncrashing of them on the shingle in the deep stillness. They retreated\r\nslowly, further and further away into the night. Suddenly the sound of\r\nthem ceased. Had she paused on her course or had she reached one of the\r\nstrips of sand left bare by the ebbing tide?\r\n\r\nHe waited, and listened anxiously. The time passed, and no sound\r\nreached him. He still listened, with a growing distrust of the\r\ndarkness. Another moment, and there came a sound from the invisible\r\nshore. Far and faint from the beach below, a long cry moaned through\r\nthe silence. Then all was still once more.\r\n\r\nIn sudden alarm, he stepped forward to descend to the beach, and to\r\ncall to her. Before he could cross the path, footsteps rapidly\r\nadvancing caught his ear. He waited an instant, and the figure of a man\r\npassed quickly along the walk between him and the sea. It was too dark\r\nto discern anything of the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s face; it was only possible to see\r\nthat he was a tall man\xe2\x80\x94as tall as that officer in the merchant-service\r\nwhose name was Kirke.\r\n\r\nThe figure passed on northward, and was instantly lost to view. Captain\r\nWragge crossed the path, and, advancing a few steps down the beach,\r\nstopped and listened again. The crash of footsteps on the shingle\r\ncaught his ear once more. Slowly, as the sound had left him, that sound\r\nnow came back. He called, to guide her to him. She came on till he\r\ncould just see her\xe2\x80\x94a shadow ascending the shingly slope, and growing\r\nout of the blackness of the night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou alarmed me,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered, nervously. \xe2\x80\x9cI was afraid something had\r\nhappened. I heard you cry out as if you were in pain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, carelessly. \xe2\x80\x9cI _was_ in pain. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmatter\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s over now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer hand mechanically swung something to and fro as she answered him.\r\nIt was the little white silk bag which she had always kept hidden in\r\nher bosom up to this time. One of the relics which it held\xe2\x80\x94one of the\r\nrelics which she had not had the heart to part with before\xe2\x80\x94was gone\r\nfrom its keeping forever. Alone, on a strange shore, she had torn from\r\nher the fondest of her virgin memories, the dearest of her virgin\r\nhopes. Alone, on a strange shore, she had taken the lock of Frank\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhair from its once-treasured place, and had cast it away from her to\r\nthe sea and the night.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II.\r\n\r\nThe tall man who had passed Captain Wragge in the dark proceeded\r\nrapidly along the public walk, struck off across a little waste patch\r\nof ground, and entered the open door of the Aldborough Hotel. The light\r\nin the passage, falling full on his face as he passed it, proved the\r\ntruth of Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s surmise, and showed the stranger to be Mr.\r\nKirke, of the merchant service.\r\n\r\nMeeting the landlord in the passage, Mr. Kirke nodded to him with the\r\nfamiliarity of an old customer. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you got the paper?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwant to look at the visitors\xe2\x80\x99 list.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have got it in my room, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the landlord, leading the way\r\ninto a parlor at the back of the house. \xe2\x80\x9cAre there any friends of yours\r\nstaying here, do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout replying, the seaman turned to the list as soon as the\r\nnewspaper was placed in his hand, and ran his finger down it, name by\r\nname. The finger suddenly stopped at this line: \xe2\x80\x9cSea-view Cottage; Mr.\r\nNoel Vanstone.\xe2\x80\x9d Kirke of the merchant-service repeated the name to\r\nhimself, and put down the paper thoughtfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you found anybody you know, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the landlord.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have found a name I know\xe2\x80\x94a name my father used often to speak of in\r\nhis time. Is this Mr. Vanstone a family man? Do you know if there is a\r\nyoung lady in the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t say, captain. My wife will be here directly; she is sure to\r\nknow. It must have been some time ago, if your father knew this Mr.\r\nVanstone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt _was_ some time ago. My father knew a subaltern officer of that\r\nname when he was with his regiment in Canada. It would be curious if\r\nthe person here turned out to be the same man, and if that young lady\r\nwas his daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me, captain\xe2\x80\x94but the young lady seems to hang a little on your\r\nmind,\xe2\x80\x9d said the landlord, with a pleasant smile.\r\n\r\nMr. Kirke looked as if the form which his host\xe2\x80\x99s good-humor had just\r\ntaken was not quite to his mind. He returned abruptly to the subaltern\r\nofficer and the regiment in Canada. \xe2\x80\x9cThat poor fellow\xe2\x80\x99s story was as\r\nmiserable a one as ever I heard,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking back again absently\r\nat the visitors\xe2\x80\x99 list.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould there be any harm in telling it, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the landlord.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiserable or not, a story\xe2\x80\x99s a story, when you know it to be true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Kirke hesitated. \xe2\x80\x9cI hardly think I should be doing right to tell\r\nit,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf this man, or any relations of his, are still alive,\r\nit is not a story they might like strangers to know. All I can tell you\r\nis, that my father was the salvation of that young officer under very\r\ndreadful circumstances. They parted in Canada. My father remained with\r\nhis regiment; the young officer sold out and returned to England, and\r\nfrom that moment they lost sight of each other. It would be curious if\r\nthis Vanstone here was the same man. It would be curious\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe suddenly checked himself just as another reference to \xe2\x80\x9cthe young\r\nlady\xe2\x80\x9d was on the point of passing his lips. At the same moment the\r\nlandlord\xe2\x80\x99s wife came in, and Mr. Kirke at once transferred his\r\ninquiries to the higher authority in the house.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know anything of this Mr. Vanstone who is down here on the\r\nvisitors\xe2\x80\x99 list?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the sailor. \xe2\x80\x9cIs he an old man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a miserable little creature to look at,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the landlady;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut he\xe2\x80\x99s not old, captain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he\xe2\x80\x99s not the man I mean. Perhaps he is the man\xe2\x80\x99s son? Has he got\r\nany ladies with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe landlady tossed her head, and pursed up her lips disparagingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has a housekeeper with him,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cA middle-aged person\xe2\x80\x94not\r\none of my sort. I dare say I\xe2\x80\x99m wrong\xe2\x80\x94but I don\xe2\x80\x99t like a dressy woman in\r\nher station of life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Kirke began to look puzzled. \xe2\x80\x9cI must have made some mistake about\r\nthe house,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cSurely there\xe2\x80\x99s a lawn cut octagon-shape at\r\nSea-view Cottage, and a white flag-staff in the middle of the\r\ngravel-walk?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s not Sea-view, sir! It\xe2\x80\x99s North Shingles you\xe2\x80\x99re talking of. Mr.\r\nBygrave\xe2\x80\x99s. His wife and his niece came here by the coach to-day. His\r\nwife\xe2\x80\x99s tall enough to be put in a show, and the worst-dressed woman I\r\never set eyes on. But Miss Bygrave is worth looking at, if I may\r\nventure to say so. She\xe2\x80\x99s the finest girl, to my mind, we\xe2\x80\x99ve had at\r\nAldborough for many a long day. I wonder who they are! Do you know the\r\nname, captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Kirke, with a shade of disappointment on his dark,\r\nweather-beaten face; \xe2\x80\x9cI never heard the name before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter replying in those words, he rose to take his leave. The landlord\r\nvainly invited him to drink a parting glass; the landlady vainly\r\npressed him to stay another ten minutes and try a cup of tea. He only\r\nreplied that his sister expected him, and that he must return to the\r\nparsonage immediately.\r\n\r\nOn leaving the hotel Mr. Kirke set his face westward, and walked inland\r\nalong the highroad as fast as the darkness would let him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBygrave?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cNow I know her name, how much am I\r\nthe wiser for it! If it had been Vanstone, my father\xe2\x80\x99s son might have\r\nhad a chance of making acquaintance with her.\xe2\x80\x9d He stopped, and looked\r\nback in the direction of Aldborough. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a fool I am!\xe2\x80\x9d he burst out\r\nsuddenly, striking his stick on the ground. \xe2\x80\x9cI was forty last\r\nbirthday.\xe2\x80\x9d He turned and went on again faster than ever\xe2\x80\x94his head down;\r\nhis resolute black eyes searching the darkness on the land as they had\r\nsearched it many a time on the sea from the deck of his ship.\r\n\r\nAfter more than an hour\xe2\x80\x99s walking he reached a village, with a\r\nprimitive little church and parsonage nestled together in a hollow. He\r\nentered the house by the back way, and found his sister, the\r\nclergyman\xe2\x80\x99s wife, sitting alone over her work in the parlor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is your husband, Lizzie?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, taking a chair in a corner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWilliam has gone out to see a sick person. He had just time enough\r\nbefore he went,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cto tell me about the young\r\nlady; and he declares he will never trust himself at Aldborough with\r\nyou again until you are a steady, married man.\xe2\x80\x9d She stopped, and looked\r\nat her brother more attentively than she had looked at him yet.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRobert!\xe2\x80\x9d she said, laying aside her work, and suddenly crossing the\r\nroom to him. \xe2\x80\x9cYou look anxious, you look distressed. William only\r\nlaughed about your meeting with the young lady. Is it serious? Tell me;\r\nwhat is she like?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned his head away at the question.\r\n\r\nShe took a stool at his feet, and persisted in looking up at him. \xe2\x80\x9cIs\r\nit serious, Robert?\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated, softly.\r\n\r\nKirke\xe2\x80\x99s weather-beaten face was accustomed to no concealments\xe2\x80\x94it\r\nanswered for him before he spoke a word. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t tell your husband till\r\nI am gone,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, with a roughness quite new in his sister\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexperience of him. \xe2\x80\x9cI know I only deserve to be laughed at; but it\r\nhurts me, for all that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHurts you?\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated, in astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t think me half such a fool, Lizzie, as I think myself,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\npursued Kirke, bitterly. \xe2\x80\x9cA man at my age ought to know better. I\r\ndidn\xe2\x80\x99t set eyes on her for as much as a minute altogether; and there I\r\nhave been hanging about the place till after nightfall on the chance of\r\nseeing her again\xe2\x80\x94skulking, I should have called it, if I had found one\r\nof my men doing what I have been doing myself. I believe I\xe2\x80\x99m bewitched.\r\nShe\xe2\x80\x99s a mere girl, Lizzie\xe2\x80\x94I doubt if she\xe2\x80\x99s out of her teens\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m old\r\nenough to be her father. It\xe2\x80\x99s all one; she stops in my mind in spite of\r\nme. I\xe2\x80\x99ve had her face looking at me, through the pitch darkness, every\r\nstep of the way to this house; and it\xe2\x80\x99s looking at me now\xe2\x80\x94as plain as I\r\nsee yours, and plainer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe rose impatiently, and began to walk backward and forward in the\r\nroom. His sister looked after him, with surprise as well as sympathy\r\nexpressed in her face. From his boyhood upward she had always been\r\naccustomed to see him master of himself. Years since, in the failing\r\nfortunes of the family, he had been their example and their support.\r\nShe had heard of him in the desperate emergencies of a life at sea,\r\nwhen hundreds of his fellow-creatures had looked to his steady\r\nself-possession for rescue from close-threatening death\xe2\x80\x94and had not\r\nlooked in vain. Never, in all her life before, had his sister seen the\r\nbalance of that calm and equal mind lost as she saw it lost now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you talk so unreasonably about your age and yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is not a woman alive, Robert, who is good enough for you.\r\nWhat is her name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBygrave. Do you know it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. But I might soon make acquaintance with her. If we only had a\r\nlittle time before us; if I could only get to Aldborough and see\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94but you are going away to-morrow; your ship sails at the end of the\r\nweek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank God for that!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kirke, fervently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you glad to be going away?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, more and more amazed at\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight glad, Lizzie, for my own sake. If I ever get to my senses again,\r\nI shall find my way back to them on the deck of my ship. This girl has\r\ngot between me and my thoughts already: she shan\xe2\x80\x99t go a step further,\r\nand get between me and my duty. I\xe2\x80\x99m determined on that. Fool as I am, I\r\nhave sense enough left not to trust myself within easy hail of\r\nAldborough to-morrow morning. I\xe2\x80\x99m good for another twenty miles of\r\nwalking, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll begin my journey back tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis sister started up, and caught him fast by the arm. \xe2\x80\x9cRobert!\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nexclaimed; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re not serious? You don\xe2\x80\x99t mean to leave us on foot,\r\nalone in the dark?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s only saying good-by, my dear, the last thing at night instead of\r\nthe first thing in the morning,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, with a smile. \xe2\x80\x9cTry and\r\nmake allowances for me, Lizzie. My life has been passed at sea; and I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nnot used to having my mind upset in this way. Men ashore are used to\r\nit; men ashore can take it easy. I can\xe2\x80\x99t. If I stopped here I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nrest. If I waited till to-morrow, I should only be going back to have\r\nanother look at her. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to feel more ashamed of myself than I\r\ndo already. I want to fight my way back to my duty and myself, without\r\nstopping to think twice about it. Darkness is nothing to me\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m used to\r\ndarkness. I have got the high-road to walk on, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t lose my way.\r\nLet me go, Lizzie! The only sweetheart I have any business with at my\r\nage is my ship. Let me get back to her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis sister still kept her hold of his arm, and still pleaded with him\r\nto stay till the morning. He listened to her with perfect patience and\r\nkindness, but she never shook his determination for an instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I to say to William?\xe2\x80\x9d she pleaded. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat will he think when he\r\ncomes back and finds you gone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him I have taken the advice he gave us in his sermon last Sunday.\r\nSay I have turned my back on the world, the flesh, and the devil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you talk so, Robert! And the boys, too\xe2\x80\x94you promised not to go\r\nwithout bidding the boys good-by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true. I made my little nephews a promise, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll keep it.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nkicked off his shoes as he spoke, on the mat outside the door. \xe2\x80\x9cLight\r\nme upstairs, Lizzie; I\xe2\x80\x99ll bid the two boys good-by without waking\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe saw the uselessness of resisting him any longer; and, taking the\r\ncandle, went before him upstairs.\r\n\r\nThe boys\xe2\x80\x94both young children\xe2\x80\x94were sleeping together in the same bed.\r\nThe youngest was his uncle\xe2\x80\x99s favorite, and was called by his uncle\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nname. He lay peacefully asleep, with a rough little toy ship hugged\r\nfast in his arms. Kirke\xe2\x80\x99s eyes softened as he stole on tiptoe to the\r\nchild\xe2\x80\x99s side, and kissed him with the gentleness of a woman. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor\r\nlittle man!\xe2\x80\x9d said the sailor, tenderly. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is as fond of his ship as I\r\nwas at his age. I\xe2\x80\x99ll cut him out a better one when I come back. Will\r\nyou give me my nephew one of these days, Lizzie, and will you let me\r\nmake a sailor of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Robert, if you were only married and happy, as I am!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe time has gone by, my dear. I must make the best of it as I am,\r\nwith my little nephew there to help me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe left the room. His sister\xe2\x80\x99s tears fell fast as she followed him into\r\nthe parlor. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is something so forlorn and dreadful in your leaving\r\nus like this,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cShall I go to Aldborough to-morrow, Robert,\r\nand try if I can get acquainted with her for your sake?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d he replied. \xe2\x80\x9cLet her be. If it\xe2\x80\x99s ordered that I am to see that\r\ngirl again, I _shall_ see her. Leave it to the future, and you leave it\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d He put on his shoes, and took up his hat and stick. \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t\r\noverwalk myself,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, cheerfully. \xe2\x80\x9cIf the coach doesn\xe2\x80\x99t overtake\r\nme on the road, I can wait for it where I stop to breakfast. Dry your\r\neyes, my dear, and give me a kiss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was like her brother in features and complexion, and she had a\r\ntouch of her brother\xe2\x80\x99s spirit; she dashed away the tears, and took her\r\nleave of him bravely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be back in a year\xe2\x80\x99s time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kirke, falling into his old\r\nsailor-like way at the door. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll bring you a China shawl, Lizzie, and\r\na chest of tea for your store-room. Don\xe2\x80\x99t let the boys forget me, and\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t think I\xe2\x80\x99m doing wrong to leave you in this way. I know I am doing\r\nright. God bless you and keep you, my dear\xe2\x80\x94and your husband, and your\r\nchildren! Good-by!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe stooped and kissed her. She ran to the door to look after him. A\r\npuff of air extinguished the candle, and the black night shut him out\r\nfrom her in an instant.\r\n\r\nThree days afterward the first-class merchantman _Deliverance_, Kirke,\r\ncommander, sailed from London for the China Sea.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III.\r\n\r\nThe threatening of storm and change passed away with the night. When\r\nmorning rose over Aldborough, the sun was master in the blue heaven,\r\nand the waves were rippling gayly under the summer breeze.\r\n\r\nAt an hour when no other visitors to the watering\xe2\x80\x94place were yet astir,\r\nthe indefatigable Wragge appeared at the door of North Shingles Villa,\r\nand directed his steps northward, with a neatly-bound copy of \xe2\x80\x9cJoyce\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nScientific Dialogues\xe2\x80\x9d in his hand. Arriving at the waste ground beyond\r\nthe houses, he descended to the beach and opened his book. The\r\ninterview of the past night had sharpened his perception of the\r\ndifficulties to be encountered in the coming enterprise. He was now\r\ndoubly determined to try the characteristic experiment at which he had\r\nhinted in his letter to Magdalen, and to concentrate on himself\xe2\x80\x94in the\r\ncharacter of a remarkably well-informed man\xe2\x80\x94the entire interest and\r\nattention of the formidable Mrs. Lecount.\r\n\r\nHaving taken his dose of ready-made science (to use his own expression)\r\nthe first thing in the morning on an empty stomach, Captain Wragge\r\njoined his small family circle at breakfast-time, inflated with\r\ninformation for the day. He observed that Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s face showed plain\r\nsigns of a sleepless night. She made no complaint: her manner was\r\ncomposed, and her temper perfectly under control. Mrs. Wragge\xe2\x80\x94refreshed\r\nby some thirteen consecutive hours of uninterrupted repose\xe2\x80\x94was in\r\nexcellent spirits, and up at heel (for a wonder) with both shoes. She\r\nbrought with her into the room several large sheets of tissue-paper,\r\ncut crisply into mysterious and many-varying forms, which immediately\r\nprovoked from her husband the short and sharp question, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you\r\ngot there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPatterns, captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Wragge, in timidly conciliating tones.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI went shopping in London, and bought an Oriental Cashmere Robe. It\r\ncost a deal of money; and I\xe2\x80\x99m going to try and save, by making it\r\nmyself. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got my patterns, and my dress-making directions written\r\nout as plain as print. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be very tidy, captain; I\xe2\x80\x99ll keep in my own\r\ncorner, if you\xe2\x80\x99ll please to give me one; and whether my head Buzzes, or\r\nwhether it don\xe2\x80\x99t, I\xe2\x80\x99ll sit straight at my work all the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will do your work,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, sternly, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you know who\r\nyou are, who I am, and who that young lady is\xe2\x80\x94not before. Show me your\r\nshoes! Good. Show me you cap! Good. Make the breakfast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen breakfast was over, Mrs. Wragge received her orders to retire into\r\nan adjoining room, and to wait there until her husband came to release\r\nher. As soon as her back was turned, Captain Wragge at once resumed the\r\nconversation which had been suspended, by Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s own desire, on the\r\npreceding night. The questions he now put to her all related to the\r\nsubject of her visit in disguise to Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s house. They were\r\nthe questions of a thoroughly clear-headed man\xe2\x80\x94short, searching, and\r\nstraight to the point. In less than half an hour\xe2\x80\x99s time he had made\r\nhimself acquainted with every incident that had happened in Vauxhall\r\nWalk.\r\n\r\nThe conclusions which the captain drew, after gaining his information,\r\nwere clear and easily stated.\r\n\r\nOn the adverse side of the question, he expressed his conviction that\r\nMrs. Lecount had certainly detected her visitor to be disguised; that\r\nshe had never really left the room, though she might have opened and\r\nshut the door; and that on both the occasions, therefore, when Magdalen\r\nhad been betrayed into speaking in her own voice, Mrs. Lecount had\r\nheard her. On the favorable side of the question, he was perfectly\r\nsatisfied that the painted face and eyelids, the wig, and the padded\r\ncloak had so effectually concealed Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s identity, that she might\r\nin her own person defy the housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s closest scrutiny, so far as\r\nthe matter of appearance was concerned. The difficulty of deceiving\r\nMrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s ears, as well as her eyes, was, he readily admitted, not\r\nso easily to be disposed of. But looking to the fact that Magdalen, on\r\nboth the occasions when she had forgotten herself, had spoken in the\r\nheat of anger, he was of opinion that her voice had every reasonable\r\nchance of escaping detection, if she carefully avoided all outbursts of\r\ntemper for the future, and spoke in those more composed and ordinary\r\ntones which Mrs. Lecount had not yet heard. Upon the whole, the captain\r\nwas inclined to pronounce the prospect hopeful, if one serious obstacle\r\nwere cleared away at the outset\xe2\x80\x94that obstacle being nothing less than\r\nthe presence on the scene of action of Mrs. Wragge.\r\n\r\nTo Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s surprise, when the course of her narrative brought her to\r\nthe story of the ghost, Captain Wragge listened with the air of a man\r\nwho was more annoyed than amused by what he heard. When she had done,\r\nhe plainly told her that her unlucky meeting on the stairs of the\r\nlodging-house with Mrs. Wragge was, in his opinion, the most serious of\r\nall the accidents that had happened in Vauxhall Walk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can deal with the difficulty of my wife\xe2\x80\x99s stupidity,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cas I\r\nhave often dealt with it before. I can hammer her new identity _into_\r\nher head, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t hammer the ghost _out_ of it. We have no security\r\nthat the woman in the gray cloak and poke bonnet may not come back to\r\nher recollection at the most critical time, and under the most awkward\r\ncircumstances. In plain English, my dear girl, Mrs. Wragge is a pitfall\r\nunder our feet at every step we take.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we are aware of the pitfall,\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen, \xe2\x80\x9cwe can take our\r\nmeasures for avoiding it. What do you propose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI propose,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the captain, \xe2\x80\x9cthe temporary removal of Mrs.\r\nWragge. Speaking purely in a pecuniary point of view, I can\xe2\x80\x99t afford a\r\ntotal separation from her. You have often read of very poor people\r\nbeing suddenly enriched by legacies reaching them from remote and\r\nunexpected quarters? Mrs. Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s case, when I married her, was one of\r\nthese. An elderly female relative shared the favors of fortune on that\r\noccasion with my wife; and if I only keep up domestic appearances, I\r\nhappen to know that Mrs. Wragge will prove a second time profitable to\r\nme on that elderly relative\xe2\x80\x99s death. But for this circumstance, I\r\nshould probably long since have transferred my wife to the care of\r\nsociety at large\xe2\x80\x94in the agreeable conviction that if I didn\xe2\x80\x99t support\r\nher, somebody else would. Although I can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to take this course,\r\nI see no objection to having her comfortably boarded and lodged out of\r\nour way for the time being\xe2\x80\x94say, at a retired farm-house, in the\r\ncharacter of a lady in infirm mental health. _You_ would find the\r\nexpense trifling; _I_ should find the relief unutterable. What do you\r\nsay? Shall I pack her up at once, and take her away by the next coach?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Magdalen, firmly. \xe2\x80\x9cThe poor creature\xe2\x80\x99s life is hard\r\nenough already; I won\xe2\x80\x99t help to make it harder. She was affectionately\r\nand truly kind to me when I was ill, and I won\xe2\x80\x99t allow her to be shut\r\nup among strangers while I can help it. The risk of keeping her here is\r\nonly one risk more. I will face it, Captain Wragge, if you won\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink twice,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cbefore you decide on keeping\r\nMrs. Wragge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnce is enough,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Magdalen. \xe2\x80\x9cI won\xe2\x80\x99t have her sent away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, resignedly. \xe2\x80\x9cI never interfere with\r\nquestions of sentiment. But I have a word to say on my own behalf. If\r\nmy services are to be of any use to you, I can\xe2\x80\x99t have my hands tied at\r\nstarting. This is serious. I won\xe2\x80\x99t trust my wife and Mrs. Lecount\r\ntogether. I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid, if you\xe2\x80\x99re not, and I make it a condition that, if\r\nMrs. Wragge stops here, she keeps her room. If you think her health\r\nrequires it, you can take her for a walk early in the morning, or late\r\nin the evening; but you must never trust her out with the servant, and\r\nnever trust her out by herself. I put the matter plainly, it is too\r\nimportant to be trifled with. What do you say\xe2\x80\x94yes or no?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say yes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Magdalen, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s consideration. \xe2\x80\x9cOn the\r\nunderstanding that I am to take her out walking, as you propose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge bowed, and recovered his suavity of manner. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are\r\nour plans?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired. \xe2\x80\x9cShall we start our enterprise this afternoon?\r\nAre you ready for your introduction to Mrs. Lecount and her master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood again. We will meet them on the Parade, at their usual hour for\r\ngoing out\xe2\x80\x94two o\xe2\x80\x99clock. It is not twelve yet. I have two hours before\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94just time enough to fit my wife into her new Skin. The process is\r\nabsolutely necessary, to prevent her compromising us with the servant.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid about the results; Mrs. Wragge has had a copious\r\nselection of assumed names hammered into her head in the course of her\r\nmatrimonial career. It is merely a question of hammering hard\r\nenough\xe2\x80\x94nothing more. I think we have settled everything now. Is there\r\nanything I can do before two o\xe2\x80\x99clock? Have you any employment for the\r\nmorning?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall go back to my own room, and try to rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had a disturbed night, I am afraid?\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, politely\r\nopening the door for her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fell asleep once or twice,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, carelessly. \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose my\r\nnerves are a little shaken. The bold black eyes of that man who stared\r\nso rudely at me yesterday evening seemed to be looking at me again in\r\nmy dreams. If we see him to-day, and if he annoys me any more, I must\r\ntrouble you to speak to him. We will meet here again at two o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t be hard with Mrs. Wragge; teach her what she must learn as\r\ntenderly as you can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith those words she left him, and went upstairs.\r\n\r\nShe lay down on her bed with a heavy sigh, and tried to sleep. It was\r\nuseless. The dull weariness of herself which now possessed her was not\r\nthe weariness which finds its remedy in repose. She rose again and sat\r\nby the window, looking out listlessly over the sea.\r\n\r\nA weaker nature than hers would not have felt the shock of Frank\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndesertion as she had felt it\xe2\x80\x94as she was feeling it still. A weaker\r\nnature would have found refuge in indignation and comfort in tears. The\r\npassionate strength of Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s love clung desperately to the sinking\r\nwreck of its own delusion-clung, until she tore herself from it, by\r\nplain force of will. All that her native pride, her keen sense of wrong\r\ncould do, was to shame her from dwelling on the thoughts which still\r\ncaught their breath of life from the undying devotion of the past;\r\nwhich still perversely ascribed Frank\xe2\x80\x99s heartless farewell to any cause\r\nbut the inborn baseness of the man who had written it. The woman never\r\nlived yet who could cast a true-love out of her heart because the\r\nobject of that love was unworthy of her. All she can do is to struggle\r\nagainst it in secret\xe2\x80\x94to sink in the contest if she is weak; to win her\r\nway through it if she is strong, by a process of self-laceration which\r\nis, of all moral remedies applied to a woman\xe2\x80\x99s nature, the most\r\ndangerous and the most desperate; of all moral changes, the change that\r\nis surest to mark her for life. Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s strong nature had sustained\r\nher through the struggle; and the issue of it had left her what she now\r\nwas.\r\n\r\nAfter sitting by the window for nearly an hour, her eyes looking\r\nmechanically at the view, her mind empty of all impressions, and\r\nconscious of no thoughts, she shook off the strange waking stupor that\r\npossessed her, and rose to prepare herself for the serious business of\r\nthe day.\r\n\r\nShe went to the wardrobe and took down from the pegs two bright,\r\ndelicate muslin dresses, which had been made for summer wear at\r\nCombe-Raven a year since, and which had been of too little value to be\r\nworth selling when she parted with her other possessions. After placing\r\nthese dresses side by side on the bed, she looked into the wardrobe\r\nonce more. It only contained one other summer dress\xe2\x80\x94the plain alpaca\r\ngown which she had worn during her memorable interview with Noel\r\nVanstone and Mrs. Lecount. This she left in its place, resolving not to\r\nwear it\xe2\x80\x94less from any dread that the housekeeper might recognize a\r\npattern too quiet to be noticed, and too common to be remembered, than\r\nfrom the conviction that it was neither gay enough nor becoming enough\r\nfor her purpose. After taking a plain white muslin scarf, a pair of\r\nlight gray kid gloves, and a garden-hat of Tuscan straw, from the\r\ndrawers of the wardrobe, she locked it, and put the key carefully in\r\nher pocket.\r\n\r\nInstead of at once proceeding to dress herself, she sat idly looking at\r\nthe two muslin gowns; careless which she wore, and yet inconsistently\r\nhesitating which to choose. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat does it matter!\xe2\x80\x9d she said to herself,\r\nwith a reckless laugh; \xe2\x80\x9cI am equally worthless in my own estimation,\r\nwhichever I put on.\xe2\x80\x9d She shuddered, as if the sound of her own laughter\r\nhad startled her, and abruptly caught up the dress which lay nearest to\r\nher hand. Its colors were blue and white\xe2\x80\x94the shade of blue which best\r\nsuited her fair complexion. She hurriedly put on the gown, without\r\ngoing near her looking-glass. For the first time in her life she shrank\r\nfrom meeting the reflection of herself\xe2\x80\x94except for a moment, when she\r\narranged her hair under her garden-hat, leaving the glass again\r\nimmediately. She drew her scarf over her shoulders and fitted on her\r\ngloves, with her back to the toilet-table. \xe2\x80\x9cShall I paint?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked\r\nherself, feeling instinctively that she was turning pale. \xe2\x80\x9cThe rouge is\r\nstill left in my box. It can\xe2\x80\x99t make my face more false than it is\r\nalready.\xe2\x80\x9d She looked round toward the glass, and again turned away from\r\nit. \xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cI have Mrs. Lecount to face as well as her master.\r\nNo paint.\xe2\x80\x9d After consulting her watch, she left the room and went\r\ndownstairs again. It wanted ten minutes only of two o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge was waiting for her in the parlor\xe2\x80\x94respectable, in a\r\nfrock-coat, a stiff summer cravat, and a high white hat; specklessly\r\nand cheerfully rural, in a buff waistcoat, gray trousers, and gaiters\r\nto match. His collars were higher than ever, and he carried a brand-new\r\ncamp-stool in his hand. Any tradesman in England who had seen him at\r\nthat moment would have trusted him on the spot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCharming!\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, paternally surveying Magdalen when she\r\nentered the room. \xe2\x80\x9cSo fresh and cool! A little too pale, my dear, and a\r\ngreat deal too serious. Otherwise perfect. Try if you can smile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen the time comes for smiling,\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen, bitterly, \xe2\x80\x9ctrust my\r\ndramatic training for any change of face that may be necessary. Where\r\nis Mrs. Wragge?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Wragge has learned her lesson,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the captain, \xe2\x80\x9cand is\r\nrewarded by my permission to sit at work in her own room. I sanction\r\nher new fancy for dressmaking, because it is sure to absorb all her\r\nattention, and to keep her at home. There is no fear of her finishing\r\nthe Oriental Robe in a hurry, for there is no mistake in the process of\r\nmaking it which she is not certain to commit. She will sit incubating\r\nher gown\xe2\x80\x94pardon the expression\xe2\x80\x94like a hen over an addled egg. I assure\r\nyou, her new whim relieves me. Nothing could be more convenient, under\r\nexisting circumstances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe strutted away to the window, looked out, and beckoned to Magdalen to\r\njoin him. \xe2\x80\x9cThere they are!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and pointed to the Parade.\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone slowly walked by, as she looked, dressed in a complete\r\nsuit of old-fashioned nankeen. It was apparently one of the days when\r\nthe state of his health was at the worst. He leaned on Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narm, and was protected from the sun by a light umbrella which she held\r\nover him. The housekeeper\xe2\x80\x94dressed to perfection, as usual, in a quiet,\r\nlavender-colored summer gown, a black mantilla, an unassuming straw\r\nbonnet, and a crisp blue veil\xe2\x80\x94escorted her invalid master with the\r\ntenderest attention; sometimes directing his notice respectfully to the\r\nvarious objects of the sea view; sometimes bending her head in graceful\r\nacknowledgment of the courtesy of passing strangers on the Parade, who\r\nstepped aside to let the invalid pass by. She produced a visible effect\r\namong the idlers on the beach. They looked after her with unanimous\r\ninterest, and exchanged confidential nods of approval which said, as\r\nplainly as words could have expressed it, \xe2\x80\x9cA very domestic person! a\r\ntruly superior woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s party-colored eyes followed Mrs. Lecount with a\r\nsteady, distrustful attention. \xe2\x80\x9cTough work for us _there_,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nwhispered in Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s ear; \xe2\x80\x9ctougher work than you think, before we\r\nturn that woman out of her place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait,\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen, quietly. \xe2\x80\x9cWait and see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe walked to the door. The captain followed her without making any\r\nfurther remark. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll wait till you\xe2\x80\x99re married,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought to\r\nhimself\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cnot a moment longer, offer me what you may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the house door Magdalen addressed him again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will go that way,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, pointing southward, \xe2\x80\x9cthen turn, and\r\nmeet them as they come back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge signified his approval of the arrangement, and followed\r\nMagdalen to the garden gate. As she opened it to pass through, her\r\nattention was attracted by a lady, with a nursery-maid and two little\r\nboys behind her, loitering on the path outside the garden wall. The\r\nlady started, looked eagerly, and smiled to herself as Magdalen came\r\nout. Curiosity had got the better of Kirke\xe2\x80\x99s sister, and she had come\r\nto Aldborough for the express purpose of seeing Miss Bygrave.\r\n\r\nSomething in the shape of the lady\xe2\x80\x99s face, something in the expression\r\nof her dark eyes, reminded Magdalen of the merchant-captain whose\r\nuncontrolled admiration had annoyed her on the previous evening. She\r\ninstantly returned the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s scrutiny by a frowning, ungracious\r\nlook. The lady colored, paid the look back with interest, and slowly\r\nwalked on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hard, bold, bad girl,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Kirke\xe2\x80\x99s sister. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat could Robert be\r\nthinking of to admire her? I am almost glad he is gone. I hope and\r\ntrust he will never set eyes on Miss Bygrave again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat boors the people are here!\xe2\x80\x9d said Magdalen to Captain Wragge.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat woman was even ruder than the man last night. She is like him in\r\nthe face. I wonder who she is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll find out directly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t be too cautious\r\nabout strangers.\xe2\x80\x9d He at once appealed to his friends, the boatmen. They\r\nwere close at hand, and Magdalen heard the questions and answers\r\nplainly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you all this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Wragge, in his easy\r\njocular way. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd how\xe2\x80\x99s the wind? Nor\xe2\x80\x99-west and by west, is it? Very\r\ngood. Who is that lady?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s Mrs. Strickland, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy! ay! The clergyman\xe2\x80\x99s wife and the captain\xe2\x80\x99s sister. Where\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\ncaptain to-day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn his way to London, I should think, sir.
