The morning\r\nanswer (relating to Magdalen) was, \xe2\x80\x9ca shade better.\xe2\x80\x9d The afternoon\r\nanswer (relating to Captain Wragge) was, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Bygrave has just gone\r\nout.\xe2\x80\x9d That evening Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s temper was very uncertain, and Mrs.\r\nLecount\xe2\x80\x99s patience and tact were sorely tried in the effort to avoid\r\noffending him.\r\n\r\nOn the third morning the report of the suffering young lady was less\r\nfavorable\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Bygrave was still very poorly, and not able to leave\r\nher bed.\xe2\x80\x9d The servant returning to Sea View with this message, met the\r\npostman, and took into the breakfast-room with her two letters\r\naddressed to Mrs. Lecount.\r\n\r\nThe first letter was in a handwriting familiar to the housekeeper. It\r\nwas from the medical attendant on her invalid brother at Zurich; and it\r\nannounced that the patient\xe2\x80\x99s malady had latterly altered in so marked a\r\nmanner for the better that there was every hope now of preserving his\r\nlife.\r\n\r\nThe address on the second letter was in a strange handwriting. Mrs.\r\nLecount, concluding that it was the answer from Miss Vanstone, waited\r\nto read it until breakfast was over, and she could retire to her own\r\nroom.\r\n\r\nShe opened the letter, looked at once for the name at the end, and\r\nstarted a little as she read it. The signature was not \xe2\x80\x9cNorah\r\nVanstone,\xe2\x80\x9d but \xe2\x80\x9cHarriet Garth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Garth announced that the elder Miss Vanstone had, a week since,\r\naccepted an engagement as governess, subject to the condition of\r\njoining the family of her employer at their temporary residence in the\r\nsouth of France, and of returning with them when they came back to\r\nEngland, probably in a month or six weeks\xe2\x80\x99 time. During the interval of\r\nthis necessary absence Miss Vanstone had requested Miss Garth to open\r\nall her letters, her main object in making that arrangement being to\r\nprovide for the speedy answering of any communication which might\r\narrive for her from her sister. Miss Magdalen Vanstone had not written\r\nsince the middle of July\xe2\x80\x94on which occasion the postmark on the letter\r\nshowed that it must have been posted in London, in the district of\r\nLambeth\xe2\x80\x94and her elder sister had left England in a state of the most\r\ndistressing anxiety on her account.\r\n\r\nHaving completed this explanation, Miss Garth then mentioned that\r\nfamily circumstances prevented her from traveling personally to\r\nAldborough to assist Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s object, but that she was provided\r\nwith a substitute; in every way fitter for the purpose, in the person\r\nof Mr. Pendril. That gentleman was well acquainted with Miss Magdalen\r\nVanstone, and his professional experience and discretion would render\r\nhis assistance doubly valuable. He had kindly consented to travel to\r\nAldborough whenever it might be thought necessary. But as his time was\r\nvery valuable, Miss Garth specially requested that he might not be sent\r\nfor until Mrs. Lecount was quite sure of the day on which his services\r\nmight be required.\r\n\r\nWhile proposing this arrangement, Miss Garth added that she thought it\r\nright to furnish her correspondent with a written description of the\r\nyounger Miss Vanstone as well. An emergency might happen which would\r\nallow Mrs. Lecount no time for securing Mr. Pendril\xe2\x80\x99s services; and the\r\nexecution of Mr. Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s intentions toward the unhappy girl who\r\nwas the object of his forbearance might be fatally delayed by an\r\nunforeseen difficulty in establishing her identity. The personal\r\ndescription, transmitted under these circumstances, then followed. It\r\nomitted no personal peculiarity by which Magdalen could be recognized,\r\nand it included the \xe2\x80\x9ctwo little moles close together on the left side\r\nof the neck,\xe2\x80\x9d which had been formerly mentioned in the printed\r\nhandbills sent to York.\r\n\r\nIn conclusion, Miss Garth expressed her fears that Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsuspicions were only too likely to be proved true. While, however,\r\nthere was the faintest chance that the conspiracy might turn out to be\r\ndirected by a stranger, Miss Garth felt bound, in gratitude toward Mr.\r\nNoel Vanstone, to assist the legal proceedings which would in that case\r\nbe instituted. She accordingly appended her own formal denial\xe2\x80\x94which she\r\nwould personally repeat if necessary\xe2\x80\x94of any identity between herself\r\nand the person in disguise who had made use of her name. She was the\r\nMiss Garth who had filled the situation of the late Mr. Andrew\r\nVanstone\xe2\x80\x99s governess, and she had never in her life been in, or near,\r\nthe neighborhood of Vauxhall Wall.\r\n\r\nWith this disclaimer, and with the writer\xe2\x80\x99s fervent assurances that she\r\nwould do all for Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s advantage which her sister might have done\r\nif her sister had been in England, the letter concluded. It was signed\r\nin full, and was dated with the business-like accuracy in such matters\r\nwhich had always distinguished Miss Garth\xe2\x80\x99s character.\r\n\r\nThis letter placed a formidable weapon in the housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s hands.\r\n\r\nIt provided a means of establishing Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s identity through the\r\nintervention of a lawyer by profession. It contained a personal\r\ndescription minute enough to be used to advantage, if necessary, before\r\nMr. Pendril\xe2\x80\x99s appearance. It presented a signed exposure of the false\r\nMiss Garth under the hand of the true Miss Garth; and it established\r\nthe fact that the last letter received by the elder Miss Vanstone from\r\nthe younger had been posted (and therefore probably written) in the\r\nneighborhood of Vauxhall Walk. If any later letter had been received\r\nwith the Aldborough postmark, the chain of evidence, so far as the\r\nquestion of localities was concerned, might doubtless have been more\r\ncomplete. But as it was, there was testimony enough (aided as that\r\ntestimony might be by the fragment of the brown alpaca dress still in\r\nMrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s possession) to raise the veil which hung over the\r\nconspiracy, and to place Mr. Noel Vanstone face to face with the plain\r\nand startling truth.\r\n\r\nThe one obstacle which now stood in the way of immediate action on the\r\nhousekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s part was the obstacle of Miss Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s present seclusion\r\nwithin the limits of her own room. The question of gaining personal\r\naccess to her was a question which must be decided before any\r\ncommunication could be opened with Mr. Pendril. Mrs. Lecount put on her\r\nbonnet at once, and called at North Shingles to try what discoveries\r\nshe could make for herself before post-time.\r\n\r\nOn this occasion Mr. Bygrave was at home, and she was admitted without\r\nthe least difficulty.\r\n\r\nCareful consideration that morning had decided Captain Wragge on\r\nadvancing matters a little nearer to the crisis. The means by which he\r\nproposed achieving this result made it necessary for him to see the\r\nhousekeeper and her master separately, and to set them at variance by\r\nproducing two totally opposite impressions relating to himself on their\r\nminds. Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s visit, therefore, instead of causing him any\r\nembarrassment, was the most welcome occurrence he could have wished\r\nfor. He received her in the parlor with a marked restraint of manner\r\nfor which she was quite unprepared. His ingratiating smile was gone,\r\nand an impenetrable solemnity of countenance appeared in its stead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have ventured to intrude on you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Lecount, \xe2\x80\x9cto\r\nexpress the regret with which both my master and I have heard of Miss\r\nBygrave\xe2\x80\x99s illness. Is there no improvement?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the captain, as briefly as possible. \xe2\x80\x9cMy niece is\r\nno better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have had some experience, Mr. Bygrave, in nursing. If I could be of\r\nany use\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Mrs. Lecount. There is no necessity for our taking\r\nadvantage of your kindness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis plain answer was followed by a moment\xe2\x80\x99s silence. The housekeeper\r\nfelt some little perplexity. What had become of Mr. Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s elaborate\r\ncourtesy, and Mr. Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s many words? Did he want to offend her? If\r\nhe did, Mrs. Lecount then and there determined that he should not gain\r\nhis object.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I inquire the nature of the illness?\xe2\x80\x9d she persisted. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not\r\nconnected, I hope, with our excursion to Dunwich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI regret to say, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the captain, \xe2\x80\x9cit began with that\r\nneuralgic attack in the carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo! so!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Mrs. Lecount. \xe2\x80\x9cHe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t even _try_ to make me think\r\nthe illness a real one; he throws off the mask at starting.\xe2\x80\x94Is it a\r\nnervous illness, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d she added, aloud.\r\n\r\nThe captain answered by a solemn affirmative inclination of the head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have _two_ nervous sufferers in the house, Mr. Bygrave?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am\xe2\x80\x94two. My wife and my niece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is rather a strange coincidence of misfortunes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, ma\xe2\x80\x99am. Very strange.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn spite of Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s resolution not to be offended, Captain\r\nWragge\xe2\x80\x99s exasperating insensibility to every stroke she aimed at him\r\nbegan to ruffle her. She was conscious of some little difficulty in\r\nsecuring her self-possession before she could say anything more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there no immediate hope,\xe2\x80\x9d she resumed, \xe2\x80\x9cof Miss Bygrave being able\r\nto leave her room?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone whatever, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are satisfied, I suppose, with the medical attendance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no medical attendance,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, composedly. \xe2\x80\x9cI watch\r\nthe case myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe gathering venom in Mrs. Lecount swelled up at that reply, and\r\noverflowed at her lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour smattering of science, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a malicious smile,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cincludes, I presume, a smattering of medicine as well?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt does, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the captain, without the slightest\r\ndisturbance of face or manner. \xe2\x80\x9cI know as much of one as I do of the\r\nother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tone in which he spoke those words left Mrs. Lecount but one\r\ndignified alternative. She rose to terminate the interview. The\r\ntemptation of the moment proved too much for her, and she could not\r\nresist casting the shadow of a threat over Captain Wragge at parting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI defer thanking you, sir, for the manner in which you have received\r\nme,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cuntil I can pay my debt of obligation to some purpose.\r\nIn the meantime I am glad to infer, from the absence of a medical\r\nattendant in the house, that Miss Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s illness is much less\r\nserious than I had supposed it to be when I came here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never contradict a lady, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the incorrigible captain.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it is your pleasure, when we next meet to think my niece quite\r\nwell, I shall bow resignedly to the expression of your opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d With\r\nthose words, he followed the housekeeper into the passage, and politely\r\nopened the door for her. \xe2\x80\x9cI mark the trick, ma\xe2\x80\x99am!\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself,\r\nas he closed it again. \xe2\x80\x9cThe trump-card in your hand is a sight of my\r\nniece, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll take care you don\xe2\x80\x99t play it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe returned to the parlor, and composedly awaited the next event which\r\nwas likely to happen\xe2\x80\x94a visit from Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s master. In less than\r\nan hour results justified Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s anticipations, and Noel\r\nVanstone walked in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear sir!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the captain, cordially seizing his visitor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreluctant hand, \xe2\x80\x9cI know what you have come for. Mrs. Lecount has told\r\nyou of her visit here, and has no doubt declared that my niece\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nillness is a mere subterfuge. You feel surprised\xe2\x80\x94you feel hurt\xe2\x80\x94you\r\nsuspect me of trifling with your kind sympathies\xe2\x80\x94in short, you require\r\nan explanation. That explanation you shall have. Take a seat. Mr.\r\nVanstone. I am about to throw myself on your sense and judgment as a\r\nman of the world. I acknowledge that we are in a false position, sir;\r\nand I tell you plainly at the outset\xe2\x80\x94your housekeeper is the cause of\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor once in his life, Noel Vanstone opened his eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cLecount!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nexclaimed, in the utmost bewilderment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Captain Wragge. \xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid I offended Mrs.\r\nLecount, when she came here this morning, by a want of cordiality in my\r\nmanner. I am a plain man, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t assume what I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel. Far be\r\nit from me to breathe a word against your housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s character. She\r\nis, no doubt, a most excellent and trustworthy woman, but she has one\r\nserious failing common to persons at her time of life who occupy her\r\nsituation\xe2\x80\x94she is jealous of her influence over her master, although you\r\nmay not have observed it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Noel Vanstone; \xe2\x80\x9cmy observation is\r\nremarkably quick. Nothing escapes me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the captain, \xe2\x80\x9cyou cannot fail to have\r\nnoticed that Mrs. Lecount has allowed her jealousy to affect her\r\nconduct toward my niece?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone thought of the domestic passage at arms between Mrs.\r\nLecount and himself when his guests of the evening had left Sea View,\r\nand failed to see his way to any direct reply. He expressed the utmost\r\nsurprise and distress\xe2\x80\x94he thought Lecount had done her best to be\r\nagreeable on the drive to Dunwich\xe2\x80\x94he hoped and trusted there was some\r\nunfortunate mistake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean to say, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued the captain, severely, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you\r\nhave not noticed the circumstance yourself? As a man of honor and a man\r\nof observation, you can\xe2\x80\x99t tell me that! Your housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s superficial\r\ncivility has not hidden your housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s real feeling. My niece has\r\nseen it, and so have you, and so have I. My niece, Mr. Vanstone, is a\r\nsensitive, high-spirited girl; and she has positively declined to\r\ncultivate Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s society for the future. Don\xe2\x80\x99t misunderstand\r\nme! To my niece as well as to myself, the attraction of _your_ society,\r\nMr. Vanstone, remains the same. Miss Bygrave simply declines to be an\r\napple of discord (if you will permit the classical allusion) cast into\r\nyour household. I think she is right so far, and I frankly confess that\r\nI have exaggerated a nervous indisposition, from which she is really\r\nsuffering, into a serious illness\xe2\x80\x94purely and entirely to prevent these\r\ntwo ladies for the present from meeting every day on the Parade, and\r\nfrom carrying unpleasant impressions of each other into your domestic\r\nestablishment and mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI allow nothing unpleasant in _my_ establishment,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Noel\r\nVanstone. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m master\xe2\x80\x94you must have noticed that already, Mr.\r\nBygrave\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99m master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt of it, my dear sir. But to live morning, noon, and night in\r\nthe perpetual exercise of your authority is more like the life of a\r\ngovernor of a prison than the life of a master of a household. The wear\r\nand tear\xe2\x80\x94consider the wear and tear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt strikes you in that light, does it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Noel Vanstone, soothed by\r\nCaptain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s ready recognition of his authority. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know that\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re not right. But I must take some steps directly. I won\xe2\x80\x99t be made\r\nridiculous\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll send Lecount away altogether, sooner than be made\r\nridiculous.\xe2\x80\x9d His color rose, and he folded his little arms fiercely.\r\nCaptain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s artfully irritating explanation had awakened that\r\ndormant suspicion of his housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s influence over him which\r\nhabitually lay hidden in his mind, and which Mrs. Lecount was now not\r\npresent to charm back to repose as usual. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat must Miss Bygrave think\r\nof me!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, with a sudden outburst of vexation. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll send\r\nLecount away. Damme, I\xe2\x80\x99ll send Lecount away on the spot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, no!\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, whose interest it was to avoid driving\r\nMrs. Lecount to any desperate extremities. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy take strong measures\r\nwhen mild measures will do? Mrs. Lecount is an old servant; Mrs.\r\nLecount is attached and useful. She has this little drawback of\r\njealousy\xe2\x80\x94jealousy of her domestic position with her bachelor master.\r\nShe sees you paying courteous attention to a handsome young lady; she\r\nsees that young lady properly sensible of your politeness; and, poor\r\nsoul, she loses her temper! What is the obvious remedy? Humor her\xe2\x80\x94make\r\na manly concession to the weaker sex. If Mrs. Lecount is with you, the\r\nnext time we meet on the Parade, walk the other way. If Mrs. Lecount is\r\nnot with you, give us the pleasure of your company by all means. In\r\nshort, my dear sir, try the _suaviter in modo_ (as we classical men\r\nsay) before you commit yourself to the _fortiter in re!\xe2\x80\x9d_\r\n\r\nThere was one excellent reason why Noel Vanstone should take Captain\r\nWragge\xe2\x80\x99s conciliatory advice. An open rupture with Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x94even if\r\nhe could have summoned the courage to face it\xe2\x80\x94would imply the\r\nrecognition of her claims to a provision, in acknowledgment of the\r\nservices she had rendered to his father and to himself. His sordid\r\nnature quailed within him at the bare prospect of expressing the\r\nemotion of gratitude in a pecuniary form; and, after first consulting\r\nappearances by a show of hesitation, he consented to adopt the\r\ncaptain\xe2\x80\x99s suggestion, and to humor Mrs. Lecount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I must be considered in this matter,\xe2\x80\x9d proceeded Noel Vanstone. \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\nconcession to Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s weakness must not be misunderstood. Miss\r\nBygrave must not be allowed to suppose I am afraid of my housekeeper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain declared that no such idea ever had entered, or ever could\r\nenter, Miss Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s mind. Noel Vanstone returned to the subject\r\nnevertheless, again and again, with his customary pertinacity. Would it\r\nbe indiscreet if he asked leave to set himself right personally with\r\nMiss Bygrave? Was there any hope that he might have the happiness of\r\nseeing her on that day? or, if not, on the next day? or if not, on the\r\nday after? Captain Wragge answered cautiously: he felt the importance\r\nof not rousing Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s distrust by too great an alacrity in\r\ncomplying with his wishes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn interview to-day, my dear sir, is out of the question,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is not well enough; she wants repose. To-morrow I propose taking\r\nher out before the heat of the day begins\xe2\x80\x94not merely to avoid\r\nembarrassment, after what has happened with Mrs. Lecount, but because\r\nthe morning air and the morning quiet are essential in these nervous\r\ncases. We are early people here\xe2\x80\x94we shall start at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock. If you\r\nare early, too, and if you would like to join us, I need hardly say\r\nthat we can feel no objection to your company on our morning walk. The\r\nhour, I am aware, is an unusual one\xe2\x80\x94but later in the day my niece may\r\nbe resting on the sofa, and may not be able to see visitors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving made this proposal purely for the purpose of enabling Noel\r\nVanstone to escape to North Shingles at an hour in the morning when his\r\nhousekeeper would be probably in bed, Captain Wragge left him to take\r\nthe hint, if he could, as indirectly as it had been given. He proved\r\nsharp enough (the case being one in which his own interests were\r\nconcerned) to close with the proposal on the spot. Politely declaring\r\nthat he was always an early man when the morning presented any special\r\nattraction to him, he accepted the appointment for seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and\r\nrose soon afterward to take his leave.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne word at parting,\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Wragge. \xe2\x80\x9cThis conversation is\r\nentirely between ourselves. Mrs. Lecount must know nothing of the\r\nimpression she has produced on my niece. I have only mentioned it to\r\nyou to account for my apparently churlish conduct and to satisfy your\r\nown mind. In confidence, Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x94strictly in confidence.\r\nGood-morning!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these parting words, the captain bowed his visitor out. Unless\r\nsome unexpected disaster occurred, he now saw his way safely to the end\r\nof the enterprise. He had gained two important steps in advance that\r\nmorning. He had sown the seeds of variance between the housekeeper and\r\nher master, and he had given Noel Vanstone a common interest with\r\nMagdalen and himself, in keeping a secret from Mrs. Lecount. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have\r\ncaught our man,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Captain Wragge, cheerfully rubbing his\r\nhands\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwe have caught our man at last!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn leaving North Shingles Noel Vanstone walked straight home, fully\r\nrestored to his place in his own estimation, and sternly determined to\r\ncarry matters with a high hand if he found himself in collision with\r\nMrs. Lecount.\r\n\r\nThe housekeeper received her master at the door with her mildest manner\r\nand her gentlest smile. She addressed him with downcast eyes; she\r\nopposed to his contemplated assertion of independence a barrier of\r\nimpenetrable respect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I venture to ask, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d she began, \xe2\x80\x9cif your visit to North\r\nShingles has led you to form the same conclusion as mine on the subject\r\nof Miss Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s illness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not, Lecount. I consider your conclusion to have been both\r\nhasty and prejudiced.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry to hear it, sir. I felt hurt by Mr. Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s rude\r\nreception of me, but I was not aware that my judgment was prejudiced by\r\nit. Perhaps he received _you_, sir, with a warmer welcome?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe received me like a gentleman\xe2\x80\x94that is all I think it necessary to\r\nsay, Lecount\xe2\x80\x94he received me like a gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis answer satisfied Mrs. Lecount on the one doubtful point that had\r\nperplexed her. Whatever Mr. Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s sudden coolness toward herself\r\nmight mean, his polite reception of her master implied that the risk of\r\ndetection had not daunted him, and that the plot was still in full\r\nprogress. The housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s eyes brightened; she had expressly\r\ncalculated on this result. After a moment\xe2\x80\x99s thinking, she addressed her\r\nmaster with another question: \xe2\x80\x9cYou will probably visit Mr. Bygrave\r\nagain, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course I shall visit him\xe2\x80\x94if I please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd perhaps see Miss Bygrave, if she gets better?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not? I should be glad to know why not? Is it necessary to ask your\r\nleave first, Lecount?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means, sir. As you have often said (and as I have often agreed\r\nwith you), you are master. It may surprise you to hear it, Mr. Noel,\r\nbut I have a private reason for wishing that you should see Miss\r\nBygrave again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Noel started a little, and looked at his housekeeper with some\r\ncuriosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a strange fancy of my own, sir, about that young lady,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nproceeded Mrs. Lecount. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you will excuse my fancy, and indulge it,\r\nyou will do me a favor for which I shall be very grateful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fancy?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated her master, in growing surprise. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat fancy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly this, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Lecount.\r\n\r\nShe took from one of the neat little pockets of her apron a morsel of\r\nnote-paper, carefully folded into the smallest possible compass, and\r\nrespectfully placed it in Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are willing to oblige an old and faithful servant, Mr. Noel,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe said, in a very quiet and very impressive manner, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will kindly\r\nput that morsel of paper into your waistcoat pocket; you will open and\r\nread it, for the first time, _when you are next in Miss Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncompany_, and you will say nothing of what has now passed between us to\r\nany living creature, from this time to that. I promise to explain my\r\nstrange request, sir, when you have done what I ask, and when your next\r\ninterview with Miss Bygrave has come to an end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe courtesied with her best grace, and quietly left the room.\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone looked from the folded paper to the door, and from the\r\ndoor back to the folded paper, in unutterable astonishment. A mystery\r\nin his own house! under his own nose! What did it mean?\r\n\r\nIt meant that Mrs. Lecount had not wasted her time that morning. While\r\nthe captain was casting the net over his visitor at North Shingles, the\r\nhousekeeper was steadily mining the ground under his feet. The folded\r\npaper contained nothing less than a carefully written extract from the\r\npersonal description of Magdalen in Miss Garth\xe2\x80\x99s letter. With a daring\r\ningenuity which even Captain Wragge might have envied, Mrs. Lecount had\r\nfound her instrument for exposing the conspiracy in the unsuspecting\r\nperson of the victim himself!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII.\r\n\r\nLate that evening, when Magdalen and Mrs. Wragge came back from their\r\nwalk in the dark, the captain stopped Magdalen on her way upstairs to\r\ninform her of the proceedings of the day. He added the expression of\r\nhis opinion that the time had come for bringing Noel Vanstone, with the\r\nleast possible delay, to the point of making a proposal. She merely\r\nanswered that she understood him, and that she would do what was\r\nrequired of her. Captain Wragge requested her in that case to oblige\r\nhim by joining a walking excursion in Mr. Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s company at\r\nseven o\xe2\x80\x99clock the next morning. \xe2\x80\x9cI will be ready,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied. \xe2\x80\x9cIs\r\nthere anything more?\xe2\x80\x9d There was nothing more. Magdalen bade him\r\ngood-night and returned to her own room.\r\n\r\nShe had shown the same disinclination to remain any longer than was\r\nnecessary in the captain\xe2\x80\x99s company throughout the three days of her\r\nseclusion in the house.\r\n\r\nDuring all that time, instead of appearing to weary of Mrs. Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsociety, she had patiently, almost eagerly, associated herself with her\r\ncompanion\xe2\x80\x99s one absorbing pursuit. She who had often chafed and fretted\r\nin past days under the monotony of her life in the freedom of\r\nCombe-Raven, now accepted without a murmur the monotony of her life at\r\nMrs. Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s work-table. She who had hated the sight of her needle and\r\nthread in old times\xe2\x80\x94who had never yet worn an article of dress of her\r\nown making\xe2\x80\x94now toiled as anxiously over the making of Mrs. Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngown, and bore as patiently with Mrs. Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s blunders, as if the sole\r\nobject of her existence had been the successful completion of that one\r\ndress. Anything was welcome to her\xe2\x80\x94the trivial difficulties of fitting\r\na gown: the small, ceaseless chatter of the poor half-witted creature\r\nwho was so proud of her assistance, and so happy in her\r\ncompany\xe2\x80\x94anything was welcome that shut her out from the coming future,\r\nfrom the destiny to which she stood self-condemned. That sorely-wounded\r\nnature was soothed by such a trifle now as the grasp of her companion\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrough and friendly hand\xe2\x80\x94that desolate heart was cheered, when night\r\nparted them, by Mrs. Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s kiss.\r\n\r\nThe captain\xe2\x80\x99s isolated position in the house produced no depressing\r\neffect on the captain\xe2\x80\x99s easy and equal spirits. Instead of resenting\r\nMagdalen\xe2\x80\x99s systematic avoidance of his society, he looked to results,\r\nand highly approved of it. The more she neglected him for his wife the\r\nmore directly useful she became in the character of Mrs. Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nself-appointed guardian. He had more than once seriously contemplated\r\nrevoking the concession which had been extorted from him, and removing\r\nhis wife, at his own sole responsibility, out of harm\xe2\x80\x99s way; and he had\r\nonly abandoned the idea on discovering that Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s resolution to\r\nkeep Mrs. Wragge in her own company was really serious. While the two\r\nwere together, his main anxiety was set at rest. They kept their door\r\nlocked by his own desire while he was out of the house, and, whatever\r\nMrs. Wragge might do, Magdalen was to be trusted not to open it until\r\nhe came back. That night Captain Wragge enjoyed his cigar with a mind\r\nat ease, and sipped his brandy-and-water in happy ignorance of the\r\npitfall which Mrs. Lecount had prepared for him in the morning.\r\n\r\nPunctually at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock Noel Vanstone made his appearance. The\r\nmoment he entered the room Captain Wragge detected a change in his\r\nvisitor\xe2\x80\x99s look and manner. \xe2\x80\x9cSomething wrong!\xe2\x80\x9d thought the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\r\nhave not done with Mrs. Lecount yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is Miss Bygrave this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Noel Vanstone. \xe2\x80\x9cWell enough,\r\nI hope, for our early walk?\xe2\x80\x9d His half-closed eyes, weak and watery with\r\nthe morning light and the morning air, looked about the room furtively,\r\nand he shifted his place in a restless manner from one chair to\r\nanother, as he made those polite inquiries.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy niece is better\xe2\x80\x94she is dressing for the walk,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the captain,\r\nsteadily observing his restless little friend while he spoke. \xe2\x80\x9cMr.\r\nVanstone!\xe2\x80\x9d he added, on a sudden, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a plain Englishman\xe2\x80\x94excuse my\r\nblunt way of speaking my mind. You don\xe2\x80\x99t meet me this morning as\r\ncordially as you met me yesterday. There is something unsettled in your\r\nface. I distrust that housekeeper of yours, sir! Has she been presuming\r\non your forbearance? Has she been trying to poison your mind against me\r\nor my niece?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf Noel Vanstone had obeyed Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s injunctions, and had kept\r\nher little morsel of note-paper folded in his pocket until the time\r\ncame to use it, Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s designedly blunt appeal might not have\r\nfound him unprepared with an answer. But curiosity had got the better\r\nof him; he had opened the note at night, and again in the morning; it\r\nhad seriously perplexed and startled him; and it had left his mind far\r\ntoo disturbed to allow him the possession of his ordinary resources. He\r\nhesitated; and his answer, when he succeeded in making it, began with a\r\nprevarication.\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge stopped him before he had got beyond his first sentence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, in his loftiest manner. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\r\nhave secrets to keep, you have only to say so, and I have done. I\r\nintrude on no man\xe2\x80\x99s secrets. At the same time, Mr. Vanstone, you must\r\nallow me to recall to your memory that I met you yesterday without any\r\nreserves on my side. I admitted you to my frankest and fullest\r\nconfidence, sir\xe2\x80\x94and, highly as I prize the advantages of your society,\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t consent to cultivate your friendship on any other than equal\r\nterms.\xe2\x80\x9d He threw open his respectable frock-coat and surveyed his\r\nvisitor with a manly and virtuous severity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean no offense!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Noel Vanstone, piteously. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy do you\r\ninterrupt me, Mr. Bygrave? Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you let me explain? I mean no\r\noffense.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo offense is taken, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have a perfect right\r\nto the exercise of your own discretion. He sent the\r\nservant downstairs again, and, resuming his chair, waited confidently\r\nfor results. In calculating the facilities for practicing on his\r\nvisitor\xe2\x80\x99s weakness, he had one great superiority over Mrs. Lecount. His\r\njudgment was not warped by latent female jealousies, and he avoided the\r\nerror into which the housekeeper had fallen, self-deluded\xe2\x80\x94the error of\r\nunderrating the impression on Noel Vanstone that Magdalen had produced.\r\nOne of the forces in this world which no middle-aged woman is capable\r\nof estimating at its full value, when it acts against her, is the force\r\nof beauty in a woman younger than herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are so hasty, Mr. Bygrave\xe2\x80\x94you won\xe2\x80\x99t give me time\xe2\x80\x94you won\xe2\x80\x99t wait\r\nand hear what I have to say!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Noel Vanstone, piteously, when the\r\nservant had closed the parlor door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy family failing, sir\xe2\x80\x94the blood of the Bygraves. He confusedly described his singular interview of the\r\nprevious evening with Mrs. Lecount, and, taking the folded paper from\r\nhis pocket, placed it in the captain\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\nA suspicion of the truth dawned on Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s mind the moment he\r\nsaw the mysterious note. He withdrew to the window before he opened it.\r\nThe first lines that attracted his attention were these: \xe2\x80\x9cOblige me,\r\nMr. Noel, by comparing the young lady who is now in your company with\r\nthe personal description which follows these lines, and which has been\r\ncommunicated to me by a friend. The one resource in Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s present\r\nsituation was to act instantly on the first impulse of his own\r\naudacity. At that crowning point of the\r\ndescription, an idea crossed his mind; his party-colored eyes twinkled;\r\nhis curly lips twisted up at the corners; Wragge was himself again. He\r\nwheeled round suddenly from the window, and looked Noel Vanstone\r\nstraight in the face with a grimly-quiet suggestiveness of something\r\nserious to come.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray, sir, do you happen to know anything of Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s family?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA respectable family,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s all I know. It is clear to me that Miss\r\nBygrave resembles some other lady who has seriously offended your\r\nhousekeeper\xe2\x80\x94who has been formerly connected, perhaps, with an outbreak\r\nof insanity in your housekeeper\xe2\x80\x94and who is now evidently confused with\r\nmy niece in your housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s wandering mind. That is my conviction,\r\nMr. Vanstone. I may be right, or I may be wrong. All I say is\r\nthis\xe2\x80\x94neither you, nor any man, can assign a sane motive for the\r\nproduction of that incomprehensible document, and for the use which you\r\nare requested to make of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s mad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noel Vanstone, with a very blank\r\nlook, and a very discomposed manner. \xe2\x80\x9cIt couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have escaped me, with\r\nmy habits of observation; it couldn\xe2\x80\x99t possibly have escaped me if\r\nLecount had been mad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good, my dear sir. The greater part of it is not\r\nworth two straws for any purpose of identification; hundreds of young\r\nladies have tall figures, fair complexions, light brown hair, and light\r\ngray eyes. My\r\nflesh-color stood on bruises of all sorts, shades, and sizes, and it\r\nwill stand, I promise you, on your moles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith this assurance, the captain dipped his brush into a little lump of\r\nopaque color which he had mixed in a saucer, and which he had graduated\r\nas nearly as the materials would permit to the color of Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nskin. Not the vestige of a mole was visible on any\r\npart of the smooth white surface of Miss Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s neck. That one central\r\nincident in the events of the morning was of all the incidents that had\r\nhitherto occurred, the most important in its results. There is my advice. What\r\ndo you think of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIf Noel Vanstone could have looked into his counselor\xe2\x80\x99s mind, he might\r\nhave thought the captain\xe2\x80\x99s advice excellently adapted to serve the\r\ncaptain\xe2\x80\x99s interests. As long as Mrs. Lecount could be kept in ignorance\r\nof her master\xe2\x80\x99s visits to North Shingles, so long she would wait until\r\nthe opportunity came for trying her experiment, and so long she might\r\nbe trusted not to endanger the conspiracy by any further proceedings.\r\nNecessarily incapable of viewing Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s advice under this\r\naspect, Noel Vanstone simply looked at it as offering him a temporary\r\nmeans of escape from an explanation with his housekeeper. He eagerly\r\ndeclared that the course of action suggested to him should be followed\r\nto the letter, and returned to Sea View without further delay.\r\n\r\nOn this occasion Captain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s anticipations were in no respect\r\nfalsified by Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s conduct. She had no suspicion of her\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s visit to North Shingles: she had made up her mind, if\r\nnecessary, to wait patiently for his interview with Miss Bygrave until\r\nthe end of the week; and she did not embarrass him by any unexpected\r\nquestions when he announced his intention of holding no personal\r\ncommunication with the Bygraves on that day. All she said was, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou feel well enough, Mr. Noel? or don\xe2\x80\x99t you feel inclined?\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nanswered, shortly, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t feel well enough\xe2\x80\x9d; and there the\r\nconversation ended.\r\n\r\nThe next day the proceedings of the previous morning were exactly\r\nrepeated. This time Noel Vanstone went home rapturously with a keepsake\r\nin his breast-pocket; he had taken tender possession of one of Miss\r\nBygrave\xe2\x80\x99s gloves. At intervals during the day, whenever he was alone,\r\nhe took out the glove and kissed it with a devotion which was almost\r\npassionate in its fervor. The miserable little creature luxuriated in\r\nhis moments of stolen happiness with a speechless and stealthy delight\r\nwhich was a new sensation to him. The few young girls whom he had met\r\nwith, in his father\xe2\x80\x99s narrow circle at Zurich, had felt a mischievous\r\npleasure in treating him like a quaint little plaything; the strongest\r\nimpression he could make on their hearts was an impression in which\r\ntheir lap-dogs might have rivaled him; the deepest interest he could\r\ncreate in them was the interest they might have felt in a new trinket\r\nor a new dress. The only women who had hitherto invited his admiration,\r\nand taken his compliments seriously had been women whose charms were on\r\nthe wane, and whose chances of marriage were fast failing them. For the\r\nfirst time in his life he had now passed hours of happiness in the\r\nsociety of a beautiful girl, who had left him to think of her afterward\r\nwithout a single humiliating remembrance to lower him in his own\r\nesteem.\r\n\r\nAnxiously as he tried to hide it, the change produced in his look and\r\nmanner by the new feeling awakened in him was not a change which could\r\nbe concealed from Mrs. Lecount. On the second day she pointedly asked\r\nhim whether he had not made an arrangement to call on the Bygraves. He\r\ndenied it as before. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you are going to-morrow, Mr. Noel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\npersisted the housekeeper. He was at the end of his resources; he was\r\nimpatient to be rid of her inquiries; he trusted to his friend at North\r\nShingles to help him; and this time he answered Yes. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you see the\r\nyoung lady,\xe2\x80\x9d proceeded Mrs. Lecount, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t forget that note of mine,\r\nsir, which you have in your waistcoat-pocket.\xe2\x80\x9d No more was said on\r\neither side, but by that night\xe2\x80\x99s post the housekeeper wrote to Miss\r\nGarth. The letter merely acknowledged, with thanks, the receipt of Miss\r\nGarth\xe2\x80\x99s communication, and informed her that in a few days Mrs. Lecount\r\nhoped to be in a position to write again and summon Mr. Pendril to\r\nAldborough.\r\n\r\nLate in the evening, when the parlor at North Shingles began to get\r\ndark, and when the captain rang the bell for candles as usual, he was\r\nsurprised by hearing Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s voice in the passage telling the\r\nservant to take the lights downstairs again. She knocked at the door\r\nimmediately afterward, and glided into the obscurity of the room like a\r\nghost.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a question to ask you about your plans for to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid. \xe2\x80\x9cMy eyes are very weak this evening, and I hope you will not\r\nobject to dispense with the candles for a few minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe spoke in low, stifled tones, and felt her way noiselessly to a\r\nchair far removed from the captain in the darkest part of the room.\r\nSitting near the window, he could just discern the dim outline of her\r\ndress, he could just hear the faint accents of her voice. For the last\r\ntwo days he had seen nothing of her except during their morning walk.\r\nOn that afternoon he had found his wife crying in the little backroom\r\ndown-stairs. She could only tell him that Magdalen had frightened\r\nher\xe2\x80\x94that Magdalen was going the way again which she had gone when the\r\nletter came from China in the terrible past time at Vauxhall Walk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was sorry to hear that you were ill to-day, from Mrs. Wragge,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe captain, unconsciously dropping his voice almost to a whisper as he\r\nspoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered quietly, out of the darkness. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nstrong enough to suffer, and live. Other girls in my place would have\r\nbeen happier\xe2\x80\x94they would have suffered, and died. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter; it\r\nwill be all the same a hundred years hence. Is he coming again tomorrow\r\nmorning at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is coming, if you feel no objection to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no objection to make; I have done with objecting. But I should\r\nlike to have the time altered. I don\xe2\x80\x99t look my best in the early\r\nmorning\xe2\x80\x94-I have bad nights, and I rise haggard and worn. Write him a\r\nnote this evening, and tell him to come at twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwelve is rather late, under the circumstances, for you to be seen out\r\nwalking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no intention of walking. Let him be shown into the parlor\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer voice died away in silence before she ended the sentence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes?\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Wragge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd leave me alone in the parlor to receive him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cAn admirable idea. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be out of\r\nthe way in the dining-room while he is here, and you can come and tell\r\nme about it when he has gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was another moment of silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there no way but telling you?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cI can control\r\nmyself while he is with me, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t answer for what I may say or do\r\nafterward. Is there no other way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlenty of ways,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cHere is the first that occurs to\r\nme. Leave the blind down over the window of your room upstairs before\r\nhe comes. I will go out on the beach, and wait there within sight of\r\nthe house. When I see him come out again, I will look at the window. If\r\nhe has said nothing, leave the blind down. If he has made you an offer,\r\ndraw the blind up. The signal is simplicity itself; we can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmisunderstand each other. Look your best to-morrow! Make sure of him,\r\nmy dear girl\xe2\x80\x94make sure of him, if you possibly can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe had spoken loud enough to feel certain that she had heard him, but\r\nno answering word came from her. The dead silence was only disturbed by\r\nthe rustling of her dress, which told him she had risen from her chair.\r\nHer shadowy presence crossed the room again; the door shut softly; she\r\nwas gone. He rang the bell hurriedly for the lights. The servant found\r\nhim standing close at the window, looking less self-possessed than\r\nusual. He told her he felt a little poorly, and sent her to the\r\ncupboard for the brandy.\r\n\r\nAt a few minutes before twelve the next day Captain Wragge withdrew to\r\nhis post of observation, concealing himself behind a fishing-boat drawn\r\nup on the beach. Punctually as the hour struck, he saw Noel Vanstone\r\napproach North Shingles and open the garden gate. When the house door\r\nhad closed on the visitor, Captain Wragge settled himself comfortably\r\nagainst the side of the boat and lit his cigar.\r\n\r\nHe smoked for half an hour\xe2\x80\x94for ten minutes over the half-hour, by his\r\nwatch. He finished the cigar down to the last morsel of it that he\r\ncould hold in his lips. Just as he had thrown away the end, the door\r\nopened again and Noel Vanstone came out.\r\n\r\nThe captain looked up instantly at Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s window. In the absorbing\r\nexcitement of the moment, he counted the seconds. She might get from\r\nthe parlor to her own room in less than a minute. He counted to thirty,\r\nand nothing happened. He counted to fifty, and nothing happened. He\r\ngave up counting, and left the boat impatiently, to return to the\r\nhouse.\r\n\r\nAs he took his first step forward he saw the signal.\r\n\r\nThe blind was drawn up.\r\n\r\nCautiously ascending the eminence of the beach, Captain Wragge looked\r\ntoward Sea-view Cottage before he showed himself on the Parade. Noel\r\nVanstone had reached home again; he was just entering his own door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf all your money was offered me to stand in your shoes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ncaptain, looking after him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9crich as you are, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t take it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII.\r\n\r\nOn returning to the house, Captain Wragge received a significant\r\nmessage from the servant. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Noel Vanstone would call again at two\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock that afternoon, when he hoped to have the pleasure of finding\r\nMr. Bygrave at home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe captain\xe2\x80\x99s first inquiry after hearing this message referred to\r\nMagdalen. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere was Miss Bygrave?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIn her own room.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWhere was Mrs.\r\nBygrave?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIn the back parlor.\xe2\x80\x9d Captain Wragge turned his steps at once\r\nin the latter direction, and found his wife, for the second time, in\r\ntears. She had been sent out of Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s room for the whole day, and\r\nshe was at her wits\xe2\x80\x99 end to know what she had done to deserve it.\r\nShortening her lamentations without ceremony, her husband sent her\r\nupstairs on the spot, with instructions to knock at the door, and to\r\ninquire whether Magdalen could give five minutes\xe2\x80\x99 attention to a\r\nquestion of importance which must be settled before two o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\n\r\nThe answer returned was in the negative. Magdalen requested that the\r\nsubject on which she was asked to decide might be mentioned to her in\r\nwriting. She engaged to reply in the same way, on the understanding\r\nthat Mrs. Wragge, and not the servant, should be employed to deliver\r\nthe note and to take back the answer.\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge forthwith opened his paper-case and wrote these lines:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAccept my warmest congratulations on the result of your interview with\r\nMr. N. V. He is coming again at two o\xe2\x80\x99clock\xe2\x80\x94no doubt to make his\r\nproposals in due form. The question to decide is, whether I shall press\r\nhim or not on the subject of settlements. The considerations for your\r\nown mind are two in number. First, whether the said pressure (without\r\nat all underrating your influence over him) may not squeeze for a long\r\ntime before it squeezes money out of Mr. N. V. Secondly, whether we are\r\naltogether justified\xe2\x80\x94considering our present position toward a certain\r\nsharp practitioner in petticoats\xe2\x80\x94in running the risk of delay. Consider\r\nthese points, and let me have your decision as soon as convenient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe answer returned to this note was written in crooked, blotted\r\ncharacters, strangely unlike Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s usually firm and clear\r\nhandwriting. It only contained these words: \xe2\x80\x9cGive yourself no trouble\r\nabout settlements. Leave the use to which he is to put his money for\r\nthe future in my hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you see her?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the captain, when his wife had delivered the\r\nanswer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tried,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Wragge, with a fresh burst of tears\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut she only\r\nopened the door far enough to put out her hand. I took and gave it a\r\nlittle squeeze\xe2\x80\x94and, oh poor soul, it felt so cold in mine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s master made his appearance at two o\xe2\x80\x99clock, he stood\r\nalarmingly in need of an anodyne application from Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s green\r\nfan. The agitation of making his avowal to Magdalen; the terror of\r\nfinding himself discovered by the housekeeper; the tormenting suspicion\r\nof the hard pecuniary conditions which Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s relative and guardian\r\nmight impose on him\xe2\x80\x94all these emotions, stirring in conflict together,\r\nhad overpowered his feebly-working heart with a trial that strained it\r\nsorely. He gasped for breath as he sat down in the parlor at North\r\nShingles, and that ominous bluish pallor which always overspread his\r\nface in moments of agitation now made its warning appearance again.\r\nCaptain Wragge seized the brandy bottle in genuine alarm, and forced\r\nhis visitor to drink a wine-glassful of the spirit before a word was\r\nsaid between them on either side.\r\n\r\nRestored by the stimulant, and encouraged by the readiness with which\r\nthe captain anticipated everything that he had to say, Noel Vanstone\r\ncontrived to state the serious object of his visit in tolerably plain\r\nterms. All the conventional preliminaries proper to the occasion were\r\neasily disposed of. The suitor\xe2\x80\x99s family was respectable; his position\r\nin life was undeniably satisfactory; his attachment, though hasty, was\r\nevidently disinterested and sincere. All that Captain Wragge had to do\r\nwas to refer to these various considerations with a happy choice of\r\nlanguage in a voice that trembled with manly emotion, and this he did\r\nto perfection. For the first half-hour of the interview, no allusion\r\nwhatever was made to the delicate and dangerous part of the subject.\r\nThe captain waited until he had composed his visitor, and when that\r\nresult was achieved came smoothly to the point in these terms:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is one little difficulty, Mr. Vanstone, which I think we have\r\nboth overlooked. Your housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s recent conduct inclines me to fear\r\nthat she will view the approaching change in your life with anything\r\nbut a friendly eye. Probably you have not thought it necessary yet to\r\ninform her of the new tie which you propose to form?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone turned pale at the bare idea of explaining himself to\r\nMrs. Lecount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t tell what I\xe2\x80\x99m to do,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, glancing aside nervously at the\r\nwindow, as if he expected to see the housekeeper peeping in. \xe2\x80\x9cI hate\r\nall awkward positions, and this is the most unpleasant position I ever\r\nwas placed in. You don\xe2\x80\x99t know what a terrible woman Lecount is. I\xe2\x80\x99m not\r\nafraid of her; pray don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid of her\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt those words his fears rose in his throat, and gave him the lie\r\ndirect by stopping his utterance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray don\xe2\x80\x99t trouble yourself to explain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Wragge, coming\r\nto the rescue. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the common story, Mr. Vanstone. Here is a woman\r\nwho has grown old in your service, and in your father\xe2\x80\x99s service before\r\nyou; a woman who has contrived, in all sorts of small, underhand ways,\r\nto presume systematically on her position for years and years past; a\r\nwoman, in short, whom your inconsiderate but perfectly natural kindness\r\nhas allowed to claim a right of property in you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProperty!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Noel Vanstone, mistaking the captain, and letting the\r\ntruth escape him through sheer inability to conceal his fears any\r\nlonger. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what amount of property she won\xe2\x80\x99t claim. She\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nmake me pay for my father as well as for myself. Thousands, Mr.\r\nBygrave\xe2\x80\x94thousands of pounds sterling out of my pocket!!!\xe2\x80\x9d He clasped\r\nhis hands in despair at the picture of pecuniary compulsion which his\r\nfancy had conjured up\xe2\x80\x94his own golden life-blood spouting from him in\r\ngreat jets of prodigality, under the lancet of Mrs. Lecount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGently, Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x94gently! The woman knows nothing so far, and the\r\nmoney is not gone yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no; the money is not gone, as you say. I\xe2\x80\x99m only nervous about it;\r\nI can\xe2\x80\x99t help being nervous. You were saying something just now; you\r\nwere going to give me advice. I value your advice; you don\xe2\x80\x99t know how\r\nhighly I value your advice.\xe2\x80\x9d He said those words with a conciliatory\r\nsmile which was more than helpless; it was absolutely servile in its\r\ndependence on his judicious friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was only assuring you, my dear sir, that I understood your\r\nposition,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cI see your difficulty as plainly as you\r\ncan see it yourself. Tell a woman like Mrs. Lecount that she must come\r\noff her domestic throne, to make way for a young and beautiful\r\nsuccessor, armed with the authority of a wife, and an unpleasant scene\r\nmust be the inevitable result. An unpleasant scene, Mr. Vanstone, if\r\nyour opinion of your housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s sanity is well founded. Something\r\nfar more serious, if my opinion that her intellect is unsettled happens\r\nto turn out the right one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t say it isn\xe2\x80\x99t my opinion, too,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Noel Vanstone.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEspecially after what has happened to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge immediately begged to know what the event alluded to\r\nmight be.\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone thereupon explained\xe2\x80\x94with an infinite number of\r\nparentheses all referring to himself\xe2\x80\x94that Mrs. Lecount had put the\r\ndreaded question relating to the little note in her master\xe2\x80\x99s pocket\r\nbarely an hour since. He had answered her inquiry as Mr. Bygrave had\r\nadvised him. On hearing that the accuracy of the personal description\r\nhad been fairly put to the test, and had failed in the one important\r\nparticular of the moles on the neck, Mrs. Lecount had considered a\r\nlittle, and had then asked him whether he had shown her note to Mr.\r\nBygrave before the experiment was tried. He had answered in the\r\nnegative, as the only safe form of reply that he could think of on the\r\nspur of the moment, and the housekeeper had then addressed him in these\r\nstrange and startling words: \xe2\x80\x9cYou are keeping the truth from me, Mr.\r\nNoel. You are trusting strangers, and doubting your old servant and\r\nyour old friend. Every time you go to Mr. Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s house, every time\r\nyou see Miss Bygrave, you are drawing nearer and nearer to your\r\ndestruction. They have got the bandage over your eyes in spite of me;\r\nbut I tell them, and tell you, before many days are over I will take it\r\noff!\xe2\x80\x9d To this extraordinary outbreak\xe2\x80\x94accompanied as it was by an\r\nexpression in Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s face which he had never seen there\r\nbefore\xe2\x80\x94Noel Vanstone had made no reply. Mr. Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s conviction that\r\nthere was a lurking taint of insanity in the housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s blood had\r\nrecurred to his memory, and he had left the room at the first\r\nopportunity.\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge listened with the closest attention to the narrative\r\nthus presented to him. But one conclusion could be drawn from it\xe2\x80\x94it was\r\na plain warning to him to hasten the end.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not surprised,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cto hear that you are inclining\r\nmore favorably to my opinion. After what you have just told me, Mr.\r\nVanstone, no sensible man could do otherwise. This is becoming serious.\r\nI hardly know what results may not be expected to follow the\r\ncommunication of your approaching change in life to Mrs. Lecount. My\r\nniece may be involved in those results. She is nervous; she is\r\nsensitive in the highest degree; she is the innocent object of this\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s unreasoning hatred and distrust. You alarm me, sir! I am not\r\neasily thrown off my balance, but I acknowledge you alarm me for the\r\nfuture.\xe2\x80\x9d He frowned, shook his head, and looked at his visitor\r\ndespondently.\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone began to feel uneasy. The change in Mr. Bygrave\xe2\x80\x99s manner\r\nseemed ominous of a reconsideration of his proposals from a new and\r\nunfavorable point of view. He took counsel of his inborn cowardice and\r\nhis inborn cunning, and proposed a solution of the difficulty\r\ndiscovered by himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should we tell Lecount at all?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat right has Lecount\r\nto know? Can\xe2\x80\x99t we be married without letting her into the secret? And\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t somebody tell her afterward when we are both out of her reach?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge received this proposal with an expression of surprise\r\nwhich did infinite credit to his power of control over his own\r\ncountenance. His foremost object throughout the interview had been to\r\nconduct it to this point, or, in other words, to make the first idea of\r\nkeeping the marriage a secret from Mrs. Lecount emanate from Noel\r\nVanstone instead of from himself. No one knew better than the captain\r\nthat the only responsibilities which a weak man ever accepts are\r\nresponsibilities which can be perpetually pointed out to him as resting\r\nexclusively on his own shoulders.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am accustomed to set my face against clandestine proceedings of all\r\nkinds,\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Wragge. \xe2\x80\x9cBut there are exceptions to the strictest\r\nrules; and I am bound to admit, Mr. Vanstone, that your position in\r\nthis matter is an exceptional position, if ever there was one yet. The\r\ncourse you have just proposed\xe2\x80\x94however unbecoming I may think it,\r\nhowever distasteful it may be to myself\xe2\x80\x94would not only spare you a very\r\nserious embarrassment (to say the least of it), but would also protect\r\nyou from the personal assertion of those pecuniary claims on the part\r\nof your housekeeper to which you have already adverted. These are both\r\ndesirable results to achieve\xe2\x80\x94to say nothing of the removal, on my side,\r\nof all apprehension of annoyance to my niece. On the other hand,\r\nhowever, a marriage solemnized with such privacy as you propose must be\r\na hasty marriage; for, as we are situated, the longer the delay the\r\ngreater will be the risk that our secret may escape our keeping. I am\r\nnot against hasty marriages where a mutual flame is fanned by an\r\nadequate income. My own was a love-match contracted in a hurry. There\r\nare plenty of instances in the experience of every one, of short\r\ncourtships and speedy marriages, which have turned up trumps\xe2\x80\x94I beg your\r\npardon\xe2\x80\x94which have turned out well after all. But if you and my niece,\r\nMr. Vanstone, are to add one to the number of these eases, the usual\r\npreliminaries of marriage among the higher classes must be hastened by\r\nsome means. You doubtless understand me as now referring to the subject\r\nof settlements.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take another teaspoonful of brandy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noel Vanstone, holding\r\nout his glass with a trembling hand as the word \xe2\x80\x9csettlements\xe2\x80\x9d passed\r\nCaptain Wragge\xe2\x80\x99s lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take a teaspoonful with you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, nimbly\r\ndismounting from the pedestal of his respectability, and sipping his\r\nbrandy with the highest relish. Noel Vanstone, after nervously\r\nfollowing his host\xe2\x80\x99s example, composed himself to meet the coming\r\nordeal, with reclining head and grasping hands, in the position\r\nfamiliarly associated to all civilized humanity with a seat in a\r\ndentist\xe2\x80\x99s chair.\r\n\r\nThe captain put down his empty glass and got up again on his pedestal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe were talking of settlements,\xe2\x80\x9d he resumed. \xe2\x80\x9cI have already\r\nmentioned, Mr. Vanstone, at an early period of our conversation, that\r\nmy niece presents the man of her choice with no other dowry than the\r\nmost inestimable of all gifts\xe2\x80\x94the gift of herself. This circumstance,\r\nhowever (as you are no doubt aware), does not disentitle me to make the\r\ncustomary stipulations with her future husband. According to the usual\r\ncourse in this matter, my lawyer would see yours\xe2\x80\x94consultations would\r\ntake place\xe2\x80\x94delays would occur\xe2\x80\x94strangers would be in possession of your\r\nintentions\xe2\x80\x94and Mrs. Lecount would, sooner or later, arrive at that\r\nknowledge of the truth which you are anxious to keep from her. Do you\r\nagree with me so far?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUnutterable apprehension closed Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s lips. He could only\r\nreply by an inclination of the head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery good,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, sir, you may possibly have\r\nobserved that I am a man of a very original turn of mind. If I have not\r\nhitherto struck you in that light, it may then be necessary to mention\r\nthat there are some subjects on which I persist in thinking for myself.\r\nThe subject of marriage settlements is one of them. What, let me ask\r\nyou, does a parent or guardian in my present condition usually do?\r\nAfter having trusted the man whom he has chosen for his son-in-law with\r\nthe sacred deposit of a woman\xe2\x80\x99s happiness, he turns round on that man,\r\nand declines to trust him with the infinitely inferior responsibility\r\nof providing for her pecuniary future. He fetters his son-in-law with\r\nthe most binding document the law can produce, and employs with the\r\nhusband of his own child the same precautions which he would use if he\r\nwere dealing with a stranger and a rogue. I call such conduct as this\r\ninconsistent and unbecoming in the last degree. You will not find it my\r\ncourse of conduct, Mr. Vanstone\xe2\x80\x94you will not find me preaching what I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t practice. If I trust you with my niece, I trust you with every\r\ninferior responsibility toward her and toward me. Give me your hand,\r\nsir; tell me, on your word of honor, that you will provide for your\r\nwife as becomes her position and your means, and the question of\r\nsettlements is decided between us from this moment at once and\r\nforever!\xe2\x80\x9d Having carried out Magdalen\xe2\x80\x99s instructions in this lofty\r\ntone, he threw open his respectable frockcoat, and sat with head erect\r\nand hand extended, the model of parental feeling and the picture of\r\nhuman integrity.\r\n\r\nFor one moment Noel Vanstone remained literally petrified by\r\nastonishment. The next, he started from his chair and wrung the hand of\r\nhis magnanimous friend in a perfect transport of admiration. Never yet,\r\nthroughout his long and varied career, had Captain Wragge felt such\r\ndifficulty in keeping his countenance as he felt now. Contempt for the\r\noutburst of miserly gratitude of which he was the object; triumph in\r\nthe sense of successful conspiracy against a man who had rated the\r\noffer of his protection at five pounds; regret at the lost opportunity\r\nof effecting a fine stroke of moral agriculture, which his dread of\r\ninvolving himself in coming consequences had forced him to let slip\xe2\x80\x94all\r\nthese varied emotions agitated the captain\xe2\x80\x99s mind; all strove together\r\nto find their way to the surface through the outlets of his face or his\r\ntongue. He allowed Noel Vanstone to keep possession of his hand, and to\r\nheap one series of shrill protestations and promises on another, until\r\nhe had regained his usual mastery over himself. That result achieved,\r\nhe put the little man back in his chair, and returned forthwith to the\r\nsubject of Mrs. Lecount.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose we now revert to the difficulty which we have not conquered\r\nyet,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us say that I do violence to my own habits\r\nand feelings; that I allow the considerations I have already mentioned\r\nto weigh with me; and that I sanction your wish to be united to my\r\nniece without the knowledge of Mrs. Lecount. Allow me to inquire in\r\nthat case what means you can suggest for the accomplishment of your\r\nend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t suggest anything,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Noel Vanstone, helplessly. \xe2\x80\x9cWould\r\nyou object to suggest for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are making a bolder request than you think, Mr. Vanstone. I never\r\ndo things by halves. When I am acting with my customary candor, I am\r\nfrank (as you know already) to the utmost verge of imprudence. When\r\nexceptional circumstances compel me to take an opposite course, there\r\nisn\xe2\x80\x99t a slyer fox alive than I am. If, at your express request, I take\r\noff my honest English coat here and put on a Jesuit\xe2\x80\x99s gown\xe2\x80\x94if, purely\r\nout of sympathy for your awkward position, I consent to keep your\r\nsecret for you from Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x94I must have no unseasonable scruples\r\nto contend with on your part. If it is neck or nothing on my side, sir,\r\nit must be neck or nothing on yours also.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeck or nothing, by all means,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noel Vanstone, briskly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9con the\r\nunderstanding that you go first. I have no scruples about keeping\r\nLecount in the dark. But she is devilish cunning, Mr. Bygrave. How is\r\nit to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall hear directly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cBefore I develop my\r\nviews, I should like to have your opinion on an abstract question of\r\nmorality. What do you think, my dear sir, of pious frauds in general?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone looked a little embarrassed by the question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I put it more plainly?\xe2\x80\x9d continued Captain Wragge. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you\r\nsay to the universally-accepted maxim that \xe2\x80\x98all stratagems are fair in\r\nlove and war\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x94Yes or No?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Noel Vanstone, with the utmost readiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne more question and I have done,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you see any\r\nparticular objection to practicing a pious fraud on Mrs. Lecount?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s resolution began to falter a little.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Lecount likely to find it out?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked cautiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe can\xe2\x80\x99t possibly discover it until you are married and out of her\r\nreach.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are sure of that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlay any trick you like on Lecount,\xe2\x80\x9d said Noel Vanstone, with an air\r\nof unutterable relief. \xe2\x80\x9cI have had my suspicions lately that she is\r\ntrying to domineer over me; I am beginning to feel that I have borne\r\nwith Lecount long enough. I wish I was well rid of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall have your wish,\xe2\x80\x9d said Captain Wragge. \xe2\x80\x9cYou shall be rid of\r\nher in a week or ten days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone rose eagerly and approached the captain\xe2\x80\x99s chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t say so!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cHow do you mean to send her away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean to send her on a journey,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Captain Wragge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom your house at Aldborough to her brother\xe2\x80\x99s bedside at Zurich.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone started back at the answer, and returned suddenly to his\r\nchair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you do that?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired, in the greatest perplexity. \xe2\x80\x9cHer\r\nbrother (hang him!) is much better. She had another letter from Zurich\r\nto say so, this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you see the letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. She always worries about her brother\xe2\x80\x94she _would_ show it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was it from? and what did it say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was from the doctor\xe2\x80\x94he always writes to her. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care two\r\nstraws about her brother, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t remember much of the letter,\r\nexcept that it was a short one. The fellow was much better; and if the\r\ndoctor didn\xe2\x80\x99t write again, she might take it for granted that he was\r\ngetting well. That was the substance of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you notice where she put the letter when you gave it her back\r\nagain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. She put it in the drawer where she keeps her account-books.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you get at that drawer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course I can. I have got a duplicate key\xe2\x80\x94I always insist on a\r\nduplicate key of the place where she keeps her account books. I never\r\nallow the account-books to be locked up from my inspection: it\xe2\x80\x99s a rule\r\nof the house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe so good as to get that letter to-day, Mr. Vanstone, without your\r\nhousekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s knowledge, and add to the favor by letting me have it\r\nhere privately for an hour or two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want it for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have some more questions to ask before I tell you. Have you any\r\nintimate friend at Zurich whom you could trust to help you in playing a\r\ntrick on Mrs. Lecount?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of help do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Noel Vanstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuppose,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, \xe2\x80\x9cyou were to send a letter addressed to\r\nMrs. Lecount at Aldborough, inclosed in another letter addressed to one\r\nof your friends abroad? And suppose you were to instruct that friend to\r\nhelp a harmless practical joke by posting Mrs. Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s letter at\r\nZurich? Do you know any one who could be trusted to do that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know two people who could be trusted!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Noel Vanstone. \xe2\x80\x9cBoth\r\nladies\xe2\x80\x94both spinsters\xe2\x80\x94both bitter enemies of Lecount\xe2\x80\x99s. But what is\r\nyour drift, Mr. Bygrave? Though I am not usually wanting in\r\npenetration, I don\xe2\x80\x99t altogether see your drift.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall see it directly, Mr. Vanstone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith those words he rose, withdrew to his desk in the corner of the\r\nroom, and wrote a few lines on a sheet of note-paper. After first\r\nreading them carefully to himself, he beckoned to Noel Vanstone to come\r\nand read them too.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA few minutes since,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, pointing complacently to his\r\nown composition with the feather end of his pen, \xe2\x80\x9cI had the honor of\r\nsuggesting a pious fraud on Mrs. Lecount. There it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe resigned his chair at the writing-table to his visitor. Noel\r\nVanstone sat down, and read these lines:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMY DEAR MADAM\xe2\x80\x94Since I last wrote, I deeply regret to inform you that\r\nyour brother has suffered a relapse. The symptoms are so serious, that\r\nit is my painful duty to summon you instantly to his bedside. I am\r\nmaking every effort to resist the renewed progress of the malady, and I\r\nhave not yet lost all hope of success. But I cannot reconcile it to my\r\nconscience to leave you in ignorance of a serious change in my patient\r\nfor the worse, which _may_ be attended by fatal results. With much\r\nsympathy, I remain, etc. etc.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCaptain Wragge waited with some anxiety for the effect which this\r\nletter might produce. Mean, selfish, and cowardly as he was, even Noel\r\nVanstone might feel some compunction at practicing such a deception as\r\nwas here suggested on a woman who stood toward him in the position of\r\nMrs. Lecount. She had served him faithfully, however interested her\r\nmotives might be\xe2\x80\x94she had lived since he was a lad in the full\r\npossession of his father\xe2\x80\x99s confidence\xe2\x80\x94she was living now under the\r\nprotection of his own roof. Could he fail to remember this; and,\r\nremembering it, could he lend his aid without hesitation to the scheme\r\nwhich was now proposed to him? Captain Wragge unconsciously retained\r\nbelief enough in human nature to doubt it. To his surprise, and, it\r\nmust be added, to his relief, also, his apprehensions proved to be\r\ngroundless. The only emotions aroused in Noel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s mind by a\r\nperusal of the letter were a hearty admiration of his friend\xe2\x80\x99s idea,\r\nand a vainglorious anxiety to claim the credit to himself of being the\r\nperson who carried it out. Examples may be found every day of a fool\r\nwho is no coward; examples may be found occasionally of a fool who is\r\nnot cunning; but it may reasonably be doubted whether there is a\r\nproducible instance anywhere of a fool who is not cruel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfect!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Noel Vanstone, clapping his hands. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Bygrave, you\r\nare as good as Figaro in the French comedy. Talking of French, there is\r\none serious mistake in this clever letter of yours\xe2\x80\x94it is written in the\r\nwrong language. When the doctor writes to Lecount, he writes in French.\r\nPerhaps you meant me to translate it? You can\xe2\x80\x99t manage without my help,\r\ncan you? I write French as fluently as I write English. Just look at\r\nme! I\xe2\x80\x99ll translate it, while I sit here, in two strokes of the pen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe completed the translation almost as rapidly as Captain Wragge had\r\nproduced the original. \xe2\x80\x9cWait a minute!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, in high critical\r\ntriumph at discovering another defect in the composition of his\r\ningenious friend. \xe2\x80\x9cThe doctor always dates his letters. Here is no date\r\nto yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI leave the date to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain, with a sardonic smile.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have discovered the fault, my dear sir\xe2\x80\x94pray correct it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone mentally looked into the great gulf which separates the\r\nfaculty that can discover a defect, from the faculty that can apply a\r\nremedy, and, following the example of many a wiser man, declined to\r\ncross over it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t think of taking the liberty,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, politely. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps\r\nyou had a motive for leaving the date out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps I had,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Captain Wragge, with his easiest good-humor.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe date must depend on the time a letter takes to get to Zurich. _I_\r\nhave had no experience on that point\xe2\x80\x94_you_ must have had plenty of\r\nexperience in your father\xe2\x80\x99s time. Give me the benefit of your\r\ninformation, and we will add the date before you leave the\r\nwriting-table.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNoel Vanstone\xe2\x80\x99s experience was, as Captain Wragge had anticipated,\r\nperfectly competent to settle the question of time. The railway\r\nresources of the Continent (in the year eighteen hundred and\r\nforty-seven) were but scanty; and a letter sent at that period from\r\nEngland to Zurich, and from Zurich back again to England, occupied ten\r\ndays in making the double journey by post.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDate the letter in French five days on from to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ncaptain, when he had got his information. \xe2\x80\x9cVery good. The next thing is\r\nto let me have the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s note as soon as you can. I may be obliged\r\nto practice some hours before I can copy your translation in an exact\r\nimitation of the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s handwriting. Have you got any foreign\r\nnote-paper?
